[?1049h[?1h=DATE(1)                          User Commands                         DATE(1)[m
[m
[1mNAME[0m[m
       date - print or set the system date and time[m
[m
[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
       [1mdate[0m [[4mOPTION[24m]... [[4m+FORMAT[24m][m
       [1mdate[0m [[4m-u|--utc|--universal[24m] [[4mMMDDhhmm[24m[[[4mCC[24m][4mYY[24m][[4m.ss[24m]][m
[m
[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
       Display the current time in the given FORMAT, or set the system date.[m
[m
       Mandatory  arguments  to  long  options are mandatory for short options[m
       too.[m
[m
       [1m-d[0m, [1m--date[0m=[4mSTRING[24m[m
              display time described by STRING, not 'now'[m
[m
       [1m-f[0m, [1m--file[0m=[4mDATEFILE[24m[m
              like [1m--date[0m once for each line of DATEFILE[m
[m
       [1m-I[TIMESPEC][0m, [1m--iso-8601[0m[=[4mTIMESPEC[24m][m
              output date/time in ISO 8601 format.  TIMESPEC='date'  for  date[m
[7m Manual page date(1) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K...skipping...
DATE(1)                          User Commands                         DATE(1)[m
[m
[1mNAME[0m[m
       date - print or set the system date and time[m
[m
[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
       [1mdate[0m [[4mOPTION[24m]... [[4m+FORMAT[24m][m
       [1mdate[0m [[4m-u|--utc|--universal[24m] [[4mMMDDhhmm[24m[[[4mCC[24m][4mYY[24m][[4m.ss[24m]][m
[m
[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
       Display the current time in the given FORMAT, or set the system date.[m
[m
       Mandatory  arguments  to  long  options are mandatory for short options[m
       too.[m
[m
       [1m-d[0m, [1m--date[0m=[4mSTRING[24m[m
              display time described by STRING, not 'now'[m
[m
       [1m-f[0m, [1m--file[0m=[4mDATEFILE[24m[m
              like [1m--date[0m once for each line of DATEFILE[m
[m
       [1m-I[TIMESPEC][0m, [1m--iso-8601[0m[=[4mTIMESPEC[24m][m
              output date/time in ISO 8601 format.  TIMESPEC='date'  for  date[m
              only  (the  default), 'hours', 'minutes', 'seconds', or 'ns' for[m
              date and time to the indicated precision.[m
[m
       [1m-r[0m, [1m--reference[0m=[4mFILE[24m[m
              display the last modification time of FILE[m
[m
       [1m-R[0m, [1m--rfc-2822[0m[m
              output date and time in RFC 2822 format.  Example: Mon,  07  Aug[m
              2006 12:34:56 [1m-0600[0m[m
[m
       [1m--rfc-3339[0m=[4mTIMESPEC[24m[m
              output date and time in RFC 3339 format.  TIMESPEC='date', 'sec‚Äê[m
              onds', or 'ns' for date and time  to  the  indicated  precision.[m
              Date  and  time  components  are  separated  by  a single space:[m
              2006-08-07 12:34:56-06:00[m
[m
       [1m-s[0m, [1m--set[0m=[4mSTRING[24m[m
              set time described by STRING[m
[m
       [1m-u[0m, [1m--utc[0m, [1m--universal[0m[m
              print or set Coordinated Universal Time (UTC)[m
[m
       [1m--help[0m display this help and exit[m
[m
       [1m--version[0m[m
              output version information and exit[m
[m
       FORMAT controls the output.  Interpreted sequences are:[m
[m
       %%     a literal %[m
[m
       %a     locale's abbreviated weekday name (e.g., Sun)[m
[m
       %A     locale's full weekday name (e.g., Sunday)[m
[m
       %b     locale's abbreviated month name (e.g., Jan)[m
[m
       %B     locale's full month name (e.g., January)[m
[m
       %c     locale's date and time (e.g., Thu Mar  3 23:05:25 2005)[m
[m
       %C     century; like %Y, except omit last two digits (e.g., 20)[m
[7m Manual page date(1) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[Kss[Kee[Kcc[Koo[Knn[Kdd[K[1;1HDATE(1)                          User Commands                         DATE(1)[m

[35;1H              output date and time in RFC 3339 format.  TIMESPEC='date', 'sec‚Äê[m
[36;1H              onds', or 'ns' for date and time  to  the  indicated  precision.[m
[37;1H              Date  and  time  components  are  separated  by  a single space:[m
[38;1H              2006-08-07 12:34:56-06:00[m
[39;1H[m
[40;1H       [1m-s[0m, [1m--set[0m=[4mSTRING[24m[m
[41;1H              set time described by STRING[m
[42;1H[m
[43;1H       [1m-u[0m, [1m--utc[0m, [1m--universal[0m[m
[44;1H              print or set Coordinated Universal Time (UTC)[m
[45;1H[m
[46;1H       [1m--help[0m display this help and exit[m
[47;1H[m
[48;1H       [1m--version[0m[m
[49;1H              output version information and exit[m
[50;1H[m
[51;1H       FORMAT controls the output.  Interpreted sequences are:[m
[52;1H[m
[53;1H       %%     a literal %[m
[54;1H[m
[55;1H       %a     locale's abbreviated weekday name (e.g., Sun)[m
[56;1H[m
[57;1H       %A     locale's full weekday name (e.g., Sunday)[m
[58;1H[m
[59;1H       %b     locale's abbreviated month name (e.g., Jan)[m
[60;1H[m
[61;1H       %B     locale's full month name (e.g., January)[m
[62;1H[m
[63;1H       %c     locale's date and time (e.g., Thu Mar  3 23:05:25 2005)[m
[64;1H[m
[65;1H       %C     century; like %Y, except omit last two digits (e.g., 20)[m
[66;1H[m
       %d     day of month (e.g., 01)[m
[m
       %D     date; same as %m/%d/%y[m
[m
       %e     day of month, space padded; same as %_d[m
[m
       %F     full date; same as %Y-%m-%d[m
[m
       %g     last two digits of year of ISO week number (see %G)[m
[m
       %G     year of ISO week number (see %V); normally useful only with %V[m
[m
       %h     same as %b[m
[m
       %H     hour (00..23)[m
[m
       %I     hour (01..12)[m
[m
       %j     day of year (001..366)[m
[m
       %k     hour, space padded ( 0..23); same as %_H[m
[m
[7m Manual page date(1) line 26/214 42% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[K...skipping...
       %N     nano[7msecond[27ms (000000000..999999999)[m
[m
       %p     locale's equivalent of either AM or PM; blank if not known[m
[m
       %P     like %p, but lower case[m
[m
       %r     locale's 12-hour clock time (e.g., 11:11:04 PM)[m
[m
       %R     24-hour hour and minute; same as %H:%M[m
[m
       %s     [7msecond[27ms since 1970-01-01 00:00:00 UTC[m
[m
       %S     [7msecond[27m (00..60)[m
[m
       %t     a tab[m
[m
       %T     time; same as %H:%M:%S[m
[m
       %u     day of week (1..7); 1 is Monday[m
[m
       %U     week number of year, with Sunday as first day of week (00..53)[m
[m
       %V     ISO week number, with Monday as first day of week (01..53)[m
[m
       %w     day of week (0..6); 0 is Sunday[m
[m
       %W     week number of year, with Monday as first day of week (00..53)[m
[m
       %x     locale's date representation (e.g., 12/31/99)[m
[m
       %X     locale's time representation (e.g., 23:13:48)[m
[m
       %y     last two digits of year (00..99)[m
[m
       %Y     year[m
[m
       %z     +hhmm numeric time zone (e.g., [1m-0400[0m)[m
[m
       %:z    +hh:mm numeric time zone (e.g., [1m-04[0m:00)[m
[m
       %::z   +hh:mm:ss numeric time zone (e.g., [1m-04[0m:00:00)[m
[m
       %:::z  numeric time zone with :  to  necessary  precision  (e.g.,  [1m-04[0m,[m
              +05:30)[m
[m
       %Z     alphabetic time zone abbreviation (e.g., EDT)[m
[m
       By  default,  date  pads  numeric  fields  with  zeroes.  The following[m
       optional flags may follow '%':[m
[m
       -      (hyphen) do not pad the field[m
[m
       _      (underscore) pad with spaces[m
[m
       0      (zero) pad with zeros[m
[m
       ^      use upper case if possible[m
[m
       #      use opposite case if possible[m
[m
       After any flags comes an optional field width,  as  a  decimal  number;[m
       then an optional modifier, which is either E to use the locale's alter‚Äê[m
       nate representations if available, or O to use the  locale's  alternate[m
       numeric symbols if available.[m
[m

]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 15:12:50]# date "%s"[1Pman date
[?1049h[?1h=DATE(1)                                                                                                       User Commands                                                                                                       DATE(1)[m
[m
[1mNAME[0m[m
       date - print or set the system date and time[m
[m
[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
       [1mdate[0m [[4mOPTION[24m]... [[4m+FORMAT[24m][m
       [1mdate[0m [[4m-u|--utc|--universal[24m] [[4mMMDDhhmm[24m[[[4mCC[24m][4mYY[24m][[4m.ss[24m]][m
[m
[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
       Display the current time in the given FORMAT, or set the system date.[m
[m
       Mandatory arguments to long options are mandatory for short options too.[m
[m
       [1m-d[0m, [1m--date[0m=[4mSTRING[24m[m
              display time described by STRING, not 'now'[m
[m
       [1m-f[0m, [1m--file[0m=[4mDATEFILE[24m[m
              like [1m--date[0m once for each line of DATEFILE[m
[m
       [1m-I[TIMESPEC][0m, [1m--iso-8601[0m[=[4mTIMESPEC[24m][m
              output date/time in ISO 8601 format.  TIMESPEC='date' for date only (the default), 'hours', 'minutes', 'seconds', or 'ns' for date and time to the indicated precision.[m
[m
       [1m-r[0m, [1m--reference[0m=[4mFILE[24m[m
              display the last modification time of FILE[m
[m
       [1m-R[0m, [1m--rfc-2822[0m[m
              output date and time in RFC 2822 format.  Example: Mon, 07 Aug 2006 12:34:56 [1m-0600[0m[m
[m
       [1m--rfc-3339[0m=[4mTIMESPEC[24m[m
              output date and time in RFC 3339 format.  TIMESPEC='date', 'seconds', or 'ns' for date and time to the indicated precision.  Date and time components are separated by a single space: 2006-08-07 12:34:56-06:00[m
[m
       [1m-s[0m, [1m--set[0m=[4mSTRING[24m[m
              set time described by STRING[m
[m
       [1m-u[0m, [1m--utc[0m, [1m--universal[0m[m
              print or set Coordinated Universal Time (UTC)[m
[m
       [1m--help[0m display this help and exit[m
[m
       [1m--version[0m[m
              output version information and exit[m
[m
       FORMAT controls the output.  Interpreted sequences are:[m
[m
       %%     a literal %[m
[m
       %a     locale's abbreviated weekday name (e.g., Sun)[m
[m
       %A     locale's full weekday name (e.g., Sunday)[m
[m
       %b     locale's abbreviated month name (e.g., Jan)[m
[m
       %B     locale's full month name (e.g., January)[m
[m
       %c     locale's date and time (e.g., Thu Mar  3 23:05:25 2005)[m
[m
       %C     century; like %Y, except omit last two digits (e.g., 20)[m
[m
       %d     day of month (e.g., 01)[m
[m
       %D     date; same as %m/%d/%y[m
[m
       %e     day of month, space padded; same as %_d[m
[m
[7m Manual page date(1) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[Kff[Koo[Krr[Kmm[Kaa[Ktt[Kqq[K[K[1;1HDATE(1)                                                                                                       User Commands                                                                                                       DATE(1)[m

[33;1H       [1m-s[0m, [1m--set[0m=[4mSTRING[24m[m

[39;1H       [1m--help[0m display this help and exit[m

[41;1H       [1m--version[0m[m

[43;1H[m
[44;1H       FORMAT controls the output.  Interpreted sequences are:[m
[45;1H[m
[46;1H       %%     a literal %[m
[47;1H[m
[48;1H       %a     locale's abbreviated weekday name (e.g., Sun)[m
[49;1H[m
[50;1H       %A     locale's full weekday name (e.g., Sunday)[m
[51;1H[m
[52;1H       %b     locale's abbreviated month name (e.g., Jan)[m
[53;1H[m
[54;1H       %B     locale's full month name (e.g., January)[m
[55;1H[m
[56;1H       %c     locale's date and time (e.g., Thu Mar  3 23:05:25 2005)[m
[57;1H[m
[58;1H       %C     century; like %Y, except omit last two digits (e.g., 20)[m
[59;1H[m
[60;1H       %d     day of month (e.g., 01)[m
[61;1H[m
[62;1H       %D     date; same as %m/%d/%y[m
[63;1H[m
[64;1H       %e     day of month, space padded; same as %_d[m
[65;1H[m
[66;1H[1;1HDATE(1)                                                                                                       User Commands                                                                                                       DATE(1)[m
[2;1H[m
[3;1H[1mNAME[0m[m
[4;1H       date - print or set the system date and time[m
[5;1H[m
[6;1H[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
[7;1H       [1mdate[0m [[4mOPTION[24m]... [[4m+[24m[4m[7mFORMAT[27m[24m][m
[8;1H       [1mdate[0m [[4m-u|--utc|--universal[24m] [[4mMMDDhhmm[24m[[[4mCC[24m][4mYY[24m][[4m.ss[24m]][m
[9;1H[m
[10;1H[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
[11;1H       Display the current time in the given [7mFORMAT[27m, or set the system date.[m
[12;1H[m
[13;1H       Mandatory arguments to long options are mandatory for short options too.[m
[14;1H[m
[15;1H       [1m-d[0m, [1m--date[0m=[4mSTRING[24m[m
[16;1H              display time described by STRING, not 'now'[m
[17;1H[m
[18;1H       [1m-f[0m, [1m--file[0m=[4mDATEFILE[24m[m
[19;1H              like [1m--date[0m once for each line of DATEFILE[m
[20;1H[m
[21;1H       [1m-I[TIMESPEC][0m, [1m--iso-8601[0m[=[4mTIMESPEC[24m][m
[22;1H              output date/time in ISO 8601 [7mformat[27m.  TIMESPEC='date' for date only (the default), 'hours', 'minutes', 'seconds', or 'ns' for date and time to the indicated precision.[m
[23;1H[m
[24;1H       [1m-r[0m, [1m--reference[0m=[4mFILE[24m[m
[25;1H              display the last modification time of FILE[m
[26;1H[m
[27;1H       [1m-R[0m, [1m--rfc-2822[0m[m
[28;1H              output date and time in RFC 2822 [7mformat[27m.  Example: Mon, 07 Aug 2006 12:34:56 [1m-0600[0m[m
[29;1H[m
[30;1H       [1m--rfc-3339[0m=[4mTIMESPEC[24m[m
[31;1H              output date and time in RFC 3339 [7mformat[27m.  TIMESPEC='date', 'seconds', or 'ns' for date and time to the indicated precision.  Date and time components are separated by a single space: 2006-08-07 12:34:56-06:00[m
[32;1H[m
[33;1H       [1m-s[0m, [1m--set[0m=[4mSTRING[24m[m
[34;1H              set time described by STRING[m
[35;1H[m
[36;1H       [1m-u[0m, [1m--utc[0m, [1m--universal[0m[m
[37;1H              print or set Coordinated Universal Time (UTC)[m
[38;1H[m
[39;1H       [1m--help[0m display this help and exit[m
[40;1H[m
[41;1H       [1m--version[0m[m
[42;1H              output version in[7mformat[27mion and exit[m
[43;1H[m
[44;1H       [7mFORMAT[27m controls the output.  Interpreted sequences are:[m
[45;1H[m
[46;1H       %%     a literal %[m
[47;1H[m
[48;1H       %a     locale's abbreviated weekday name (e.g., Sun)[m
[49;1H[m
[50;1H       %A     locale's full weekday name (e.g., Sunday)[m
[51;1H[m
[52;1H       %b     locale's abbreviated month name (e.g., Jan)[m
[53;1H[m
[54;1H       %B     locale's full month name (e.g., January)[m
[55;1H[m
[56;1H       %c     locale's date and time (e.g., Thu Mar  3 23:05:25 2005)[m
[57;1H[m
[58;1H       %C     century; like %Y, except omit last two digits (e.g., 20)[m
[59;1H[m
[60;1H       %d     day of month (e.g., 01)[m
[61;1H[m
[62;1H       %D     date; same as %m/%d/%y[m
[63;1H[m
[64;1H       %e     day of month, space padded; same as %_d[m
[65;1H[m
[66;1H       %F     full date; same as %Y-%m-%d[m
[m
       %g     last two digits of year of ISO week number (see %G)[m
[m
       %G     year of ISO week number (see %V); normally useful only with %V[m
[m

[?1049h[?1h=DATE(1)                                                                                                       User Commands                                                                                                       DATE(1)[m
[m
[1mNAME[0m[m
       date - print or set the system date and time[m
[m
[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
       [1mdate[0m [[4mOPTION[24m]... [[4m+FORMAT[24m][m
       [1mdate[0m [[4m-u|--utc|--universal[24m] [[4mMMDDhhmm[24m[[[4mCC[24m][4mYY[24m][[4m.ss[24m]][m
[m
[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
       Display the current time in the given FORMAT, or set the system date.[m
[m
       Mandatory arguments to long options are mandatory for short options too.[m
[m
       [1m-d[0m, [1m--date[0m=[4mSTRING[24m[m
              display time described by STRING, not 'now'[m
[m
       [1m-f[0m, [1m--file[0m=[4mDATEFILE[24m[m
              like [1m--date[0m once for each line of DATEFILE[m
[m
       [1m-I[TIMESPEC][0m, [1m--iso-8601[0m[=[4mTIMESPEC[24m][m
              output date/time in ISO 8601 format.  TIMESPEC='date' for date only (the default), 'hours', 'minutes', 'seconds', or 'ns' for date and time to the indicated precision.[m
[m
       [1m-r[0m, [1m--reference[0m=[4mFILE[24m[m
              display the last modification time of FILE[m
[m
       [1m-R[0m, [1m--rfc-2822[0m[m
              output date and time in RFC 2822 format.  Example: Mon, 07 Aug 2006 12:34:56 [1m-0600[0m[m
[m
       [1m--rfc-3339[0m=[4mTIMESPEC[24m[m
              output date and time in RFC 3339 format.  TIMESPEC='date', 'seconds', or 'ns' for date and time to the indicated precision.  Date and time components are separated by a single space: 2006-08-07 12:34:56-06:00[m
[m
       [1m-s[0m, [1m--set[0m=[4mSTRING[24m[m
              set time described by STRING[m
[m
       [1m-u[0m, [1m--utc[0m, [1m--universal[0m[m
              print or set Coordinated Universal Time (UTC)[m
[m
       [1m--help[0m display this help and exit[m
[m
       [1m--version[0m[m
              output version information and exit[m
[m
       FORMAT controls the output.  Interpreted sequences are:[m
[m
       %%     a literal %[m
[m
       %a     locale's abbreviated weekday name (e.g., Sun)[m
[m
       %A     locale's full weekday name (e.g., Sunday)[m
[m
       %b     locale's abbreviated month name (e.g., Jan)[m
[m
       %B     locale's full month name (e.g., January)[m
[m
       %c     locale's date and time (e.g., Thu Mar  3 23:05:25 2005)[m
[m
       %C     century; like %Y, except omit last two digits (e.g., 20)[m
[m
       %d     day of month (e.g., 01)[m
[m
       %D     date; same as %m/%d/%y[m
[m
       %e     day of month, space padded; same as %_d[m

[66;1H[1;1HDATE(1)                                                                                                       User Commands                                                                                                       DATE(1)[m
[2;1H[m
[3;1H[1mNAME[0m[m
[4;1H       date - print or set the system date and time[m
[5;1H[m
[6;1H[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
[7;1H       [1mdate[0m [[4mOPTION[24m]... [[4m+FORMAT[24m][m
[8;1H       [1mdate[0m [[4m-u|--utc|--universal[24m] [[4mMMDDhhmm[24m[[[4mCC[24m][4mYY[24m][[4m.ss[24m]][m
[9;1H[m
[10;1H[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
[11;1H       Display the current time in the given FORMAT, or set the system date.[m
[12;1H[m
[13;1H       Mandatory arguments to long options are mandatory for short options too.[m
[14;1H[m
[15;1H       [1m-d[0m, [1m--date[0m=[4mSTRING[24m[m
[16;1H              display time described by STRING, not 'now'[m
[17;1H[m
[18;1H       [1m-f[0m, [1m--file[0m=[4mDATEFILE[24m[m
[19;1H              like [1m--date[0m once for each line of DATEFILE[m
[20;1H[m
[21;1H       [1m-I[TIMESPEC][0m, [1m--iso-8601[0m[=[4mTIMESPEC[24m][m
[22;1H              output date/time in ISO 8601 format.  TIMESPEC='date' for date only (the default), 'hours', 'minutes', '[7msecond[27ms', or 'ns' for date and time to the indicated precision.[m
[23;1H[m
[24;1H       [1m-r[0m, [1m--reference[0m=[4mFILE[24m[m
[25;1H              display the last modification time of FILE[m
[26;1H[m
[27;1H       [1m-R[0m, [1m--rfc-2822[0m[m
[28;1H              output date and time in RFC 2822 format.  Example: Mon, 07 Aug 2006 12:34:56 [1m-0600[0m[m
[29;1H[m
[30;1H       [1m--rfc-3339[0m=[4mTIMESPEC[24m[m
[31;1H              output date and time in RFC 3339 format.  TIMESPEC='date', '[7msecond[27ms', or 'ns' for date and time to the indicated precision.  Date and time components are separated by a single space: 2006-08-07 12:34:56-06:00[m
[32;1H[m
[33;1H       [1m-s[0m, [1m--set[0m=[4mSTRING[24m[m
[34;1H              set time described by STRING[m
[35;1H[m
[36;1H       [1m-u[0m, [1m--utc[0m, [1m--universal[0m[m
[37;1H              print or set Coordinated Universal Time (UTC)[m
[38;1H[m
[39;1H       [1m--help[0m display this help and exit[m
[40;1H[m
[41;1H       [1m--version[0m[m
[42;1H              output version information and exit[m
[43;1H[m
[44;1H       FORMAT controls the output.  Interpreted sequences are:[m
[45;1H[m
[46;1H       %%     a literal %[m
[47;1H[m
[48;1H       %a     locale's abbreviated weekday name (e.g., Sun)[m
[49;1H[m
[50;1H       %A     locale's full weekday name (e.g., Sunday)[m
[51;1H[m
[52;1H       %b     locale's abbreviated month name (e.g., Jan)[m
[53;1H[m
[54;1H       %B     locale's full month name (e.g., January)[m
[55;1H[m
[56;1H       %c     locale's date and time (e.g., Thu Mar  3 23:05:25 2005)[m
[57;1H[m
[58;1H       %C     century; like %Y, except omit last two digits (e.g., 20)[m
[59;1H[m
[60;1H       %d     day of month (e.g., 01)[m
[61;1H[m
[62;1H       %D     date; same as %m/%d/%y[m
[63;1H[m
[64;1H       %e     day of month, space padded; same as %_d[m
[65;1H[m
[66;1H       %F     full date; same as %Y-%m-%d[m
[m
       %g     last two digits of year of ISO week number (see %G)[m
[m
       %G     year of ISO week number (see %V); normally useful only with %V[m
[m
       %h     same as %b[m
[m
       %H     hour (00..23)[m
[m
       %I     hour (01..12)[m
[m
       %j     day of year (001..366)[m
[m
       %k     hour, space padded ( 0..23); same as %_H[m
[m
       %l     hour, space padded ( 1..12); same as %_I[m
[m
       %m     month (01..12)[m
[m
       %M     minute (00..59)[m
[7m Manual page date(1) line 24/192 44% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[K[m
       %n     a newline[m
[m
       %N     nano[7msecond[27ms (000000000..999999999)[m
[m
       %p     locale's equivalent of either AM or PM; blank if not known[m
[m
       %P     like %p, but lower case[m
[m
[7m Manual page date(1) line 33/192 47% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[K       %r     locale's 12-hour clock time (e.g., 11:11:04 PM)[m
[m
       %R     24-hour hour and minute; same as %H:%M[m
[m
       %s     [7msecond[27ms since 1970-01-01 00:00:00 UTC[m
[m
       %S     [7msecond[27m (00..60)[m
[m
       %t     a tab[m
[m
       %T     time; same as %H:%M:%S[m
[m
       %u     day of week (1..7); 1 is Monday[m
[m
       %U     week number of year, with Sunday as first day of week (00..53)[m
[m
       %V     ISO week number, with Monday as first day of week (01..53)[m
[m
       %w     day of week (0..6); 0 is Sunday[m
[m
       %W     week number of year, with Monday as first day of week (00..53)[m
[m
       %x     locale's date representation (e.g., 12/31/99)[m
[m
       %X     locale's time representation (e.g., 23:13:48)[m
[m
       %y     last two digits of year (00..99)[m
[m
       %Y     year[m
[m
       %z     +hhmm numeric time zone (e.g., [1m-0400[0m)[m
[m
       %:z    +hh:mm numeric time zone (e.g., [1m-04[0m:00)[m
[m
       %::z   +hh:mm:ss numeric time zone (e.g., [1m-04[0m:00:00)[m
[m
       %:::z  numeric time zone with : to necessary precision (e.g., [1m-04[0m, +05:30)[m
[m
       %Z     alphabetic time zone abbreviation (e.g., EDT)[m
[m
       By default, date pads numeric fields with zeroes.  The following optional flags may follow '%':[m
[m
       -      (hyphen) do not pad the field[m
[m
       _      (underscore) pad with spaces[m
[m
       0      (zero) pad with zeros[m
[m
       ^      use upper case if possible[m
[m
       #      use opposite case if possible[m
[m
       After any flags comes an optional field width, as a decimal number; then an optional modifier, which is either E to use the locale's alternate representations if available, or O to use the locale's alternate numeric symbols if[m
       available.[m
[m
[1mENVIRONMENT[0m[m
       TZ     Specifies the timezone, unless overridden by command line parameters.  If neither is specified, the setting from /etc/localtime is used.[m
[m
[1mEXAMPLES[0m[m
[7m Manual page date(1) line 92/192 73% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[K       Convert [7msecond[27ms since the epoch (1970-01-01 UTC) to a date[m
[m
              $ date --date='@2147483647'[m
[m
       Show the time on the west coast of the US (use tzselect(1) to find TZ)[m
[m
              $ TZ='America/Los_Angeles' date[m
[m
       Show the local time for 9AM next Friday on the west coast of the US[m
[m

      DST active: n/a
]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 15:16:47]# man not applicable)[K[K[K[K[K[K[K[K[K[K[K[K[K[K[Ktimedatectl
[?1049h[?1h=TIMEDATECTL(1)                    timedatectl                   TIMEDATECTL(1)[m
[m
[1mNAME[0m[m
       timedatectl - Control the system time and date[m
[m
[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
       [1mtimedatectl[0m [1m[OPTIONS...][0m [1m{COMMAND}[0m[m
[m
[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
       [1mtimedatectl[0m may be used to query and change the system clock and its[m
       settings.[m
[m
       Use [1msystemd-firstboot[0m(1) to initialize the system time zone for mounted[m
       (but not booted) system images.[m
[m
[1mOPTIONS[0m[m

[1mNAME[0m[m
       timedatectl - Control the system time and date[m
[m
[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
       [1mtimedatectl[0m [1m[OPTIONS...][0m [1m{COMMAND}[0m[m
[m
[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
       [1mtimedatectl[0m may be used to query and change the system clock and its[m
       settings.[m
[m
       Use [1msystemd-firstboot[0m(1) to initialize the system time zone for mounted[m
       (but not booted) system images.[m

[m

           Do not query the user for authentication for privileged operations.[m
[m
       [1m--adjust-system-clock[0m[m
           If [1mset-local-rtc[0m is invoked and this option is passed, the system[m
           clock is synchronized from the RTC again, taking the new setting[m
           into account. Otherwise, the RTC is synchronized from the system[m
           clock.[m

       [1mtimedatectl[0m [1m[OPTIONS...][0m [1m{COMMAND}[0m[m

[m
[1mOPTIONS[0m[m
       The following options are understood:[m
[m
       [1m--no-ask-password[0m[m
           Do not query the user for authentication for privileged operations.[m
[m
       [1m--adjust-system-clock[0m[m
           If [1mset-local-rtc[0m is invoked and this option is passed, the system[m
           clock is synchronized from the RTC again, taking the new setting[m
           into account. Otherwise, the RTC is synchronized from the system[m
           clock.[m
[m
       [1m-H[0m, [1m--host=[0m[m
           Execute the operation remotely. Specify a hostname, or a username[m
           and hostname separated by "@", to connect to. The hostname may[m
           optionally be suffixed by a container name, separated by ":", which[m
           connects directly to a specific container on the specified host.[m
           This will use SSH to talk to the remote machine manager instance.[m

       [1m--no-ask-password[0m[m

           optionally be suffixed by a container name, separated by ":", which[m
           connects directly to a specific container on the specified host.[m
           This will use SSH to talk to the remote machine manager instance.[m
           Container names may be enumerated with [1mmachinectl[0m [1m-H[0m [4mHOST[24m.[m

[1mNAME[0m[m
       timedatectl - Control the system time and date[m
[m
[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
       [1mtimedatectl[0m [1m[OPTIONS...][0m [1m{COMMAND}[0m[m
[m
[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
       [1mtimedatectl[0m may be used to query and change the system clock and its settings.[m
[m
       Use [1msystemd-firstboot[0m(1) to initialize the system time zone for mounted (but not booted) system images.[m
[m
[1mOPTIONS[0m[m
       The following options are understood:[m
[m
       [1m--no-ask-password[0m[m
           Do not query the user for authentication for privileged operations.[m
[m
       [1m--adjust-system-clock[0m[m
           If [1mset-local-rtc[0m is invoked and this option is passed, the system clock is synchronized from the RTC again,[m
           taking the new setting into account. Otherwise, the RTC is synchronized from the system clock.[m
[m
       [1m-H[0m, [1m--host=[0m[m
           Execute the operation remotely. Specify a hostname, or a username and hostname separated by "@", to connect[m
           to. The hostname may optionally be suffixed by a container name, separated by ":", which connects directly[m
           to a specific container on the specified host. This will use SSH to talk to the remote machine manager[m
           instance. Container names may be enumerated with [1mmachinectl[0m [1m-H[0m [4mHOST[24m.[m
[m
       [1m-M[0m, [1m--machine=[0m[m
           Execute operation on a local container. Specify a container name to connect to.[m
[m
       [1m-h[0m, [1m--help[0m[m
[7m Manual page timedatectl(1) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[Ktt[Kii[Kmm[Kee[Kzz[Koo[Knn[Kee[K[1;1HTIMEDATECTL(1)                                        timedatectl                                       TIMEDATECTL(1)[m

[3;1H[1mNAME[0m[m
[4;1H       timedatectl - Control the system time and date[m
[5;1H[m

[7;1H       [1mtimedatectl[0m [1m[OPTIONS...][0m [1m{COMMAND}[0m[m
[8;1H[m
[9;1H[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
[10;1H       [1mtimedatectl[0m may be used to query and change the system clock and its settings.[m
[11;1H[m
[12;1H       Use [1msystemd-firstboot[0m(1) to initialize the system time zone for mounted (but not booted) system images.[m
[13;1H[m
[14;1H[1mOPTIONS[0m[m
[15;1H       The following options are understood:[m
[16;1H[m
[17;1H       [1m--no-ask-password[0m[m
[18;1H           Do not query the user for authentication for privileged operations.[m
[19;1H[m
[20;1H       [1m--adjust-system-clock[0m[m
[21;1H           If [1mset-local-rtc[0m is invoked and this option is passed, the system clock is synchronized from the RTC again,[m
[22;1H           taking the new setting into account. Otherwise, the RTC is synchronized from the system clock.[m
[23;1H[m
[24;1H       [1m-H[0m, [1m--host=[0m[m
[25;1H           Execute the operation remotely. Specify a hostname, or a username and hostname separated by "@", to connect[m
[26;1H           to. The hostname may optionally be suffixed by a container name, separated by ":", which connects directly[m
[27;1H           to a specific container on the specified host. This will use SSH to talk to the remote machine manager[m
[28;1H           instance. Container names may be enumerated with [1mmachinectl[0m [1m-H[0m [4mHOST[24m.[m
[29;1H[m
[30;1H       [1m-M[0m, [1m--machine=[0m[m
[31;1H           Execute operation on a local container. Specify a container name to connect to.[m
[32;1H[m
[33;1H       [1m-h[0m, [1m--help[0m[m
[34;1H[1;1HTIMEDATECTL(1)                                        timedatectl                                       TIMEDATECTL(1)[m
[2;1H[m
[3;1H[1mNAME[0m[m
[4;1H       timedatectl - Control the system time and date[m
[5;1H[m
[6;1H[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
[7;1H       [1mtimedatectl[0m [1m[OPTIONS...][0m [1m{COMMAND}[0m[m
[8;1H[m
[9;1H[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
[10;1H       [1mtimedatectl[0m may be used to query and change the system clock and its settings.[m
[11;1H[m
[12;1H       Use [1msystemd-firstboot[0m(1) to initialize the system time zone for mounted (but not booted) system images.[m
[13;1H[m
[14;1H[1mOPTIONS[0m[m
[15;1H       The following options are understood:[m
[16;1H[m
[17;1H       [1m--no-ask-password[0m[m
[18;1H           Do not query the user for authentication for privileged operations.[m
[19;1H[m
[20;1H       [1m--adjust-system-clock[0m[m
[21;1H           If [1mset-local-rtc[0m is invoked and this option is passed, the system clock is synchronized from the RTC again,[m
[22;1H           taking the new setting into account. Otherwise, the RTC is synchronized from the system clock.[m
[23;1H[m
[24;1H       [1m-H[0m, [1m--host=[0m[m
[25;1H           Execute the operation remotely. Specify a hostname, or a username and hostname separated by "@", to connect[m
[26;1H           to. The hostname may optionally be suffixed by a container name, separated by ":", which connects directly[m
[27;1H           to a specific container on the specified host. This will use SSH to talk to the remote machine manager[m
[28;1H           instance. Container names may be enumerated with [1mmachinectl[0m [1m-H[0m [4mHOST[24m.[m
[29;1H[m
[30;1H       [1m-M[0m, [1m--machine=[0m[m
[31;1H           Execute operation on a local container. Specify a container name to connect to.[m
[32;1H[m
[33;1H       [1m-h[0m, [1m--help[0m[m
[34;1H...skipping...
       [1mset-[0m[1m[7mtimezone[27m[0m [1m[[0m[1m[7mTIMEZONE[27m[0m[1m][0m[m
           Set the system time zone to the specified value. Available [7mtimezone[27ms can be listed with [1mlist-[0m[1m[7mtimezone[27m[0m[1ms[0m. If[m
           the RTC is configured to be in the local time, this will also update the RTC time. This call will alter the[m
           /etc/localtime symlink. See [1mlocaltime[0m(5) for more information.[m
[m
       [1mlist-[0m[1m[7mtimezone[27m[0m[1ms[0m[m
           List available time zones, one per line. Entries from the list can be set as the system [7mtimezone[27m with[m
           [1mset-[0m[1m[7mtimezone[27m[0m.[m
[m
       [1mset-local-rtc[0m [1m[BOOL][0m[m
           Takes a boolean argument. If "0", the system is configured to maintain the RTC in universal time. If "1",[m
           it will maintain the RTC in local time instead. Note that maintaining the RTC in the local [7mtimezone[27m is not[m
           fully supported and will create various problems with time zone changes and daylight saving adjustments. If[m
           at all possible, keep the RTC in UTC mode. Note that invoking this will also synchronize the RTC from the[m
           system clock, unless [1m--adjust-system-clock[0m is passed (see above). This command will change the 3rd line of[m
           /etc/adjtime, as documented in [1mhwclock[0m(8).[m
[m
       [1mset-ntp[0m [1m[BOOL][0m[m
           Takes a boolean argument. Controls whether NTP based network time synchronization is enabled (if[m
           available).[m
[m
[1mEXIT[0m [1mSTATUS[0m[m
       On success, 0 is returned, a non-zero failure code otherwise.[m
[m
[1mENVIRONMENT[0m[m
       [4m$SYSTEMD_PAGER[24m[m
           Pager to use when [1m--no-pager[0m is not given; overrides [4m$PAGER[24m. Setting this to an empty string or the value[m
           "cat" is equivalent to passing [1m--no-pager[0m.[m
[m
       [4m$SYSTEMD_LESS[24m[m
           Override the default options passed to [1mless[0m ("FRSXMK").[m
[m
[1mEXAMPLES[0m[m

[1mNAME[0m[m
       timedatectl - Control the system time and date[m
[m

[m
       Use [1msystemd-firstboot[0m(1) to initialize the system time zone for mounted (but not booted) system images.[m
[m

       [1m--no-ask-password[0m[m

           If [1mset-local-rtc[0m is invoked and this option is passed, the system clock is synchronized from the RTC again,[m
           taking the new setting into account. Otherwise, the RTC is synchronized from the system clock.[m
[m

           to a specific container on the specified host. This will use SSH to talk to the remote machine manager[m
           instance. Container names may be enumerated with [1mmachinectl[0m [1m-H[0m [4mHOST[24m.[m

[?1049h[?1h=TIMEDATECTL(1)                                        timedatectl                                       TIMEDATECTL(1)[m
[m
[1mNAME[0m[m
       timedatectl - Control the system time and date[m
[m
[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
       [1mtimedatectl[0m [1m[OPTIONS...][0m [1m{COMMAND}[0m[m
[m
[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
       [1mtimedatectl[0m may be used to query and change the system clock and its settings.[m
[m
       Use [1msystemd-firstboot[0m(1) to initialize the system time zone for mounted (but not booted) system images.[m
[m
[1mOPTIONS[0m[m
       The following options are understood:[m
[m
       [1m--no-ask-password[0m[m
           Do not query the user for authentication for privileged operations.[m
[m
       [1m--adjust-system-clock[0m[m
           If [1mset-local-rtc[0m is invoked and this option is passed, the system clock is synchronized from the RTC again,[m
           taking the new setting into account. Otherwise, the RTC is synchronized from the system clock.[m
[m
       [1m-H[0m, [1m--host=[0m[m
           Execute the operation remotely. Specify a hostname, or a username and hostname separated by "@", to connect[m
           to. The hostname may optionally be suffixed by a container name, separated by ":", which connects directly[m
           to a specific container on the specified host. This will use SSH to talk to the remote machine manager[m
           instance. Container names may be enumerated with [1mmachinectl[0m [1m-H[0m [4mHOST[24m.[m
[m
       [1m-M[0m, [1m--machine=[0m[m
           Execute operation on a local container. Specify a container name to connect to.[m
[m
       [1m-h[0m, [1m--help[0m[m
[7m Manual page timedatectl(1) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[Kss[Kee[Ktt[K[1;1HTIMEDATECTL(1)                                        timedatectl                                       TIMEDATECTL(1)[m
[2;1H[m
[3;1H[1mNAME[0m[m
[4;1H       timedatectl - Control the system time and date[m
[5;1H[m
[6;1H[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m

[8;1H[m

[15;1H       The following options are understood:[m

[17;1H       [1m--no-ask-password[0m[m
[18;1H           Do not query the user for authentication for privileged operations.[m

[21;1H           If [1mset-local-rtc[0m is invoked and this option is passed, the system clock is synchronized from the RTC again,[m
[22;1H           taking the new setting into account. Otherwise, the RTC is synchronized from the system clock.[m
[23;1H[m
[24;1H       [1m-H[0m, [1m--host=[0m[m
[25;1H           Execute the operation remotely. Specify a hostname, or a username and hostname separated by "@", to connect[m

[34;1H[1;1HTIMEDATECTL(1)                                        timedatectl                                       TIMEDATECTL(1)[m
[2;1H[m
[3;1H[1mNAME[0m[m
[4;1H       timedatectl - Control the system time and date[m
[5;1H[m
[6;1H[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
[7;1H       [1mtimedatectl[0m [1m[OPTIONS...][0m [1m{COMMAND}[0m[m
[8;1H[m
[9;1H[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
[10;1H       [1mtimedatectl[0m may be used to query and change the system clock and its [7mset[27mtings.[m
[11;1H[m
[12;1H       Use [1msystemd-firstboot[0m(1) to initialize the system time zone for mounted (but not booted) system images.[m
[13;1H[m
[14;1H[1mOPTIONS[0m[m
[15;1H       The following options are understood:[m
[16;1H[m
[17;1H       [1m--no-ask-password[0m[m
[18;1H           Do not query the user for authentication for privileged operations.[m
[19;1H[m
[20;1H       [1m--adjust-system-clock[0m[m
[21;1H           If [1m[7mset[27m[0m[1m-local-rtc[0m is invoked and this option is passed, the system clock is synchronized from the RTC again,[m
[22;1H           taking the new [7mset[27mting into account. Otherwise, the RTC is synchronized from the system clock.[m
[23;1H[m
[24;1H       [1m-H[0m, [1m--host=[0m[m
[25;1H           Execute the operation remotely. Specify a hostname, or a username and hostname separated by "@", to connect[m
[26;1H           to. The hostname may optionally be suffixed by a container name, separated by ":", which connects directly[m
[27;1H           to a specific container on the specified host. This will use SSH to talk to the remote machine manager[m
[28;1H           instance. Container names may be enumerated with [1mmachinectl[0m [1m-H[0m [4mHOST[24m.[m

[32;1H[m
[33;1H       [1m-h[0m, [1m--help[0m[m
[34;1H           Print a short help text and exit.[m
[m
       [1m--version[0m[m
           Print a short version string and exit.[m
[m
       [1m--no-pager[0m[m
           Do not pipe output into a pager.[m
[m
       The following commands are understood:[m
[7m Manual page timedatectl(1) line 12/127 32% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[m

[34;1H[1;1H[m
[2;1H       Use [1msystemd-firstboot[0m(1) to initialize the system time zone for mounted (but not booted) system images.[m
[3;1H[m
[4;1H[1mOPTIONS[0m[m
[5;1H       The following options are understood:[m

[26;1H       [1m--version[0m[m
[27;1H           Print a short version string and exit.[m
[28;1H[m
[29;1H       [1m--no-pager[0m[m
[30;1H           Do not pipe output into a pager.[m
[31;1H[m
[32;1H       The following commands are understood:[m
[33;1H[m
[34;1H...skipping...
       [1mset-[0m[1m[7mtimezone[27m[0m [1m[[0m[1m[7mTIMEZONE[27m[0m[1m][0m[m
           Set the system time zone to the specified value. Available [7mtimezone[27ms can be listed with [1mlist-[0m[1m[7mtimezone[27m[0m[1ms[0m. If[m
           the RTC is configured to be in the local time, this will also update the RTC time. This call will alter the[m
           /etc/localtime symlink. See [1mlocaltime[0m(5) for more information.[m
[m
       [1mlist-[0m[1m[7mtimezone[27m[0m[1ms[0m[m
           List available time zones, one per line. Entries from the list can be set as the system [7mtimezone[27m with[m
           [1mset-[0m[1m[7mtimezone[27m[0m.[m
[m
       [1mset-local-rtc[0m [1m[BOOL][0m[m
           Takes a boolean argument. If "0", the system is configured to maintain the RTC in universal time. If "1",[m
           it will maintain the RTC in local time instead. Note that maintaining the RTC in the local [7mtimezone[27m is not[m
           fully supported and will create various problems with time zone changes and daylight saving adjustments. If[m
           at all possible, keep the RTC in UTC mode. Note that invoking this will also synchronize the RTC from the[m
           system clock, unless [1m--adjust-system-clock[0m is passed (see above). This command will change the 3rd line of[m
           /etc/adjtime, as documented in [1mhwclock[0m(8).[m
[m
       [1mset-ntp[0m [1m[BOOL][0m[m
           Takes a boolean argument. Controls whether NTP based network time synchronization is enabled (if[m
           available).[m
[m
[1mEXIT[0m [1mSTATUS[0m[m
       On success, 0 is returned, a non-zero failure code otherwise.[m
[m
[1mENVIRONMENT[0m[m
       [4m$SYSTEMD_PAGER[24m[m
           Pager to use when [1m--no-pager[0m is not given; overrides [4m$PAGER[24m. Setting this to an empty string or the value[m
           "cat" is equivalent to passing [1m--no-pager[0m.[m
[m
       [4m$SYSTEMD_LESS[24m[m
           Override the default options passed to [1mless[0m ("FRSXMK").[m

[?1049h[?1h=yum(8)                                                                                                          yum(8)[m
[m
[1mNAME[0m[m
       yum - Yellowdog Updater Modified[m
[m
[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
       [1myum[0m [options] [command] [package ...][m
[m
[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
       [1myum[0m  is  an  interactive,  rpm  based,  package manager. It can automatically perform system updates, including[m
       dependency analysis and obsolete processing based on "repository" metadata. It can also perform installation of[m
       new packages, removal of old packages and perform queries on the installed and/or available packages among many[m
       other commands/services (see below). [1myum[0m is similar to other high  level  package  managers  like  apt-get  and[m
       smart.[m
[m
       While there are some graphical interfaces directly to the [1myum[0m code, more recent graphical interface development[m
       is happening with PackageKit and the gnome-packagekit application.[m
[m
       [4mcommand[24m is one of:[m
        * install package1 [package2] [...][m
        * update [package1] [package2] [...][m
        * update-to [package1] [package2] [...][m
        * update-minimal [package1] [package2] [...][m
        * check-update[m
        * upgrade [package1] [package2] [...][m
        * upgrade-to [package1] [package2] [...][m
        * distribution-synchronization [package1] [package2] [...][m
        * remove | erase package1 [package2] [...][m
        * autoremove [package1] [...][m
        * list [...][m
        * info [...][m
        * provides | whatprovides feature1 [feature2] [...][m
        * clean [ packages | metadata | expire-cache | rpmdb | plugins | all ][m
[7m Manual page yum(8) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[Kss[Kee[Krr[Kaa[Kcc[Khh[K[K[K[K[Kaa[Krr[Kcc[Khh[K[1;1Hyum(8)                                                                                                          yum(8)[m

[14;1H       smart.[m

[3;1H[1mNAME[0m[m
[4;1H       yum - Yellowdog Updater Modified[m
[5;1H[m
[6;1H[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
[7;1H       [1myum[0m [options] [command] [package ...][m
[8;1H[m
[9;1H[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
[10;1H       [1myum[0m  is  an  interactive,  rpm  based,  package manager. It can automatically perform system updates, including[m
[11;1H       dependency analysis and obsolete processing based on "repository" metadata. It can also perform installation of[m
[12;1H       new packages, removal of old packages and perform queries on the installed and/or available packages among many[m
[13;1H       other commands/services (see below). [1myum[0m is similar to other high  level  package  managers  like  apt-get  and[m
[14;1H       smart.[m
[15;1H[m
[16;1H       While there are some graphical interfaces directly to the [1myum[0m code, more recent graphical interface development[m
[17;1H       is happening with PackageKit and the gnome-packagekit application.[m
[18;1H[m
[19;1H       [4mcommand[24m is one of:[m
[20;1H        * install package1 [package2] [...][m
[21;1H        * update [package1] [package2] [...][m
[22;1H        * update-to [package1] [package2] [...][m
[23;1H        * update-minimal [package1] [package2] [...][m
[24;1H        * check-update[m
[25;1H        * upgrade [package1] [package2] [...][m
[26;1H        * upgrade-to [package1] [package2] [...][m
[27;1H        * distribution-synchronization [package1] [package2] [...][m
[28;1H        * remove | erase package1 [package2] [...][m
[29;1H        * autoremove [package1] [...][m
[30;1H        * list [...][m
[31;1H        * info [...][m
[32;1H        * provides | whatprovides feature1 [feature2] [...][m
[33;1H        * clean [ packages | metadata | expire-cache | rpmdb | plugins | all ][m
[34;1H...skipping...
        * [7msearch[27m string1 [string2] [...][m
        * shell [filename][m
        * resolvedep dep1 [dep2] [...][m
           (maintained for legacy reasons only - use repoquery or yum provides)[m
        * localinstall rpmfile1 [rpmfile2] [...][m
           (maintained for legacy reasons only - use install)[m
        * localupdate rpmfile1 [rpmfile2] [...][m
           (maintained for legacy reasons only - use update)[m
        * reinstall package1 [package2] [...][m
        * downgrade package1 [package2] [...][m
        * deplist package1 [package2] [...][m
        * repolist [all|enabled|disabled][m
        * repoinfo [all|enabled|disabled][m
        * repository-packages <enabled-repoid> <install|remove|remove-or-reinstall|remove-or-distribution-synchroniza‚Äê[m
       tion> [package2] [...][m
        * version [ all | installed | available | group-* | nogroups* | grouplist | groupinfo ][m
        * history [info|list|packages-list|packages-info|summary|addon-info|redo|undo|rollback|new|sync|stats][m
        * load-transaction [txfile][m
        * updateinfo [summary | list | info | remove-pkgs-ts | exclude-updates | exclude-all | check-running-kernel][m
        * fssnapshot [summary | list | have-space | create | delete][m
        * fs [filters | refilter | refilter-cleanup | du][m
        * check[m
        * help [command][m
[m
       Unless the --help or -h option is given, one of the above commands must be present.[m
[m
       Repository configuration is honored in all operations.[m
[m
       [1minstall[0m[m
              Is  used  to install the latest version of a package or group of packages while ensuring that all depen‚Äê[m
              dencies are satisfied.  (See [1mSpecifying[0m [1mpackage[0m [1mnames[0m for more information) If no  package  matches  the[m
              given  package  name(s),  they are assumed to be a shell glob and any matches are then installed. If the[m
              name starts with @^ then it is treated as an environment group (group install @^foo), an @ character and[m

]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 16:28:32]# less /etc/ntp.conf 
[?1049h[?1h=# For more information about this file, see the man pages
# ntp.conf(5), ntp_acc(5), ntp_auth(5), ntp_clock(5), ntp_misc(5), ntp_mon(5).

driftfile /var/lib/ntp/drift

# Permit time synchronization with our time source, but do not
# permit the source to query or modify the service on this system.
restrict default nomodify notrap nopeer noquery

# Permit all access over the loopback interface.  This could
# be tightened as well, but to do so would effect some of
# the administrative functions.
restrict 127.0.0.1 
restrict ::1

# Hosts on local network are less restricted.
#restrict 192.168.1.0 mask 255.255.255.0 nomodify notrap

# Use public servers from the pool.ntp.org project.
# Please consider joining the pool (http://www.pool.ntp.org/join.html).
server 0.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
server 1.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
server 2.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
server 3.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst

#broadcast 192.168.1.255 autokey        # broadcast server
#broadcastclient                        # broadcast client
#broadcast 224.0.1.1 autokey            # multicast server
#multicastclient 224.0.1.1              # multicast client
#manycastserver 239.255.254.254         # manycast server
#manycastclient 239.255.254.254 autokey # manycast client

# Enable public key cryptography.

includefile /etc/ntp/crypto/pw

[34m# Key file containing the keys and key identifiers used when operating
# with symmetric key cryptography. [m
keys /etc/ntp/keys

[34m# Specify the key identifiers which are trusted.
#trustedkey 4 8 42

# Specify the key identifier to use with the ntpdc utility.
#requestkey 8

# Specify the key identifier to use with the ntpq utility.
#controlkey 8

# Enable writing of statistics records.
#statistics clockstats cryptostats loopstats peerstats

# Disable the monitoring facility to prevent amplification attacks using ntpdc
# monlist command when default restrict does not include the noquery flag. See
# CVE-2013-5211 for more details.
# Note: Monitoring will not be disabled with the limited restriction flag.[m
disable monitor

[?1049h[?1h=# For more information about this file, see the man pages
# ntp.conf(5), ntp_acc(5), ntp_auth(5), ntp_clock(5), ntp_misc(5), ntp_mon(5).

driftfile /var/lib/ntp/drift

# Permit time synchronization with our time source, but do not
# permit the source to query or modify the service on this system.
restrict default nomodify notrap nopeer noquery

# Permit all access over the loopback interface.  This could
# be tightened as well, but to do so would effect some of
# the administrative functions.
restrict 127.0.0.1 
restrict ::1

# Hosts on local network are less restricted.
#restrict 192.168.1.0 mask 255.255.255.0 nomodify notrap

# Use public servers from the pool.ntp.org project.
# Please consider joining the pool (http://www.pool.ntp.org/join.html).
server 0.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
server 1.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
server 2.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
server 3.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst

#broadcast 192.168.1.255 autokey        # broadcast server
#broadcastclient                        # broadcast client
#broadcast 224.0.1.1 autokey            # multicast server
#multicastclient 224.0.1.1              # multicast client
#manycastserver 239.255.254.254         # manycast server
#manycastclient 239.255.254.254 autokey # manycast client

# Enable public key cryptography.
#crypto

includefile /etc/ntp/crypto/pw

# Key file containing the keys and key identifiers used when operating
# with symmetric key cryptography. 
keys /etc/ntp/keys

# Specify the key identifiers which are trusted.
#trustedkey 4 8 42

# Specify the key identifier to use with the ntpdc utility.
#requestkey 8

# Specify the key identifier to use with the ntpq utility.
#controlkey 8

# Enable writing of statistics records.
#statistics clockstats cryptostats loopstats peerstats

# Disable the monitoring facility to prevent amplification attacks using ntpdc
# monlist command when default restrict does not include the noquery flag. See
# CVE-2013-5211 for more details.
# Note: Monitoring will not be disabled with the limited restriction flag.
disable monitor
[7m/etc/ntp.conf (END)[27m[K[K[?1l>[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 16:29:30]# man yum
[?1049h[?1h=yum(8)                                                                                                                                                                                                                             yum(8)[m
[m
[1mNAME[0m[m
       yum - Yellowdog Updater Modified[m
[m
[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
       [1myum[0m [options] [command] [package ...][m
[m
[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
       [1myum[0m  is  an  interactive,  rpm  based, package manager. It can automatically perform system updates, including dependency analysis and obsolete processing based on "repository" metadata. It can also perform installation of new[m
       packages, removal of old packages and perform queries on the installed and/or available packages among many other commands/services (see below). [1myum[0m is similar to other high level package managers like apt-get and smart.[m
[m
       While there are some graphical interfaces directly to the [1myum[0m code, more recent graphical interface development is happening with PackageKit and the gnome-packagekit application.[m
[m
       [4mcommand[24m is one of:[m
        * install package1 [package2] [...][m
        * update [package1] [package2] [...][m
        * update-to [package1] [package2] [...][m
        * update-minimal [package1] [package2] [...][m
        * check-update[m
        * upgrade [package1] [package2] [...][m
        * upgrade-to [package1] [package2] [...][m
        * distribution-synchronization [package1] [package2] [...][m
        * remove | erase package1 [package2] [...][m
        * autoremove [package1] [...][m
        * list [...][m
        * info [...][m
        * provides | whatprovides feature1 [feature2] [...][m
        * clean [ packages | metadata | expire-cache | rpmdb | plugins | all ][m
        * makecache [fast][m
        * groups [...][m
        * search string1 [string2] [...][m
        * shell [filename][m
        * resolvedep dep1 [dep2] [...][m
           (maintained for legacy reasons only - use repoquery or yum provides)[m
        * localinstall rpmfile1 [rpmfile2] [...][m
           (maintained for legacy reasons only - use install)[m
        * localupdate rpmfile1 [rpmfile2] [...][m
           (maintained for legacy reasons only - use update)[m
        * reinstall package1 [package2] [...][m
        * downgrade package1 [package2] [...][m
        * deplist package1 [package2] [...][m
        * repolist [all|enabled|disabled][m
        * repoinfo [all|enabled|disabled][m
        * repository-packages <enabled-repoid> <install|remove|remove-or-reinstall|remove-or-distribution-synchronization> [package2] [...][m
        * version [ all | installed | available | group-* | nogroups* | grouplist | groupinfo ][m
        * history [info|list|packages-list|packages-info|summary|addon-info|redo|undo|rollback|new|sync|stats][m
        * load-transaction [txfile][m
        * updateinfo [summary | list | info | remove-pkgs-ts | exclude-updates | exclude-all | check-running-kernel][m
        * fssnapshot [summary | list | have-space | create | delete][m
        * fs [filters | refilter | refilter-cleanup | du][m
        * check[m
        * help [command][m
[m
       Unless the --help or -h option is given, one of the above commands must be present.[m
[m
       Repository configuration is honored in all operations.[m
[m
       [1minstall[0m[m
              Is used to install the latest version of a package or group of packages while ensuring that all dependencies are satisfied.  (See [1mSpecifying[0m [1mpackage[0m [1mnames[0m for more information) If no package matches  the  given  package[m
              name(s),  they  are  assumed to be a shell glob and any matches are then installed. If the name starts with @^ then it is treated as an environment group (group install @^foo), an @ character and it's treated as a group[m
              (plain group install).[m
[m
              If the name starts with a "-" character, then a search is done within the transaction and any matches are removed. Note that Yum options use the same syntax and it may be necessary to use "--" to  resolve  any  possible[m
              conflicts.[m
[7m Manual page yum(8) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[Kll[Kii[Kss[Ktt[K[1;1Hyum(8)                                                                                                                                                                                                                             yum(8)[m
[2;1H[m
[3;1H[1mNAME[0m[m
[4;1H       yum - Yellowdog Updater Modified[m
[5;1H[m
[6;1H[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
[7;1H       [1myum[0m [options] [command] [package ...][m
[8;1H[m
[9;1H[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
[10;1H       [1myum[0m  is  an  interactive,  rpm  based, package manager. It can automatically perform system updates, including dependency analysis and obsolete processing based on "repository" metadata. It can also perform installation of new[m
[11;1H       packages, removal of old packages and perform queries on the installed and/or available packages among many other commands/services (see below). [1myum[0m is similar to other high level package managers like apt-get and smart.[m
[12;1H[m
[13;1H       While there are some graphical interfaces directly to the [1myum[0m code, more recent graphical interface development is happening with PackageKit and the gnome-packagekit application.[m
[14;1H[m
[15;1H       [4mcommand[24m is one of:[m
[16;1H        * install package1 [package2] [...][m
[17;1H        * update [package1] [package2] [...][m
[18;1H        * update-to [package1] [package2] [...][m
[19;1H        * update-minimal [package1] [package2] [...][m
[20;1H        * check-update[m
[21;1H        * upgrade [package1] [package2] [...][m
[22;1H        * upgrade-to [package1] [package2] [...][m
[23;1H        * distribution-synchronization [package1] [package2] [...][m
[24;1H        * remove | erase package1 [package2] [...][m
[25;1H        * autoremove [package1] [...][m
[26;1H        * list [...][m
[27;1H        * info [...][m
[28;1H        * provides | whatprovides feature1 [feature2] [...][m
[29;1H        * clean [ packages | metadata | expire-cache | rpmdb | plugins | all ][m
[30;1H        * makecache [fast][m
[31;1H        * groups [...][m
[32;1H        * search string1 [string2] [...][m
[33;1H        * shell [filename][m
[34;1H        * resolvedep dep1 [dep2] [...][m
[35;1H           (maintained for legacy reasons only - use repoquery or yum provides)[m
[36;1H        * localinstall rpmfile1 [rpmfile2] [...][m
[37;1H           (maintained for legacy reasons only - use install)[m
[38;1H        * localupdate rpmfile1 [rpmfile2] [...][m
[39;1H           (maintained for legacy reasons only - use update)[m
[40;1H        * reinstall package1 [package2] [...][m
[41;1H        * downgrade package1 [package2] [...][m
[42;1H        * deplist package1 [package2] [...][m
[43;1H        * repolist [all|enabled|disabled][m
[44;1H        * repoinfo [all|enabled|disabled][m
[45;1H        * repository-packages <enabled-repoid> <install|remove|remove-or-reinstall|remove-or-distribution-synchronization> [package2] [...][m
[46;1H        * version [ all | installed | available | group-* | nogroups* | grouplist | groupinfo ][m
[47;1H        * history [info|list|packages-list|packages-info|summary|addon-info|redo|undo|rollback|new|sync|stats][m
[48;1H        * load-transaction [txfile][m
[49;1H        * updateinfo [summary | list | info | remove-pkgs-ts | exclude-updates | exclude-all | check-running-kernel][m
[50;1H        * fssnapshot [summary | list | have-space | create | delete][m
[51;1H        * fs [filters | refilter | refilter-cleanup | du][m
[52;1H        * check[m
[53;1H        * help [command][m
[54;1H[m
[55;1H       Unless the --help or -h option is given, one of the above commands must be present.[m
[56;1H[m
[57;1H       Repository configuration is honored in all operations.[m
[58;1H[m
[59;1H       [1minstall[0m[m
[60;1H              Is used to install the latest version of a package or group of packages while ensuring that all dependencies are satisfied.  (See [1mSpecifying[0m [1mpackage[0m [1mnames[0m for more information) If no package matches  the  given  package[m
[61;1H              name(s),  they  are  assumed to be a shell glob and any matches are then installed. If the name starts with @^ then it is treated as an environment group (group install @^foo), an @ character and it's treated as a group[m
[62;1H              (plain group install).[m
[63;1H[m
[64;1H              If the name starts with a "-" character, then a search is done within the transaction and any matches are removed. Note that Yum options use the same syntax and it may be necessary to use "--" to  resolve  any  possible[m
[65;1H              conflicts.[m
[66;1H[1;1Hyum(8)                                                                                                                                                                                                                             yum(8)[m
[2;1H[m
[3;1H[1mNAME[0m[m
[4;1H       yum - Yellowdog Updater Modified[m
[5;1H[m
[6;1H[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
[7;1H       [1myum[0m [options] [command] [package ...][m
[8;1H[m
[9;1H[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
[10;1H       [1myum[0m  is  an  interactive,  rpm  based, package manager. It can automatically perform system updates, including dependency analysis and obsolete processing based on "repository" metadata. It can also perform installation of new[m
[11;1H       packages, removal of old packages and perform queries on the installed and/or available packages among many other commands/services (see below). [1myum[0m is similar to other high level package managers like apt-get and smart.[m
[12;1H[m
[13;1H       While there are some graphical interfaces directly to the [1myum[0m code, more recent graphical interface development is happening with PackageKit and the gnome-packagekit application.[m
[14;1H[m
[15;1H       [4mcommand[24m is one of:[m
[16;1H        * install package1 [package2] [...][m
[17;1H        * update [package1] [package2] [...][m
[18;1H        * update-to [package1] [package2] [...][m
[19;1H        * update-minimal [package1] [package2] [...][m
[20;1H        * check-update[m
[21;1H        * upgrade [package1] [package2] [...][m
[22;1H        * upgrade-to [package1] [package2] [...][m
[23;1H        * distribution-synchronization [package1] [package2] [...][m
[24;1H        * remove | erase package1 [package2] [...][m
[25;1H        * autoremove [package1] [...][m
[26;1H        * [7mlist[27m [...][m
[27;1H        * info [...][m
[28;1H        * provides | whatprovides feature1 [feature2] [...][m
[29;1H        * clean [ packages | metadata | expire-cache | rpmdb | plugins | all ][m
[30;1H        * makecache [fast][m
[31;1H        * groups [...][m
[32;1H        * search string1 [string2] [...][m
[33;1H        * shell [filename][m
[34;1H        * resolvedep dep1 [dep2] [...][m
[35;1H           (maintained for legacy reasons only - use repoquery or yum provides)[m
[36;1H        * localinstall rpmfile1 [rpmfile2] [...][m
[37;1H           (maintained for legacy reasons only - use install)[m
[38;1H        * localupdate rpmfile1 [rpmfile2] [...][m
[39;1H           (maintained for legacy reasons only - use update)[m
[40;1H        * reinstall package1 [package2] [...][m
[41;1H        * downgrade package1 [package2] [...][m
[42;1H        * dep[7mlist[27m package1 [package2] [...][m
[43;1H        * repo[7mlist[27m [all|enabled|disabled][m
[44;1H        * repoinfo [all|enabled|disabled][m
[45;1H        * repository-packages <enabled-repoid> <install|remove|remove-or-reinstall|remove-or-distribution-synchronization> [package2] [...][m
[46;1H        * version [ all | installed | available | group-* | nogroups* | group[7mlist[27m | groupinfo ][m
[47;1H        * history [info|[7mlist[27m|packages-[7mlist[27m|packages-info|summary|addon-info|redo|undo|rollback|new|sync|stats][m
[48;1H        * load-transaction [txfile][m
[49;1H        * updateinfo [summary | [7mlist[27m | info | remove-pkgs-ts | exclude-updates | exclude-all | check-running-kernel][m
[50;1H        * fssnapshot [summary | [7mlist[27m | have-space | create | delete][m
[51;1H        * fs [filters | refilter | refilter-cleanup | du][m
[52;1H        * check[m
[53;1H        * help [command][m
[54;1H[m
[55;1H       Unless the --help or -h option is given, one of the above commands must be present.[m
[56;1H[m
[57;1H       Repository configuration is honored in all operations.[m
[58;1H[m
[59;1H       [1minstall[0m[m
[60;1H              Is used to install the latest version of a package or group of packages while ensuring that all dependencies are satisfied.  (See [1mSpecifying[0m [1mpackage[0m [1mnames[0m for more information) If no package matches  the  given  package[m
[61;1H              name(s),  they  are  assumed to be a shell glob and any matches are then installed. If the name starts with @^ then it is treated as an environment group (group install @^foo), an @ character and it's treated as a group[m
[62;1H              (plain group install).[m
[63;1H[m
[64;1H              If the name starts with a "-" character, then a search is done within the transaction and any matches are removed. Note that Yum options use the same syntax and it may be necessary to use "--" to  resolve  any  possible[m
[65;1H              conflicts.[m
[66;1H[m
              If  the  name is a file, then install works like localinstall. If the name doesn't match a package, then package "provides" are searched (e.g. "_sqlitecache.so()(64bit)") as are file[7mlist[27ms (Eg. "/usr/bin/yum"). Also note[m
              that for file[7mlist[27ms, wildcards will match multiple packages.[m
[m
              Because install does a lot of work to make it as easy as possible to use, there are also a few specific install commands "[1minstall-n[0m", "[1minstall-na[0m" and "[1minstall-nevra[0m". These only  work  on  package  names,  and  do  not[m
              process wildcards etc.[m
[m
       [1mupdate[0m If  run  without  any packages, update will update every currently installed package.  If one or more packages or package globs are specified, Yum will only update the [7mlist[27med packages.  While updating packages, [1myum[0m will[m
              ensure that all dependencies are satisfied. (See [1mSpecifying[0m [1mpackage[0m [1mnames[0m for more information) If the packages or globs specified match to packages which are not currently installed then update will not  install  them.[m
              update operates on groups, files, provides and file[7mlist[27ms just like the "install" command.[m
[m
              If  the main obsoletes configure option is true (default) or the --obsoletes flag is present [1myum[0m will include package obsoletes in its calculations - this makes it better for distro-version changes, for example: upgrad‚Äê[m
              ing from somelinux 8.0 to somelinux 9.[m
[m
              Note that "[1mupdate[0m" works on installed packages first, and only if there are no matches does it look for available packages. The difference is most noticeable when you do  "[1mupdate[0m  foo-1-2"  which  will  act  exactly  as[m
              "[1mupdate[0m foo" if foo-1-2 is installed. You can use the "[1mupdate-to[0m" if you'd prefer that nothing happen in the above case.[m
[m
       [1mupdate-to[0m[m
              This command works like "[1mupdate[0m" but always specifies the version of the package we want to update to.[m
[m
       [1mupdate-minimal[0m[m
              This works like the update command, but if you have the package foo-1 installed and have foo-2 (bugfix) and foo-3 (enhancement) available with updateinfo.xml then update-minimal --bugfix will update you to foo-2.[m
[m
       [1mcheck-update[0m[m
              Implemented  so  you could know if your machine had any updates that needed to be applied without running it interactively. Returns exit value of 100 if there are packages available for an update. Also returns a [7mlist[27m of[m
[7m Manual page yum(8) line 28 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K              the packages to be updated in [7mlist[27m format. Returns 0 if no packages are available for update. Returns 1 if an error occurred.  Running in verbose mode also shows obsoletes.[m
[7m Manual page yum(8) line 29 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K[?1l>[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 16:29:39]# ty[K[Kyum list ntp.x86_64
Paquets install√©s
ntp.x86_64                                                                                                     4.2.6p5-28.el7.centos                                                                                                      @base
]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 16:29:44]# yum list ntp.x86_64^C
]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 16:29:46]# man yum

       yum - Yellowdog Updater Modified[m

       [1myum[0m [options] [command] [package ...][m
[m

       [1myum[0m  is  an  interactive,  rpm  based, package manager. It can automatically perform system updates, including dependency analysis and obsolete processing based on "repository" metadata. It can also perform installation of new[m

        * updateinfo [summary | list | info | remove-pkgs-ts | exclude-updates | exclude-all | check-running-kernel][m
        * fssnapshot [summary | list | have-space | create | delete][m
        * fs [filters | refilter | refilter-cleanup | du][m
        * check[m
        * help [command][m
[m
       Unless the --help or -h option is given, one of the above commands must be present.[m
[m
       Repository configuration is honored in all operations.[m
[m
       [1minstall[0m[m
              Is used to install the latest version of a package or group of packages while ensuring that all dependencies are satisfied.  (See [1mSpecifying[0m [1mpackage[0m [1mnames[0m for more information) If no package matches  the  given  package[m

[7m Manual page yum(8) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[Kii[Knn[Kff[Koo[K[1;1Hyum(8)                                                                                                                                                                                                                             yum(8)[m

[30;1H        * makecache [fast][m
