[34;1H        * resolvedep dep1 [dep2] [...][m
[35;1H           (maintained for legacy reasons only - use repoquery or yum provides)[m
[36;1H        * localinstall rpmfile1 [rpmfile2] [...][m
[37;1H           (maintained for legacy reasons only - use install)[m
[38;1H        * localupdate rpmfile1 [rpmfile2] [...][m
[39;1H           (maintained for legacy reasons only - use update)[m
[40;1H        * reinstall package1 [package2] [...][m
[41;1H        * downgrade package1 [package2] [...][m
[42;1H        * deplist package1 [package2] [...][m
[43;1H        * repolist [all|enabled|disabled][m
[44;1H        * repoinfo [all|enabled|disabled][m
[45;1H        * repository-packages <enabled-repoid> <install|remove|remove-or-reinstall|remove-or-distribution-synchronization> [package2] [...][m
[46;1H        * version [ all | installed | available | group-* | nogroups* | grouplist | groupinfo ][m
[47;1H        * history [info|list|packages-list|packages-info|summary|addon-info|redo|undo|rollback|new|sync|stats][m
[48;1H        * load-transaction [txfile][m
[49;1H        * updateinfo [summary | list | info | remove-pkgs-ts | exclude-updates | exclude-all | check-running-kernel][m
[50;1H        * fssnapshot [summary | list | have-space | create | delete][m
[51;1H        * fs [filters | refilter | refilter-cleanup | du][m
[52;1H        * check[m
[53;1H        * help [command][m
[54;1H[m
[55;1H       Unless the --help or -h option is given, one of the above commands must be present.[m
[56;1H[m
[57;1H       Repository configuration is honored in all operations.[m
[58;1H[m
[59;1H       [1minstall[0m[m
[60;1H              Is used to install the latest version of a package or group of packages while ensuring that all dependencies are satisfied.  (See [1mSpecifying[0m [1mpackage[0m [1mnames[0m for more information) If no package matches  the  given  package[m
[61;1H              name(s),  they  are  assumed to be a shell glob and any matches are then installed. If the name starts with @^ then it is treated as an environment group (group install @^foo), an @ character and it's treated as a group[m
[62;1H              (plain group install).[m
[63;1H[m
[64;1H              If the name starts with a "-" character, then a search is done within the transaction and any matches are removed. Note that Yum options use the same syntax and it may be necessary to use "--" to  resolve  any  possible[m
[65;1H              conflicts.[m
[66;1H[1;1Hyum(8)                                                                                                                                                                                                                             yum(8)[m
[2;1H[m
[3;1H[1mNAME[0m[m
[4;1H       yum - Yellowdog Updater Modified[m
[5;1H[m
[6;1H[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
[7;1H       [1myum[0m [options] [command] [package ...][m
[8;1H[m
[9;1H[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
[10;1H       [1myum[0m  is  an  interactive,  rpm  based, package manager. It can automatically perform system updates, including dependency analysis and obsolete processing based on "repository" metadata. It can also perform installation of new[m
[11;1H       packages, removal of old packages and perform queries on the installed and/or available packages among many other commands/services (see below). [1myum[0m is similar to other high level package managers like apt-get and smart.[m
[12;1H[m
[13;1H       While there are some graphical interfaces directly to the [1myum[0m code, more recent graphical interface development is happening with PackageKit and the gnome-packagekit application.[m
[14;1H[m
[15;1H       [4mcommand[24m is one of:[m
[16;1H        * install package1 [package2] [...][m
[17;1H        * update [package1] [package2] [...][m
[18;1H        * update-to [package1] [package2] [...][m
[19;1H        * update-minimal [package1] [package2] [...][m
[20;1H        * check-update[m
[21;1H        * upgrade [package1] [package2] [...][m
[22;1H        * upgrade-to [package1] [package2] [...][m
[23;1H        * distribution-synchronization [package1] [package2] [...][m
[24;1H        * remove | erase package1 [package2] [...][m
[25;1H        * autoremove [package1] [...][m
[26;1H        * list [...][m
[27;1H        * [7minfo[27m [...][m
[28;1H        * provides | whatprovides feature1 [feature2] [...][m
[29;1H        * clean [ packages | metadata | expire-cache | rpmdb | plugins | all ][m
[30;1H        * makecache [fast][m
[31;1H        * groups [...][m
[32;1H        * search string1 [string2] [...][m
[33;1H        * shell [filename][m
[34;1H        * resolvedep dep1 [dep2] [...][m
[35;1H           (maintained for legacy reasons only - use repoquery or yum provides)[m
[36;1H        * localinstall rpmfile1 [rpmfile2] [...][m
[37;1H           (maintained for legacy reasons only - use install)[m
[38;1H        * localupdate rpmfile1 [rpmfile2] [...][m
[39;1H           (maintained for legacy reasons only - use update)[m
[40;1H        * reinstall package1 [package2] [...][m
[41;1H        * downgrade package1 [package2] [...][m
[42;1H        * deplist package1 [package2] [...][m
[43;1H        * repolist [all|enabled|disabled][m
[44;1H        * repo[7minfo[27m [all|enabled|disabled][m
[45;1H        * repository-packages <enabled-repoid> <install|remove|remove-or-reinstall|remove-or-distribution-synchronization> [package2] [...][m
[46;1H        * version [ all | installed | available | group-* | nogroups* | grouplist | group[7minfo[27m ][m
[47;1H        * history [[7minfo[27m|list|packages-list|packages-[7minfo[27m|summary|addon-[7minfo[27m|redo|undo|rollback|new|sync|stats][m
[48;1H        * load-transaction [txfile][m
[49;1H        * update[7minfo[27m [summary | list | [7minfo[27m | remove-pkgs-ts | exclude-updates | exclude-all | check-running-kernel][m
[50;1H        * fssnapshot [summary | list | have-space | create | delete][m
[51;1H        * fs [filters | refilter | refilter-cleanup | du][m
[52;1H        * check[m
[53;1H        * help [command][m
[54;1H[m
[55;1H       Unless the --help or -h option is given, one of the above commands must be present.[m
[56;1H[m
[57;1H       Repository configuration is honored in all operations.[m
[58;1H[m
[59;1H       [1minstall[0m[m
[60;1H              Is used to install the latest version of a package or group of packages while ensuring that all dependencies are satisfied.  (See [1mSpecifying[0m [1mpackage[0m [1mnames[0m for more [7minfo[27mrmation) If no package matches  the  given  package[m
[61;1H              name(s),  they  are  assumed to be a shell glob and any matches are then installed. If the name starts with @^ then it is treated as an environment group (group install @^foo), an @ character and it's treated as a group[m
[62;1H              (plain group install).[m
[63;1H[m
[64;1H              If the name starts with a "-" character, then a search is done within the transaction and any matches are removed. Note that Yum options use the same syntax and it may be necessary to use "--" to  resolve  any  possible[m
[65;1H              conflicts.[m
[66;1H[m
              If  the  name is a file, then install works like localinstall. If the name doesn't match a package, then package "provides" are searched (e.g. "_sqlitecache.so()(64bit)") as are filelists (Eg. "/usr/bin/yum"). Also note[m
              that for filelists, wildcards will match multiple packages.[m
[m
              Because install does a lot of work to make it as easy as possible to use, there are also a few specific install commands "[1minstall-n[0m", "[1minstall-na[0m" and "[1minstall-nevra[0m". These only  work  on  package  names,  and  do  not[m
              process wildcards etc.[m
[m
       [1mupdate[0m If  run  without  any packages, update will update every currently installed package.  If one or more packages or package globs are specified, Yum will only update the listed packages.  While updating packages, [1myum[0m will[m
              ensure that all dependencies are satisfied. (See [1mSpecifying[0m [1mpackage[0m [1mnames[0m for more [7minfo[27mrmation) If the packages or globs specified match to packages which are not currently installed then update will not  install  them.[m
              update operates on groups, files, provides and filelists just like the "install" command.[m
[m
              If  the main obsoletes configure option is true (default) or the --obsoletes flag is present [1myum[0m will include package obsoletes in its calculations - this makes it better for distro-version changes, for example: upgrad‚Äê[m
              ing from somelinux 8.0 to somelinux 9.[m
[m
              Note that "[1mupdate[0m" works on installed packages first, and only if there are no matches does it look for available packages. The difference is most noticeable when you do  "[1mupdate[0m  foo-1-2"  which  will  act  exactly  as[m
              "[1mupdate[0m foo" if foo-1-2 is installed. You can use the "[1mupdate-to[0m" if you'd prefer that nothing happen in the above case.[m
[m
       [1mupdate-to[0m[m
              This command works like "[1mupdate[0m" but always specifies the version of the package we want to update to.[m
[m
       [1mupdate-minimal[0m[m
              This works like the update command, but if you have the package foo-1 installed and have foo-2 (bugfix) and foo-3 (enhancement) available with update[7minfo[27m.xml then update-minimal --bugfix will update you to foo-2.[m
[m
       [1mcheck-update[0m[m
              Implemented  so  you could know if your machine had any updates that needed to be applied without running it interactively. Returns exit value of 100 if there are packages available for an update. Also returns a list of[m
              the packages to be updated in list format. Returns 0 if no packages are available for update. Returns 1 if an error occurred.  Running in verbose mode also shows obsoletes.[m
[7m Manual page yum(8) line 29 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K[?1l>[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 16:29:50]# t[Kyum ino[Kof[K[Kfo ntp.x86_64
Paquets install√©s
Nom                 : ntp
Architecture        : x86_64
Version             : 4.2.6p5
R√©vision            : 28.el7.centos
Taille              : 1.4 M
D√©p√¥t        ¬†      : installed
Depuis le d√©p√¥t     : base
R√©sum√©       ¬†      : The NTP daemon and utilities
URL                 : http://www.ntp.org
Licence      ¬†      : (MIT and BSD and BSD with advertising) and GPLv2
Description¬†        : The Network Time Protocol (NTP) is used to synchronize a computer's
                    : time with another reference time source. This package includes ntpd
                    : (a daemon which continuously adjusts system time) and utilities used
                    : to query and configure the ntpd daemon.
                    : 
                    : Perl scripts ntp-wait and ntptrace are in the ntp-perl package,
                    : ntpdate is in the ntpdate package and sntp is in the sntp package.
                    : The documentation is in the ntp-doc package.

   [1mOPTIONS[0m [1mD'INTERROGATION[0m[m

   [1mOPTIONS[0m [1mD'INSTALLATION[0m[m
       [1m[--allfiles][0m  [1m[--badreloc][0m  [1m[--excludepath[0m [4mANCIEN_CHEMIN[24m[1m][0m  [1m[--excludedocs][0m [1m[--force][0m [1m[-h,--hash][0m [1m[--ignoresize][0m [1m[--ignorearch][0m [1m[--ignoreos][0m [1m[--includedocs][0m [1m[--justdb][0m [1m[--nodeps][0m [1m[--noorder][0m [1m[--noscripts][0m [1m[--notriggers][0m [1m[--old‚Äê[0m[m

[m
[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
       [1mrpm[0m est un puissant [4mgestionnaire[24m [4mde[24m [4mpaquetages[24m, qui peut √™tre utilis√© pour construire, installer, interroger, v√©rifier, mettre √† jour, et d√©sinstaller des paquetages de logiciels individuels. Un [4mpaquetage[24m est  constitu√©  d'une[m
       archive de fichiers, et de m√©ta-donn√©es utilis√©es pour installer et supprimer les fichiers de l'archive. Les m√©ta-donn√©es incluent les scripts assistants, les attributs des fichiers, et des informations d√©crivant le paquetage.[m
       Il y a deux types de [1mpaquetages[0m : les paquetages binaires, utilis√©s pour encapsuler des logiciels √† installer, et les paquetages de sources, qui contiennent le code et la recette permettant de produire des paquetages binaires.[m
[m
       Un des modes de base suivants doit √™tre s√©lectionn√© : [1mInterroger[0m, [1mV√©rifier[0m, [1mV√©rifier[0m [1mSignature[0m, [1mInstaller/Mettre[0m [1m√†[0m [1mniveau/Rafra√Æchir[0m, [1mD√©sinstaller[0m, [1mConstruire[0m [1mPaquetage[0m,  [1mConstruire[0m  [1mPaquetage[0m  [1m√†[0m  [1mpartir[0m  [1md'un[0m  [1mTarball[0m  (NdT :[m
       sources  au format .tar.xx), [1mRecompiler[0m [1mPaquetage[0m, [1mInitialiser[0m [1mBase[0m [1mde[0m [1mDonn√©es[0m, [1mReconstruire[0m [1mBase[0m [1mde[0m [1mDonn√©es[0m, [1mResigner[0m, [1mAjouter[0m [1mSignature[0m, [1mFixer[0m [1mPropri√©taires/Groupes[0m, [1mMontrer[0m [1mles[0m [1mOptions[0m [1md'Interrogation[0m, et [1mMontrer[0m [1mConfigura‚Äê[0m[m
       [1mtion[0m.[m
[m
   [1mOPTIONS[0m [1mG√âN√âRALES[0m[m
       Ces options peuvent √™tre utilis√©es dans tous les modes.[m
[m
       [1m-?,[0m [1m--help[0m[m
              Afficher un message d'utilisation plus long que de coutume.[m
[7m Manual page rpm(8) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[Kll[Kii[Kss[Ktt[K[1;1HRPM(8)                                                                                                   System Manager's Manual                                                                                                   RPM(8)[m
[2;1H[m
[3;1H[1mNOM[0m[m
[4;1H       rpm - Gestionnaire de Paquetages Red Hat[m
[5;1H[m
[6;1H[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
[7;1H   [1mINTERROGER[0m [1mET[0m [1mV√âRIFIER[0m [1mDES[0m [1mPAQUETAGES[0m [1m:[0m[m
[8;1H       [1mrpm[0m {[1m-q|--query[0m} [[1moptions-s√©lection[0m] [[1moptions-interrogation[0m][m
[9;1H[m
[10;1H       [1mrpm[0m {[1m-V|--verify[0m} [[1moptions-s√©lection[0m] [[1m--nodeps[0m] [[1m--nofiles[0m] [[1m--nomd5[0m] [[1m--noscripts[0m][m
[11;1H[m
[12;1H       [1mrpm[0m {[1m-K|--checksig[0m} [[1m--nogpg[0m] [[1m--nopgp[0m] [[1m--nomd5[0m] [4mFICHIER_PAQUETAGE[24m [4m...[24m[m
[13;1H[m
[14;1H   [1mINSTALLER,[0m [1mMETTRE[0m [1m√Ä[0m [1mNIVEAU[0m [1mET[0m [1mD√âSINSTALLER[0m [1mDES[0m [1mPAQUETAGES[0m [1m:[0m[m

[32;1H[m
[33;1H       [1mrpm[0m {[1m--addsign|--resign[0m} [4mFICHIER_PAQUETAGE[24m [4m...[24m[m

[35;1H       [1mrpm[0m {[1m--querytags|--showrc[0m}[m
[36;1H[m
[37;1H       [1mrpm[0m {[1m--setperms|--setugids[0m} [4mNOM_PAQUETAGE[24m [4m...[24m[m

[39;1H   [1mOPTIONS[0m [1mDE[0m [1mS√âLECTION[0m[m

       La forme g√©n√©rale d'une commande d'installation rpm est[m

       Cela installe un nouveau paquetage.[m
[m
       La forme g√©n√©rale d'une commande de mise √† niveau rpm est[m
[m
       [1mrpm[0m {[1m-U|--upgrade[0m} [[1moptions-installation[0m] [4mFICHIER_PAQUETAGE[24m [4m...[24m[m

       Cela met √† niveau ou installe le paquetage actuellement install√© vers une version plus r√©cente. C'est similaire √† l'installation, sauf que toutes les anciennes versions du paquetage sont  d√©sinstall√©es  apr√®s  que  le  nouveau[m
       paquetage ait √©t√© install√©.[m

       [1mrpm[0m {[1m-F|--freshen[0m} [[1moptions-installation[0m] [4mFICHIER_PAQUETAGE[24m [4m...[24m[m

       Cela  mettra  √†  niveau les paquetages, mais seulement si une version plus ancienne existe √† cet instant. Le [4mFICHIER_PAQUETAGE[24m peut √™tre sp√©cifi√© en tant qu'URL [1mftp[0m ou [1mhttp[0m, auquel cas le paquetage sera t√©l√©charg√© avant d'√™tre[m

       [1m--allfiles[0m[m
              Installer ou mettre √† niveau tous les fichiers manquants du paquetage, m√™me s'ils existent d√©j√†.[m

       [1m--badreloc[0m[m
              Utilis√© avec [1m--relocate[0m, permet des relogements dans tous les chemins de fichiers, et pas seulement dans les [4mANCIEN_CHEMIN[24m inclus dans les indications de relogement du paquetage binaire.[m

       [1m--excludepath[0m [4mANCIEN_CHEMIN[24m[m
              Ne pas installer de fichier dont le nom commence par [4mANCIEN_CHEMIN[24m.[m

       [1m--ignoresize[0m[m
              Ne pas v√©rifier s'il y a un espace disque suffisant sur les syst√®mes de fichiers mont√©s avant d'installer ce paquetage.[m

       [1m--ignorearch[0m[m
              Permettre l'installation ou la mise √† niveau m√™me si les architectures du paquetage binaire et de l'h√¥te ne correspondent pas.[m

       [1m--ignoreos[0m[m
              Permettre l'installation ou la mise √† niveau m√™me si les syst√®mes d'exploitation du paquetage binaire et de l'h√¥te ne concordent pas.[m
[m
       [1m--includedocs[0m[m
              Installer les fichiers de documentation. C'est le comportement par d√©faut.[m
[m
       [1m--justdb[0m[m
              Ne mettre √† jour que la base de donn√©es, et pas le syst√®me de fichiers.[m
[7m Manual page rpm(8) line 81 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[K[m

   [1mOPTIONS[0m [1mD'INTERROGATION[0m[m
       La forme g√©n√©rale d'une commande d'interrogation rpm est[m
[m
       [1mrpm[0m {[1m-q|--query[0m} [[1moptions-s√©lection[0m] [[1moptions-interrogation[0m][m
[m
       Vous  pouvez sp√©cifier le format dans lequel les informations sur le paquetage doivent √™tre affich√©es. Pour ce faire, utilisez l'option {[1m--qf|--queryformat[0m}, suivie par la cha√Æne de format [4mFORMAT_REQU√äTE[24m. Les cha√Ænes de format[m
       sont des versions modifi√©es de celles du [1mprintf(3)[0m standard. Le format est constitu√© de cha√Ænes de caract√®res statiques (qui peuvent inclure les s√©quences d'√©chappement de caract√®re C standard pour les sauts de lignes, tabula‚Äê[m
       tions  et  autres  caract√®res  sp√©ciaux)  et de formateurs de type [1mprintf(3)[0m. Comme [1mrpm[0m conna√Æt d√©j√† le type √† afficher, le sp√©cificateur de type doit n√©anmoins √™tre omis, et √™tre remplac√© par le nom de l'√©tiquette d'en-t√™te √†[m
       afficher, enferm√© dans des caract√®res [1m{}[0m. Les noms d'√©tiquettes sont insensibles √† la casse, et la partie [1mRPMTAG_[0m du nom de l'√©tiquette peut √©galement √™tre omise.[m
[m
       Des formats de sortie alternatifs peuvent √™tre requis en faisant suivre l'√©tiquette par [1m:[0m[4mtypetag[24m. Actuellement, les types suivants sont support√©s : [1moctal[0m, [1mdate[0m,  [1mshescape[0m,  [1mperms[0m,  [1mfflags[0m,  and  [1mdepflags[0m.   Par  exemple,  pour[m
       n'afficher  que  le  nom  des  paquetages  interrog√©s,  vous  pourriez  utiliser [1m%{NAME}[0m comme cha√Æne de format. Pour afficher les noms de paquetages et les informations de distribution en deux colonnes, vous pourriez utiliser[m
       [1m%-30{NAME}%{DISTRIBUTION}[0m. [1mrpm[0m affichera une [7mlist[27me de tous les √©tiquettes qu'il conna√Æt quand il est invoqu√© avec l'argument [1m--querytags[0m.[m
[7m Manual page rpm(8) line 151 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[K[m
       Il y a deux sous-ensembles d'options d'interrogation : la s√©lection de paquetage, et la s√©lection d'informations.[m

[45;1H              Lister uniquement les [7mfichier[27ms de configuration (implique [1m-l[0m).[m
[46;1H[m

[48;1H              Lister uniquement les [7mfichier[27ms de documentation (implique [1m-l[0m).[m
[49;1H[m
[50;1H       [1m--dump[0m Afficher les informations sur le [7mfichier[27m comme suit :[m

[52;1H               chemin taille date_modif somme_md5 mode propri√©taire[m
[53;1H               groupe isconfig isdoc rdev symlink[m
[54;1H[m
[55;1H       Cette option doit √™tre utilis√©e avec au moins une option parmi [1m-l[0m, [1m-c[0m, [1m-d[0m.[m
[56;1H[m
[57;1H       [1m--filesbypkg[0m[m
[58;1H              Lister tous les [7mfichier[27ms de chaque paquetage s√©lectionn√©.[m
[59;1H[m
[60;1H       [1m-i,[0m [1m--info[0m[m
[61;1H              Afficher des informations sur le paquetage, incluant son nom, sa version et sa description. Utilise l'option [1m--queryformat[0m si elle a √©t√© sp√©cifi√©e.[m
[62;1H[m
[63;1H       [1m--last[0m Ordonner le listing des paquetages par date d'installation de sorte que les derniers paquetages install√©s apparaissent en premier lieu.[m
[64;1H[m
[65;1H       [1m-l,[0m [1m--list[0m[m
[66;1H              Lister les [7mfichier[27ms du paquetage.[m
[m
       [1m--provides[0m[m
              Lister les capacit√©s que fournit ce paquetage.[m
[m
       [1m-R,[0m [1m--requires[0m[m

[m

[?1049h[?1h=# For more information about this file, see the man pages
# ntp.conf(5), ntp_acc(5), ntp_auth(5), ntp_clock(5), ntp_misc(5), ntp_mon(5).

driftfile /var/lib/ntp/drift

# Permit time synchronization with our time source, but do not
# permit the source to query or modify the service on this system.
restrict default nomodify notrap nopeer noquery

# Permit all access over the loopback interface.  This could
# be tightened as well, but to do so would effect some of
# the administrative functions.
restrict 127.0.0.1 
restrict ::1

# Hosts on local network are less restricted.
#restrict 192.168.1.0 mask 255.255.255.0 nomodify notrap

# Use public servers from the pool.ntp.org project.
# Please consider joining the pool (http://www.pool.ntp.org/join.html).
server 0.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
server 1.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
server 2.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
server 3.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst

#broadcast 192.168.1.255 autokey        # broadcast server
#broadcastclient                        # broadcast client
#broadcast 224.0.1.1 autokey            # multicast server
#multicastclient 224.0.1.1              # multicast client
#manycastserver 239.255.254.254         # manycast server
#manycastclient 239.255.254.254 autokey # manycast client

# Enable public key cryptography.
#crypto

includefile /etc/ntp/crypto/pw

# Key file containing the keys and key identifiers used when operating
# with symmetric key cryptography. 
keys /etc/ntp/keys

# Specify the key identifiers which are trusted.
#trustedkey 4 8 42

# Specify the key identifier to use with the ntpdc utility.
#requestkey 8

# Specify the key identifier to use with the ntpq utility.
#controlkey 8

# Enable writing of statistics records.
#statistics clockstats cryptostats loopstats peerstats

# Disable the monitoring facility to prevent amplification attacks using ntpdc
# monlist command when default restrict does not include the noquery flag. See
# CVE-2013-5211 for more details.
# Note: Monitoring will not be disabled with the limited restriction flag.
disable monitor
[7m/etc/ntp.conf (END)[27m[K[K[?1l>[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 16:31:38]# man ntp.conf
[?1049h[?1h=ntp.conf(5)                                                                                                File Formats Manual                                                                                                ntp.conf(5)[m
[m
[1mNAME[0m[m
       ntp.conf - Server Options[m
[m
       Following  is a description of the configuration commands in NTPv4. There are two classes of commands, configuration commands that configure an association with a remote server, peer or reference clock, and auxilliary commands[m
       that specify environmental variables that control various related operations.[m
[m
       The various modes described on the Association Management page are determined by the command keyword and the DNS name or IP address. Addresses are classed by type as (s) a remote server or peer (IPv4 class A, B and C), (b) the[m
       IP  broadcast address of a local interface, (m) a multicast address (IPv4 class D), or (r) a reference clock address (127.127.x.x). For type m addresses the IANA has assigned the multicast group address IPv4 224.0.1.1 and IPv6[m
       ff05::101 (site local) exclusively to NTP, but other nonconflicting addresses can be used.[m
[m
       If the Basic Socket Interface Extensions for IPv6 (RFC-2553) is detected, support for the IPv6 address family is generated in addition to the default IPv4 address family. IPv6 addresses can be identified  by  the  presence  of[m
       colons ":" in the address field. IPv6 addresses can be used almost everywhere where IPv4 addresses can be used, with the exception of reference clock addresses, which are always IPv4. Note that in contexts where a host name is[m
       expected, a [1m-4[0m qualifier preceding the host name forces DNS resolution to the IPv4 namespace, while a [1m-6[0m qualifier forces DNS resolution to the IPv6 namespace.[m
[m
[1mCONFIGURATION[0m [1mCOMMANDS[0m[m
       [1mserver[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[options[0m [1m...][0m[m
[m
       [1mpeer[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[options[0m [1m...][0m[m
[m
       [1mbroadcast[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[options[0m [1m...][0m[m
[m
       [1mmanycastclient[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[options[0m [1m...][0m[m
[m
       [1mpool[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[options[0m [1m...][0m[m
[m
       [1munpeer[0m [1m[[0m[4maddress[24m [1m|[0m [4massocid[24m[1m][0m[m
               These commands specify the time server name or address to be used and the mode in which to operate. The [4maddress[24m can be either a DNS name or a IPv4 or IPv6 address in standard notation. In general, multiple commands  of[m
               each type can be used for different server and peer addresses or multicast groups.[m
[m
               [1mserver[0m  For  type  s and r addresses (only), this command mobilizes a persistent client mode association with the specified remote server or local reference clock. If the [1mpreempt[0m flag is specified, a preemptable client[m
                       mode association is mobilized instead.[m
[m
               [1mpeer[0m    For type s addresses (only), this command mobilizes a persistent symmetric-active mode association with the specified remote peer.[m
[m
               [1mbroadcast[0m[m
                       For type b and m addressees (only), this command mobilizes a persistent broadcast or multicast server mode association. Note that type b messages go only to the interface specified, but type m  messages  go  to[m
                       all interfaces.[m
[m
               [1mmanycastclient[0m[m
                       For  type m addresses (only), this command mobilizes a manycast client mode association for the multicast group address specified. In this mode the address must match the address specified on the [1mmanycastserver[0m[m
                       command of one or more designated manycast servers.[m
[m
               [1mpool[0m    For type s messages (only) this command mobilizes a client mode association for servers implementing the pool automatic server discovery scheme described on the Association Management page. The address is a DNS[m
                       name in the form [4marea[24m[1m.pool.ntp.org[0m, where [4marea[24m is a qualifier designating the server geographic area such as [1mus[0m or [1meurope[0m.[m
[m
               [1munpeer[0m  This  command  removes  a  previously configured association. An address or association ID can be used to identify the association. Either an IP address or DNS name can be used. This command is most useful when[m
                       supplied via [1mntpq[0m runtime configuration commands [1m:config[0m and [1mconfig-from-file[0m.[m
[m
[1mCOMMAND[0m [1mOPTIONS[0m[m
       [1mautokey[0m Send and receive packets authenticated by the Autokey scheme described in the Authentication Options page. This option is mutually exclusive with the [1mkey[0m option.[m
[m
       [1mburst[0m   When the server is reachable, send a burst of eight packets instead of the usual one. The packet spacing is normally 2 s; however, the spacing between the first and second packets can be changed with the [1mcalldelay[0m com‚Äê[m
               mand  to  allow additional time for a modem or ISDN call to complete. This option is valid only with the [1mserver[0m command and type s addressesa. It is a recommended option when the [1mmaxpoll[0m option is greater than 10 (1024[m
               s).[m
[m
       [1miburst[0m  When the server is unreachable, send a burst of eight packets instead of the usual one. The packet spacing is normally 2 s; however, the spacing between the first and second packets can be changed  with  the  [1mcalldelay[0m[m
               command to allow additional time for a modem or ISDN call to complete. This option is valid only with the [1mserver[0m command and type s addresses. It is a recommended option with this command.[m
[m
       [1mkey[0m [1mkey[0m Send  and  receive  packets  authenticated  by the symmetric key scheme described in the Authentication Options page. The [1mkey[0m specifies the key identifier with values from 1 to 65534, inclusive. This option is mutually[m
               exclusive with the [1mautokey[0m option.[m
[m
       [1mminpoll[0m [4mminpoll[24m[m
[m
[7m Manual page ntp.conf(5) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[Kee[Ktt[Kqq[K[7m Manual page ntp.conf(5) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K[?1l>[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 16:31:46]# man ntp.confless /etc/ntp.conf 
[?1049h[?1h=# For more information about this file, see the man pages
# ntp.conf(5), ntp_acc(5), ntp_auth(5), ntp_clock(5), ntp_misc(5), ntp_mon(5).

driftfile /var/lib/ntp/drift

# Permit time synchronization with our time source, but do not
# permit the source to query or modify the service on this system.
restrict default nomodify notrap nopeer noquery

# Permit all access over the loopback interface.  This could
# be tightened as well, but to do so would effect some of
# the administrative functions.
restrict 127.0.0.1 
restrict ::1

# Hosts on local network are less restricted.
#restrict 192.168.1.0 mask 255.255.255.0 nomodify notrap

# Use public servers from the pool.ntp.org project.
# Please consider joining the pool (http://www.pool.ntp.org/join.html).
server 0.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
server 1.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
server 2.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
server 3.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst

#broadcast 192.168.1.255 autokey        # broadcast server
#broadcastclient                        # broadcast client
#broadcast 224.0.1.1 autokey            # multicast server
#multicastclient 224.0.1.1              # multicast client
#manycastserver 239.255.254.254         # manycast server
#manycastclient 239.255.254.254 autokey # manycast client

# Enable public key cryptography.
#crypto

includefile /etc/ntp/crypto/pw

# Key file containing the keys and key identifiers used when operating
# with symmetric key cryptography. 
keys /etc/ntp/keys

# Specify the key identifiers which are trusted.
#trustedkey 4 8 42

# Specify the key identifier to use with the ntpdc utility.
#requestkey 8

# Specify the key identifier to use with the ntpq utility.
#controlkey 8

# Enable writing of statistics records.
#statistics clockstats cryptostats loopstats peerstats

# Disable the monitoring facility to prevent amplification attacks using ntpdc
# monlist command when default restrict does not include the noquery flag. See
# CVE-2013-5211 for more details.
# Note: Monitoring will not be disabled with the limited restriction flag.
disable monitor

[42;1H# Specify the key identifiers which are trusted.
[43;1H#trustedkey 4 8 42
[44;1H
[45;1H# Specify the key identifier to use with the ntpdc utility.
[46;1H#requestkey 8
[47;1H
[48;1H# Specify the key identifier to use with the ntpq utility.
[49;1H#controlkey 8
[50;1H
[51;1H# Enable writing of statistics records.
[52;1H#statistics clockstats cryptostats loopstats peerstats
[53;1H
[54;1H# Disable the monitoring facility to prevent amplification attacks using ntpdc
[55;1H# monlist command when default restrict does not include the noquery flag. See
[56;1H# CVE-2013-5211 for more details.
[57;1H# Note: Monitoring will not be disabled with the limited restriction flag.
[58;1Hdisable monitor
[59;1H[1m~[0m
[66;1H[K[7mPattern not found  (press RETURN)[27m[66;1H[K[K/[Kee[Khh[K[Ktt[Khh[K00[K[1;1H# For more information about this file, see the man pages
[2;1H# ntp.conf(5), ntp_acc(5), ntp_auth(5), ntp_clock(5), ntp_misc(5), ntp_mon(5).
[3;1H
[4;1Hdriftfile /var/lib/ntp/drift
[5;1H
[6;1H# Permit time synchronization with our time source, but do not
[7;1H# permit the source to query or modify the service on this system.
[8;1Hrestrict default nomodify notrap nopeer noquery
[9;1H
[10;1H# Permit all access over the loopback interface.  This could
[11;1H# be tightened as well, but to do so would effect some of
[12;1H# the administrative functions.
[13;1Hrestrict 127.0.0.1 
[14;1Hrestrict ::1
[15;1H
[16;1H# Hosts on local network are less restricted.
[17;1H#restrict 192.168.1.0 mask 255.255.255.0 nomodify notrap
[18;1H
[19;1H# Use public servers from the pool.ntp.org project.
[20;1H# Please consider joining the pool (http://www.pool.ntp.org/join.html).
[21;1Hserver 0.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
[22;1Hserver 1.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
[23;1Hserver 2.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
[24;1Hserver 3.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
[25;1H
[26;1H#broadcast 192.168.1.255 autokey        # broadcast server
[27;1H#broadcastclient                        # broadcast client
[28;1H#broadcast 224.0.1.1 autokey            # multicast server
[29;1H#multicastclient 224.0.1.1              # multicast client
[30;1H#manycastserver 239.255.254.254         # manycast server
[31;1H#manycastclient 239.255.254.254 autokey # manycast client
[32;1H
[33;1H# Enable public key cryptography.
[34;1H#crypto
[35;1H
[36;1Hincludefile /etc/ntp/crypto/pw
[37;1H
[38;1H# Key file containing the keys and key identifiers used when operating
[39;1H# with symmetric key cryptography. 
[40;1Hkeys /etc/ntp/keys
[41;1H
[42;1H# Specify the key identifiers which are trusted.
[43;1H#trustedkey 4 8 42
[44;1H
[45;1H# Specify the key identifier to use with the ntpdc utility.
[46;1H#requestkey 8
[47;1H
[48;1H# Specify the key identifier to use with the ntpq utility.
[49;1H#controlkey 8
[50;1H
[51;1H# Enable writing of statistics records.
[52;1H#statistics clockstats cryptostats loopstats peerstats
[53;1H
[54;1H# Disable the monitoring facility to prevent amplification attacks using ntpdc
[55;1H# monlist command when default restrict does not include the noquery flag. See
[56;1H# CVE-2013-5211 for more details.
[57;1H# Note: Monitoring will not be disabled with the limited restriction flag.
[58;1Hdisable monitor
[59;1H[1m~[0m
[66;1H[1;1H# For more information about this file, see the man pages
[2;1H# ntp.conf(5), ntp_acc(5), ntp_auth(5), ntp_clock(5), ntp_misc(5), ntp_mon(5).
[3;1H
[4;1Hdriftfile /var/lib/ntp/drift
[5;1H
[6;1H# Permit time synchronization with our time source, but do not
[7;1H# permit the source to query or modify the service on this system.
[8;1Hrestrict default nomodify notrap nopeer noquery
[9;1H
[10;1H# Permit all access over the loopback interface.  This could
[11;1H# be tightened as well, but to do so would effect some of
[12;1H# the administrative functions.
[13;1Hrestrict 127.0.0.1 
[14;1Hrestrict ::1
[15;1H
[16;1H# Hosts on local network are less restricted.
[17;1H#restrict 192.168.1.0 mask 255.255.255.0 nomodify notrap
[18;1H
[19;1H# Use public servers from the pool.ntp.org project.
[20;1H# Please consider joining the pool (http://www.pool.ntp.org/join.html).
[21;1Hserver 0.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
[22;1Hserver 1.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
[23;1Hserver 2.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
[24;1Hserver 3.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
[25;1H
[26;1H#broadcast 192.168.1.255 autokey        # broadcast server
[27;1H#broadcastclient                        # broadcast client
[28;1H#broadcast 224.0.1.1 autokey            # multicast server
[29;1H#multicastclient 224.0.1.1              # multicast client
[30;1H#manycastserver 239.255.254.254         # manycast server
[31;1H#manycastclient 239.255.254.254 autokey # manycast client
[32;1H
[33;1H# Enable public key cryptography.
[34;1H#crypto
[35;1H
[36;1Hincludefile /etc/ntp/crypto/pw
[37;1H
[38;1H# Key file containing the keys and key identifiers used when operating
[39;1H# with symmetric key cryptography. 
[40;1Hkeys /etc/ntp/keys
[41;1H
[42;1H# Specify the key identifiers which are trusted.
[43;1H#trustedkey 4 8 42
[44;1H
[45;1H# Specify the key identifier to use with the ntpdc utility.
[46;1H#requestkey 8
[47;1H
[48;1H# Specify the key identifier to use with the ntpq utility.
[49;1H#controlkey 8
[50;1H
[51;1H# Enable writing of statistics records.
[52;1H#statistics clockstats cryptostats loopstats peerstats
[53;1H

[55;1H# monlist command when default restrict does not include the noquery flag. See
[56;1H# CVE-2013-5211 for more details.
[57;1H# Note: Monitoring will not be disabled with the limited restriction flag.
[58;1Hdisable monitor

[66;1H[K[7mPattern not found  (press RETURN)[27m[66;1H[K[K [KESCESC[K[[[K55[K~~[K[7m(END)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[K[[[K55[K~~[K[K[7m(END)[27m[K[K[?1l>[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 16:31:58]# less /etc/ntp.conf [7Pman ntp.confless /etc/ntp.conf [7Pman ntp.conf
[?1049h[?1h=ntp.conf(5)                                                                                                File Formats Manual                                                                                                ntp.conf(5)[m
[m
[1mNAME[0m[m
       ntp.conf - Server Options[m
[m
       Following  is a description of the configuration commands in NTPv4. There are two classes of commands, configuration commands that configure an association with a remote server, peer or reference clock, and auxilliary commands[m
       that specify environmental variables that control various related operations.[m
[m
       The various modes described on the Association Management page are determined by the command keyword and the DNS name or IP address. Addresses are classed by type as (s) a remote server or peer (IPv4 class A, B and C), (b) the[m
       IP  broadcast address of a local interface, (m) a multicast address (IPv4 class D), or (r) a reference clock address (127.127.x.x). For type m addresses the IANA has assigned the multicast group address IPv4 224.0.1.1 and IPv6[m
       ff05::101 (site local) exclusively to NTP, but other nonconflicting addresses can be used.[m
[m
       If the Basic Socket Interface Extensions for IPv6 (RFC-2553) is detected, support for the IPv6 address family is generated in addition to the default IPv4 address family. IPv6 addresses can be identified  by  the  presence  of[m
       colons ":" in the address field. IPv6 addresses can be used almost everywhere where IPv4 addresses can be used, with the exception of reference clock addresses, which are always IPv4. Note that in contexts where a host name is[m
       expected, a [1m-4[0m qualifier preceding the host name forces DNS resolution to the IPv4 namespace, while a [1m-6[0m qualifier forces DNS resolution to the IPv6 namespace.[m
[m
[1mCONFIGURATION[0m [1mCOMMANDS[0m[m
       [1mserver[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[options[0m [1m...][0m[m
[m
       [1mpeer[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[options[0m [1m...][0m[m
[m
       [1mbroadcast[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[options[0m [1m...][0m[m
[m
       [1mmanycastclient[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[options[0m [1m...][0m[m
[m
       [1mpool[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[options[0m [1m...][0m[m
[m
       [1munpeer[0m [1m[[0m[4maddress[24m [1m|[0m [4massocid[24m[1m][0m[m
               These commands specify the time server name or address to be used and the mode in which to operate. The [4maddress[24m can be either a DNS name or a IPv4 or IPv6 address in standard notation. In general, multiple commands  of[m
               each type can be used for different server and peer addresses or multicast groups.[m
[m
               [1mserver[0m  For  type  s and r addresses (only), this command mobilizes a persistent client mode association with the specified remote server or local reference clock. If the [1mpreempt[0m flag is specified, a preemptable client[m
                       mode association is mobilized instead.[m
[m
               [1mpeer[0m    For type s addresses (only), this command mobilizes a persistent symmetric-active mode association with the specified remote peer.[m
[m
               [1mbroadcast[0m[m
                       For type b and m addressees (only), this command mobilizes a persistent broadcast or multicast server mode association. Note that type b messages go only to the interface specified, but type m  messages  go  to[m
                       all interfaces.[m
[m
               [1mmanycastclient[0m[m
                       For  type m addresses (only), this command mobilizes a manycast client mode association for the multicast group address specified. In this mode the address must match the address specified on the [1mmanycastserver[0m[m
                       command of one or more designated manycast servers.[m
[m
               [1mpool[0m    For type s messages (only) this command mobilizes a client mode association for servers implementing the pool automatic server discovery scheme described on the Association Management page. The address is a DNS[m
                       name in the form [4marea[24m[1m.pool.ntp.org[0m, where [4marea[24m is a qualifier designating the server geographic area such as [1mus[0m or [1meurope[0m.[m
[m
               [1munpeer[0m  This  command  removes  a  previously configured association. An address or association ID can be used to identify the association. Either an IP address or DNS name can be used. This command is most useful when[m
                       supplied via [1mntpq[0m runtime configuration commands [1m:config[0m and [1mconfig-from-file[0m.[m
[m
[1mCOMMAND[0m [1mOPTIONS[0m[m
       [1mautokey[0m Send and receive packets authenticated by the Autokey scheme described in the Authentication Options page. This option is mutually exclusive with the [1mkey[0m option.[m
[m
       [1mburst[0m   When the server is reachable, send a burst of eight packets instead of the usual one. The packet spacing is normally 2 s; however, the spacing between the first and second packets can be changed with the [1mcalldelay[0m com‚Äê[m
               mand  to  allow additional time for a modem or ISDN call to complete. This option is valid only with the [1mserver[0m command and type s addressesa. It is a recommended option when the [1mmaxpoll[0m option is greater than 10 (1024[m
               s).[m
[m
       [1miburst[0m  When the server is unreachable, send a burst of eight packets instead of the usual one. The packet spacing is normally 2 s; however, the spacing between the first and second packets can be changed  with  the  [1mcalldelay[0m[m
               command to allow additional time for a modem or ISDN call to complete. This option is valid only with the [1mserver[0m command and type s addresses. It is a recommended option with this command.[m
[m
       [1mkey[0m [1mkey[0m Send  and  receive  packets  authenticated  by the symmetric key scheme described in the Authentication Options page. The [1mkey[0m specifies the key identifier with values from 1 to 65534, inclusive. This option is mutually[m
               exclusive with the [1mautokey[0m option.[m
[m
       [1mminpoll[0m [4mminpoll[24m[m
[m
[7m Manual page ntp.conf(5) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[Krr[Kee[Kss[Ktt[Krr[Kii[Kcc[Ktt[K[1;1Hntp.conf(5)                                                                                                File Formats Manual                                                                                                ntp.conf(5)[m
[2;1H[m
[3;1H[1mNAME[0m[m
[4;1H       ntp.conf - Server Options[m
[5;1H[m
[6;1H       Following  is a description of the configuration commands in NTPv4. There are two classes of commands, configuration commands that configure an association with a remote server, peer or reference clock, and auxilliary commands[m
[7;1H       that specify environmental variables that control various related operations.[m
[8;1H[m
[9;1H       The various modes described on the Association Management page are determined by the command keyword and the DNS name or IP address. Addresses are classed by type as (s) a remote server or peer (IPv4 class A, B and C), (b) the[m
[10;1H       IP  broadcast address of a local interface, (m) a multicast address (IPv4 class D), or (r) a reference clock address (127.127.x.x). For type m addresses the IANA has assigned the multicast group address IPv4 224.0.1.1 and IPv6[m
[11;1H       ff05::101 (site local) exclusively to NTP, but other nonconflicting addresses can be used.[m
[12;1H[m
[13;1H       If the Basic Socket Interface Extensions for IPv6 (RFC-2553) is detected, support for the IPv6 address family is generated in addition to the default IPv4 address family. IPv6 addresses can be identified  by  the  presence  of[m
[14;1H       colons ":" in the address field. IPv6 addresses can be used almost everywhere where IPv4 addresses can be used, with the exception of reference clock addresses, which are always IPv4. Note that in contexts where a host name is[m
[15;1H       expected, a [1m-4[0m qualifier preceding the host name forces DNS resolution to the IPv4 namespace, while a [1m-6[0m qualifier forces DNS resolution to the IPv6 namespace.[m
[16;1H[m
[17;1H[1mCONFIGURATION[0m [1mCOMMANDS[0m[m
[18;1H       [1mserver[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[options[0m [1m...][0m[m
[19;1H[m
[20;1H       [1mpeer[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[options[0m [1m...][0m[m
[21;1H[m
[22;1H       [1mbroadcast[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[options[0m [1m...][0m[m
[23;1H[m
[24;1H       [1mmanycastclient[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[options[0m [1m...][0m[m
[25;1H[m
[26;1H       [1mpool[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[options[0m [1m...][0m[m
[27;1H[m
[28;1H       [1munpeer[0m [1m[[0m[4maddress[24m [1m|[0m [4massocid[24m[1m][0m[m
[29;1H               These commands specify the time server name or address to be used and the mode in which to operate. The [4maddress[24m can be either a DNS name or a IPv4 or IPv6 address in standard notation. In general, multiple commands  of[m
[30;1H               each type can be used for different server and peer addresses or multicast groups.[m
[31;1H[m
[32;1H               [1mserver[0m  For  type  s and r addresses (only), this command mobilizes a persistent client mode association with the specified remote server or local reference clock. If the [1mpreempt[0m flag is specified, a preemptable client[m
[33;1H                       mode association is mobilized instead.[m
[34;1H[m
[35;1H               [1mpeer[0m    For type s addresses (only), this command mobilizes a persistent symmetric-active mode association with the specified remote peer.[m
[36;1H[m
[37;1H               [1mbroadcast[0m[m
[38;1H                       For type b and m addressees (only), this command mobilizes a persistent broadcast or multicast server mode association. Note that type b messages go only to the interface specified, but type m  messages  go  to[m
[39;1H                       all interfaces.[m
[40;1H[m
[41;1H               [1mmanycastclient[0m[m
[42;1H                       For  type m addresses (only), this command mobilizes a manycast client mode association for the multicast group address specified. In this mode the address must match the address specified on the [1mmanycastserver[0m[m
[43;1H                       command of one or more designated manycast servers.[m
[44;1H[m
[45;1H               [1mpool[0m    For type s messages (only) this command mobilizes a client mode association for servers implementing the pool automatic server discovery scheme described on the Association Management page. The address is a DNS[m
[46;1H                       name in the form [4marea[24m[1m.pool.ntp.org[0m, where [4marea[24m is a qualifier designating the server geographic area such as [1mus[0m or [1meurope[0m.[m
[47;1H[m
[48;1H               [1munpeer[0m  This  command  removes  a  previously configured association. An address or association ID can be used to identify the association. Either an IP address or DNS name can be used. This command is most useful when[m
[49;1H                       supplied via [1mntpq[0m runtime configuration commands [1m:config[0m and [1mconfig-from-file[0m.[m
[50;1H[m
[51;1H[1mCOMMAND[0m [1mOPTIONS[0m[m
[52;1H       [1mautokey[0m Send and receive packets authenticated by the Autokey scheme described in the Authentication Options page. This option is mutually exclusive with the [1mkey[0m option.[m
[53;1H[m
[54;1H       [1mburst[0m   When the server is reachable, send a burst of eight packets instead of the usual one. The packet spacing is normally 2 s; however, the spacing between the first and second packets can be changed with the [1mcalldelay[0m com‚Äê[m
[55;1H               mand  to  allow additional time for a modem or ISDN call to complete. This option is valid only with the [1mserver[0m command and type s addressesa. It is a recommended option when the [1mmaxpoll[0m option is greater than 10 (1024[m
[56;1H               s).[m
[57;1H[m
[58;1H       [1miburst[0m  When the server is unreachable, send a burst of eight packets instead of the usual one. The packet spacing is normally 2 s; however, the spacing between the first and second packets can be changed  with  the  [1mcalldelay[0m[m
[59;1H               command to allow additional time for a modem or ISDN call to complete. This option is valid only with the [1mserver[0m command and type s addresses. It is a recommended option with this command.[m
[60;1H[m
[61;1H       [1mkey[0m [1mkey[0m Send  and  receive  packets  authenticated  by the symmetric key scheme described in the Authentication Options page. The [1mkey[0m specifies the key identifier with values from 1 to 65534, inclusive. This option is mutually[m
[62;1H               exclusive with the [1mautokey[0m option.[m
[63;1H[m
[64;1H       [1mminpoll[0m [4mminpoll[24m[m
[65;1H[m
[66;1H[1;1Hntp.conf(5)                                                                                                File Formats Manual                                                                                                ntp.conf(5)[m
[2;1H[m
[3;1H[1mNAME[0m[m
[4;1H       ntp.conf - Server Options[m
[5;1H[m
[6;1H       Following  is a description of the configuration commands in NTPv4. There are two classes of commands, configuration commands that configure an association with a remote server, peer or reference clock, and auxilliary commands[m
[7;1H       that specify environmental variables that control various related operations.[m
[8;1H[m
[9;1H       The various modes described on the Association Management page are determined by the command keyword and the DNS name or IP address. Addresses are classed by type as (s) a remote server or peer (IPv4 class A, B and C), (b) the[m
[10;1H       IP  broadcast address of a local interface, (m) a multicast address (IPv4 class D), or (r) a reference clock address (127.127.x.x). For type m addresses the IANA has assigned the multicast group address IPv4 224.0.1.1 and IPv6[m
[11;1H       ff05::101 (site local) exclusively to NTP, but other nonconflicting addresses can be used.[m
[12;1H[m
[13;1H       If the Basic Socket Interface Extensions for IPv6 (RFC-2553) is detected, support for the IPv6 address family is generated in addition to the default IPv4 address family. IPv6 addresses can be identified  by  the  presence  of[m
[14;1H       colons ":" in the address field. IPv6 addresses can be used almost everywhere where IPv4 addresses can be used, with the exception of reference clock addresses, which are always IPv4. Note that in contexts where a host name is[m
[15;1H       expected, a [1m-4[0m qualifier preceding the host name forces DNS resolution to the IPv4 namespace, while a [1m-6[0m qualifier forces DNS resolution to the IPv6 namespace.[m
[16;1H[m
[17;1H[1mCONFIGURATION[0m [1mCOMMANDS[0m[m
[18;1H       [1mserver[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[options[0m [1m...][0m[m
[19;1H[m
[20;1H       [1mpeer[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[options[0m [1m...][0m[m
[21;1H[m
[22;1H       [1mbroadcast[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[options[0m [1m...][0m[m
[23;1H[m
[24;1H       [1mmanycastclient[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[options[0m [1m...][0m[m
[25;1H[m
[26;1H       [1mpool[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[options[0m [1m...][0m[m
[27;1H[m
[28;1H       [1munpeer[0m [1m[[0m[4maddress[24m [1m|[0m [4massocid[24m[1m][0m[m
[29;1H               These commands specify the time server name or address to be used and the mode in which to operate. The [4maddress[24m can be either a DNS name or a IPv4 or IPv6 address in standard notation. In general, multiple commands  of[m
[30;1H               each type can be used for different server and peer addresses or multicast groups.[m
[31;1H[m
[32;1H               [1mserver[0m  For  type  s and r addresses (only), this command mobilizes a persistent client mode association with the specified remote server or local reference clock. If the [1mpreempt[0m flag is specified, a preemptable client[m
[33;1H                       mode association is mobilized instead.[m
[34;1H[m
[35;1H               [1mpeer[0m    For type s addresses (only), this command mobilizes a persistent symmetric-active mode association with the specified remote peer.[m
[36;1H[m
[37;1H               [1mbroadcast[0m[m
[38;1H                       For type b and m addressees (only), this command mobilizes a persistent broadcast or multicast server mode association. Note that type b messages go only to the interface specified, but type m  messages  go  to[m
[39;1H                       all interfaces.[m
[40;1H[m
[41;1H               [1mmanycastclient[0m[m
[42;1H                       For  type m addresses (only), this command mobilizes a manycast client mode association for the multicast group address specified. In this mode the address must match the address specified on the [1mmanycastserver[0m[m
[43;1H                       command of one or more designated manycast servers.[m
[44;1H[m
[45;1H               [1mpool[0m    For type s messages (only) this command mobilizes a client mode association for servers implementing the pool automatic server discovery scheme described on the Association Management page. The address is a DNS[m
[46;1H                       name in the form [4marea[24m[1m.pool.ntp.org[0m, where [4marea[24m is a qualifier designating the server geographic area such as [1mus[0m or [1meurope[0m.[m
[47;1H[m
[48;1H               [1munpeer[0m  This  command  removes  a  previously configured association. An address or association ID can be used to identify the association. Either an IP address or DNS name can be used. This command is most useful when[m
[49;1H                       supplied via [1mntpq[0m runtime configuration commands [1m:config[0m and [1mconfig-from-file[0m.[m
[50;1H[m
[51;1H[1mCOMMAND[0m [1mOPTIONS[0m[m
[52;1H       [1mautokey[0m Send and receive packets authenticated by the Autokey scheme described in the Authentication Options page. This option is mutually exclusive with the [1mkey[0m option.[m
[53;1H[m
[54;1H       [1mburst[0m   When the server is reachable, send a burst of eight packets instead of the usual one. The packet spacing is normally 2 s; however, the spacing between the first and second packets can be changed with the [1mcalldelay[0m com‚Äê[m
[55;1H               mand  to  allow additional time for a modem or ISDN call to complete. This option is valid only with the [1mserver[0m command and type s addressesa. It is a recommended option when the [1mmaxpoll[0m option is greater than 10 (1024[m
[56;1H               s).[m
[57;1H[m
[58;1H       [1miburst[0m  When the server is unreachable, send a burst of eight packets instead of the usual one. The packet spacing is normally 2 s; however, the spacing between the first and second packets can be changed  with  the  [1mcalldelay[0m[m
[59;1H               command to allow additional time for a modem or ISDN call to complete. This option is valid only with the [1mserver[0m command and type s addresses. It is a recommended option with this command.[m
[60;1H[m
[61;1H       [1mkey[0m [1mkey[0m Send  and  receive  packets  authenticated  by the symmetric key scheme described in the Authentication Options page. The [1mkey[0m specifies the key identifier with values from 1 to 65534, inclusive. This option is mutually[m
[62;1H               exclusive with the [1mautokey[0m option.[m
[63;1H[m
[64;1H       [1mminpoll[0m [4mminpoll[24m[m
[65;1H[m
[66;1H[K[7mPattern not found  (press RETURN)[27m[66;1H[K[K/[Kee[Ktt[Khh[K[1;1Hntp.conf(5)                                                                                                File Formats Manual                                                                                                ntp.conf(5)[m
[2;1H[m
[3;1H[1mNAME[0m[m
[4;1H       ntp.conf - Server Options[m
[5;1H[m
[6;1H       Following  is a description of the configuration commands in NTPv4. There are two classes of commands, configuration commands that configure an association with a remote server, peer or reference clock, and auxilliary commands[m
[7;1H       that specify environmental variables that control various related operations.[m
[8;1H[m
[9;1H       The various modes described on the Association Management page are determined by the command keyword and the DNS name or IP address. Addresses are classed by type as (s) a remote server or peer (IPv4 class A, B and C), (b) the[m
[10;1H       IP  broadcast address of a local interface, (m) a multicast address (IPv4 class D), or (r) a reference clock address (127.127.x.x). For type m addresses the IANA has assigned the multicast group address IPv4 224.0.1.1 and IPv6[m
[11;1H       ff05::101 (site local) exclusively to NTP, but other nonconflicting addresses can be used.[m
[12;1H[m
[13;1H       If the Basic Socket Interface Extensions for IPv6 (RFC-2553) is detected, support for the IPv6 address family is generated in addition to the default IPv4 address family. IPv6 addresses can be identified  by  the  presence  of[m
[14;1H       colons ":" in the address field. IPv6 addresses can be used almost everywhere where IPv4 addresses can be used, with the exception of reference clock addresses, which are always IPv4. Note that in contexts where a host name is[m
[15;1H       expected, a [1m-4[0m qualifier preceding the host name forces DNS resolution to the IPv4 namespace, while a [1m-6[0m qualifier forces DNS resolution to the IPv6 namespace.[m
[16;1H[m
[17;1H[1mCONFIGURATION[0m [1mCOMMANDS[0m[m
[18;1H       [1mserver[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[options[0m [1m...][0m[m
[19;1H[m
[20;1H       [1mpeer[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[options[0m [1m...][0m[m
[21;1H[m
[22;1H       [1mbroadcast[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[options[0m [1m...][0m[m
[23;1H[m
[24;1H       [1mmanycastclient[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[options[0m [1m...][0m[m
[25;1H[m
[26;1H       [1mpool[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[options[0m [1m...][0m[m
[27;1H[m
[28;1H       [1munpeer[0m [1m[[0m[4maddress[24m [1m|[0m [4massocid[24m[1m][0m[m
[29;1H               These commands specify the time server name or address to be used and the mode in which to operate. The [4maddress[24m can be either a DNS name or a IPv4 or IPv6 address in standard notation. In general, multiple commands  of[m
[30;1H               each type can be used for different server and peer addresses or multicast groups.[m
[31;1H[m
[32;1H               [1mserver[0m  For  type  s and r addresses (only), this command mobilizes a persistent client mode association with the specified remote server or local reference clock. If the [1mpreempt[0m flag is specified, a preemptable client[m
[33;1H                       mode association is mobilized instead.[m
[34;1H[m
[35;1H               [1mpeer[0m    For type s addresses (only), this command mobilizes a persistent symmetric-active mode association with the specified remote peer.[m
[36;1H[m
[37;1H               [1mbroadcast[0m[m
[38;1H                       For type b and m addressees (only), this command mobilizes a persistent broadcast or multicast server mode association. Note that type b messages go only to the interface specified, but type m  messages  go  to[m
[39;1H                       all interfaces.[m
[40;1H[m
[41;1H               [1mmanycastclient[0m[m
[42;1H                       For  type m addresses (only), this command mobilizes a manycast client mode association for the multicast group address specified. In this mode the address must match the address specified on the [1mmanycastserver[0m[m
[43;1H                       command of one or more designated manycast servers.[m
[44;1H[m
[45;1H               [1mpool[0m    For type s messages (only) this command mobilizes a client mode association for servers implementing the pool automatic server discovery scheme described on the Association Management page. The address is a DNS[m
[46;1H                       name in the form [4marea[24m[1m.pool.ntp.org[0m, where [4marea[24m is a qualifier designating the server geographic area such as [1mus[0m or [1meurope[0m.[m
[47;1H[m
[48;1H               [1munpeer[0m  This  command  removes  a  previously configured association. An address or association ID can be used to identify the association. Either an IP address or DNS name can be used. This command is most useful when[m
[49;1H                       supplied via [1mntpq[0m runtime configuration commands [1m:config[0m and [1mconfig-from-file[0m.[m
[50;1H[m
[51;1H[1mCOMMAND[0m [1mOPTIONS[0m[m
[52;1H       [1mautokey[0m Send and receive packets authenticated by the Autokey scheme described in the Authentication Options page. This option is mutually exclusive with the [1mkey[0m option.[m
[53;1H[m
[54;1H       [1mburst[0m   When the server is reachable, send a burst of eight packets instead of the usual one. The packet spacing is normally 2 s; however, the spacing between the first and second packets can be changed with the [1mcalldelay[0m com‚Äê[m
[55;1H               mand  to  allow additional time for a modem or ISDN call to complete. This option is valid only with the [1mserver[0m command and type s addressesa. It is a recommended option when the [1mmaxpoll[0m option is greater than 10 (1024[m
[56;1H               s).[m
[57;1H[m
[58;1H       [1miburst[0m  When the server is unreachable, send a burst of eight packets instead of the usual one. The packet spacing is normally 2 s; however, the spacing between the first and second packets can be changed  with  the  [1mcalldelay[0m[m
[59;1H               command to allow additional time for a modem or ISDN call to complete. This option is valid only with the [1mserver[0m command and type s addresses. It is a recommended option with this command.[m
[60;1H[m
[61;1H       [1mkey[0m [1mkey[0m Send  and  receive  packets  authenticated  by the symmetric key scheme described in the Authentication Options page. The [1mkey[0m specifies the key identifier with values from 1 to 65534, inclusive. This option is mutually[m
[62;1H               exclusive with the [1mautokey[0m option.[m
[63;1H[m
[64;1H       [1mminpoll[0m [4mminpoll[24m[m
[65;1H[m
[66;1H[1;1Hntp.conf(5)                                                                                                File Formats Manual                                                                                                ntp.conf(5)[m
[2;1H[m
[3;1H[1mNAME[0m[m
[4;1H       ntp.conf - Server Options[m
[5;1H[m
[6;1H       Following  is a description of the configuration commands in NTPv4. There are two classes of commands, configuration commands that configure an association with a remote server, peer or reference clock, and auxilliary commands[m
[7;1H       that specify environmental variables that control various related operations.[m
[8;1H[m
[9;1H       The various modes described on the Association Management page are determined by the command keyword and the DNS name or IP address. Addresses are classed by type as (s) a remote server or peer (IPv4 class A, B and C), (b) the[m
[10;1H       IP  broadcast address of a local interface, (m) a multicast address (IPv4 class D), or (r) a reference clock address (127.127.x.x). For type m addresses the IANA has assigned the multicast group address IPv4 224.0.1.1 and IPv6[m
[11;1H       ff05::101 (site local) exclusively to NTP, but other nonconflicting addresses can be used.[m
[12;1H[m
[13;1H       If the Basic Socket Interface Extensions for IPv6 (RFC-2553) is detected, support for the IPv6 address family is generated in addition to the default IPv4 address family. IPv6 addresses can be identified  by  the  presence  of[m
[14;1H       colons ":" in the address field. IPv6 addresses can be used almost everywhere where IPv4 addresses can be used, with the exception of reference clock addresses, which are always IPv4. Note that in contexts where a host name is[m
[15;1H       expected, a [1m-4[0m qualifier preceding the host name forces DNS resolution to the IPv4 namespace, while a [1m-6[0m qualifier forces DNS resolution to the IPv6 namespace.[m
[16;1H[m
[17;1H[1mCONFIGURATION[0m [1mCOMMANDS[0m[m
[18;1H       [1mserver[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[options[0m [1m...][0m[m
[19;1H[m
[20;1H       [1mpeer[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[options[0m [1m...][0m[m
[21;1H[m
[22;1H       [1mbroadcast[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[options[0m [1m...][0m[m
[23;1H[m
[24;1H       [1mmanycastclient[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[options[0m [1m...][0m[m
[25;1H[m
[26;1H       [1mpool[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[options[0m [1m...][0m[m
[27;1H[m
[28;1H       [1munpeer[0m [1m[[0m[4maddress[24m [1m|[0m [4massocid[24m[1m][0m[m
[29;1H               These commands specify the time server name or address to be used and the mode in which to operate. The [4maddress[24m can be either a DNS name or a IPv4 or IPv6 address in standard notation. In general, multiple commands  of[m
[30;1H               each type can be used for different server and peer addresses or multicast groups.[m
[31;1H[m
[32;1H               [1mserver[0m  For  type  s and r addresses (only), this command mobilizes a persistent client mode association with the specified remote server or local reference clock. If the [1mpreempt[0m flag is specified, a preemptable client[m
[33;1H                       mode association is mobilized instead.[m
[34;1H[m
[35;1H               [1mpeer[0m    For type s addresses (only), this command mobilizes a persistent symmetric-active mode association with the specified remote peer.[m
[36;1H[m
[37;1H               [1mbroadcast[0m[m
[38;1H                       For type b and m addressees (only), this command mobilizes a persistent broadcast or multicast server mode association. Note that type b messages go only to the interface specified, but type m  messages  go  to[m
[39;1H                       all interfaces.[m
[40;1H[m
[41;1H               [1mmanycastclient[0m[m
[42;1H                       For  type m addresses (only), this command mobilizes a manycast client mode association for the multicast group address specified. In this mode the address must match the address specified on the [1mmanycastserver[0m[m
[43;1H                       command of one or more designated manycast servers.[m
[44;1H[m
[45;1H               [1mpool[0m    For type s messages (only) this command mobilizes a client mode association for servers implementing the pool automatic server discovery scheme described on the Association Management page. The address is a DNS[m
[46;1H                       name in the form [4marea[24m[1m.pool.ntp.org[0m, where [4marea[24m is a qualifier designating the server geographic area such as [1mus[0m or [1meurope[0m.[m
[47;1H[m
[48;1H               [1munpeer[0m  This  command  removes  a  previously configured association. An address or association ID can be used to identify the association. Either an IP address or DNS name can be used. This command is most useful when[m
[49;1H                       supplied via [1mntpq[0m runtime configuration commands [1m:config[0m and [1mconfig-from-file[0m.[m
[50;1H[m
[51;1H[1mCOMMAND[0m [1mOPTIONS[0m[m
[52;1H       [1mautokey[0m Send and receive packets authenticated by the Autokey scheme described in the Authentication Options page. This option is mutually exclusive with the [1mkey[0m option.[m
[53;1H[m
[54;1H       [1mburst[0m   When the server is reachable, send a burst of eight packets instead of the usual one. The packet spacing is normally 2 s; however, the spacing between the first and second packets can be changed with the [1mcalldelay[0m com‚Äê[m
[55;1H               mand  to  allow additional time for a modem or ISDN call to complete. This option is valid only with the [1mserver[0m command and type s addressesa. It is a recommended option when the [1mmaxpoll[0m option is greater than 10 (1024[m
[56;1H               s).[m
[57;1H[m
[58;1H       [1miburst[0m  When the server is unreachable, send a burst of eight packets instead of the usual one. The packet spacing is normally 2 s; however, the spacing between the first and second packets can be changed  with  the  [1mcalldelay[0m[m
[59;1H               command to allow additional time for a modem or ISDN call to complete. This option is valid only with the [1mserver[0m command and type s addresses. It is a recommended option with this command.[m
[60;1H[m
[61;1H       [1mkey[0m [1mkey[0m Send  and  receive  packets  authenticated  by the symmetric key scheme described in the Authentication Options page. The [1mkey[0m specifies the key identifier with values from 1 to 65534, inclusive. This option is mutually[m
[62;1H               exclusive with the [1mautokey[0m option.[m
[63;1H[m
[64;1H       [1mminpoll[0m [4mminpoll[24m[m
[65;1H[m
[66;1H[K[7mPattern not found  (press RETURN)[27m[66;1H[K[K/[Kee[Ktt[Khh[K[K[K[K[7m Manual page ntp.conf(5) line 1/131 53% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[K[[[K66[K~~[K       [1mmaxpoll[0m [4mmaxpoll[24m[m
               These options specify the minimum and maximum poll intervals for NTP messages, in seconds as a power of two. The maximum poll interval defaults to 10 (1024 s), but can be increased by the [1mmaxpoll[0m  option  to  an  upper[m
               limit of 17 (36 h). The minimum poll interval defaults to 6 (64 s), but can be decreased by the [1mminpoll[0m option to a lower limit of 3 (8 s).[m
[m
       [1mmode[0m [4moption[24m[m
               Pass the [4moption[24m to a reference clock driver, where [4moption[24m is an integer in the range from 0 to 255, inclusive. This option is valid only with type r addresses.[m
[m
       [1mnoselect[0m[m
               Marks the server or peer to be ignored by the selection algorithm but visible to the monitoring program. This option is ignored with the [1mbroadcast[0m command.[m
[m
       [1mpreempt[0m Specifies the association as preemptable rather than the default persistent. This option is ignored with the [1mbroadcast[0m command and is most useful with the [1mmanycastclient[0m and [1mpool[0m commands.[m
[m
       [1mprefer[0m  Mark the server as preferred. All other things being equal, this host will be chosen for synchronization among a set of correctly operating hosts. See the Mitigation Rules and the [1mprefer[0m Keyword page for further infor‚Äê[m
               mation. This option is valid only with the [1mserver[0m and [1mpeer[0m commands.[m
[m
       [1mtrue[0m    Mark the association to assume truechimer status; that is, always survive the selection and clustering algorithms. This option can be used with any association, but is most useful for reference clocks with large jitter[m
               on  the  serial port and precision pulse-per-second (PPS) signals. Caution: this option defeats the algorithms designed to cast out falsetickers and can allow these sources to set the system clock. This option is valid[m
               only with the [1mserver[0m and [1mpeer[0m commands.[m
[m
       [1mttl[0m [4mttl[24m This option specifies the time-to-live [1mttl[0m for the [1mbroadcast[0m command and the maximum [1mttl[0m for the expanding ring search used by the [1mmanycastclient[0m command. Selection of the proper value, which defaults to 127, is  some‚Äê[m
               thing of a black art and should be coordinated with the network administrator. This option is invalid with type r addresses.[m
[m
       [1mversion[0m [4mversion[24m[m
               Specifies the version number to be used f or outgoing NTP packets. Versions 1-4 are the choices, with version 4 the default.[m
[m
       [1mxleave[0m  Operate in interleaved mode (symmetric and broadcast modes only). (see NTP Interleaved Modes)[m
[m
[1mAUXILLIARY[0m [1mCOMMANDS[0m[m
       [1mbroadcastclient[0m[m
               Enable  reception  of  broadcast  server messages to any local interface (type b address). Ordinarily, upon receiving a broadcast message for the first time, the broadcast client measures the nominal server propagation[m
               delay using a brief client/server exchange, after which it continues in listen-only mode. If a nonzero value is specified in the [1mbroadcastdelay[0m command, the value becomes the delay and the volley is not executed. Note:[m
               the [1mnovolley[0m option has been deprecated for future enhancements. Note that, in order to avoid accidental or malicious disruption in this mode, both the server and client should operate using symmetric key or public key[m
               authentication as described in the Authentication Options page. Note that the [1mnovolley[0m keyword is incompatible with public key authentication.[m
[m
       [1mmanycastserver[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[...][0m[m
               Enable reception of manycast client messages (type m)to the multicast group address(es) (type m) specified. At least one address is required. Note that, in order to avoid accidental or malicious  disruption,  both  the[m
               server and client should operate using symmetric key or public key authentication as described in the Authentication Options page.[m
[m
       [1mmulticastclient[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[...][0m[m
               Enable reception of multicast server messages to the multicast group address(es) (type m) specified. Upon receiving a message for the first time, the multicast client measures the nominal server propagation delay using[m
               a brief client/server exchange with the server, then enters the broadcast client mode, in which it synchronizes to succeeding multicast messages. Note that, in order to avoid accidental or malicious disruption in  this[m
               mode, both the server and client should operate using symmetric key or public key authentication as described in the Authentication Options page.[m
[m
[1mBUGS[0m[m
       The syntax checking is not picky; some combinations of ridiculous and even hilarious options and modes may not be detected.[m
[m
[1mSEE[0m [1mALSO[0m[m
       ntpd(8), ntp_auth(5), ntp_mon(5), ntp_acc(5), ntp_clock(5), ntp_misc(5)[m
[m
       The official HTML documentation.[m
