[7m Manual page ntp.conf(5) line 61/131 (END) (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[K[[[K66[K~~[K[K[7m Manual page ntp.conf(5) line 61/131 (END) (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K[?1l>[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 16:32:09]# man ntp.confless /etc/ntp.conf 
[?1049h[?1h=# For more information about this file, see the man pages
# ntp.conf(5), ntp_acc(5), ntp_auth(5), ntp_clock(5), ntp_misc(5), ntp_mon(5).

driftfile /var/lib/ntp/drift

# Permit time synchronization with our time source, but do not
# permit the source to query or modify the service on this system.
restrict default nomodify notrap nopeer noquery

# Permit all access over the loopback interface.  This could
# be tightened as well, but to do so would effect some of
# the administrative functions.
restrict 127.0.0.1 
restrict ::1

# Hosts on local network are less restricted.
#restrict 192.168.1.0 mask 255.255.255.0 nomodify notrap

# Use public servers from the pool.ntp.org project.
# Please consider joining the pool (http://www.pool.ntp.org/join.html).
server 0.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
server 1.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
server 2.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
server 3.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst

#broadcast 192.168.1.255 autokey        # broadcast server
#broadcastclient                        # broadcast client
#broadcast 224.0.1.1 autokey            # multicast server
#multicastclient 224.0.1.1              # multicast client
#manycastserver 239.255.254.254         # manycast server
#manycastclient 239.255.254.254 autokey # manycast client

# Enable public key cryptography.
#crypto

includefile /etc/ntp/crypto/pw

# Key file containing the keys and key identifiers used when operating
# with symmetric key cryptography. 
keys /etc/ntp/keys

# Specify the key identifiers which are trusted.
#trustedkey 4 8 42

# Specify the key identifier to use with the ntpdc utility.
#requestkey 8

# Specify the key identifier to use with the ntpq utility.
#controlkey 8

# Enable writing of statistics records.
#statistics clockstats cryptostats loopstats peerstats

# Disable the monitoring facility to prevent amplification attacks using ntpdc
# monlist command when default restrict does not include the noquery flag. See
# CVE-2013-5211 for more details.
# Note: Monitoring will not be disabled with the limited restriction flag.
disable monitor
[7m/etc/ntp.conf (END)[27m[K[K/[Kpp[Koo[Krr[Ktt[K...skipping...
# For more information about this file, see the man pages
# ntp.conf(5), ntp_acc(5), ntp_auth(5), ntp_clock(5), ntp_misc(5), ntp_mon(5).

driftfile /var/lib/ntp/drift

# Permit time synchronization with our time source, but do not
# permit the source to query or modify the service on this system.
restrict default nomodify notrap nopeer noquery

# Permit all access over the loopback interface.  This could
# be tightened as well, but to do so would effect some of
# the administrative functions.
restrict 127.0.0.1 
restrict ::1

# Hosts on local network are less restricted.
#restrict 192.168.1.0 mask 255.255.255.0 nomodify notrap

# Use public servers from the pool.ntp.org project.
# Please consider joining the pool (http://www.pool.ntp.org/join.html).
server 0.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
server 1.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
server 2.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
server 3.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst

#broadcast 192.168.1.255 autokey        # broadcast server
#broadcastclient                        # broadcast client
#broadcast 224.0.1.1 autokey            # multicast server
#multicastclient 224.0.1.1              # multicast client
#manycastserver 239.255.254.254         # manycast server
#manycastclient 239.255.254.254 autokey # manycast client

# Enable public key cryptography.
#crypto

includefile /etc/ntp/crypto/pw

# Key file containing the keys and key identifiers used when operating
# with symmetric key cryptography. 
keys /etc/ntp/keys

# Specify the key identifiers which are trusted.
#trustedkey 4 8 42

# Specify the key identifier to use with the ntpdc utility.
#requestkey 8

# Specify the key identifier to use with the ntpq utility.
#controlkey 8

# Enable writing of statistics records.
#statistics clockstats cryptostats loopstats peerstats

# Disable the monitoring facility to prevent amplification attacks using ntpdc
# monlist command when default restrict does not include the noquery flag. See
# CVE-2013-5211 for more details.
# Note: Monitoring will not be disabled with the limited restriction flag.
disable monitor

[3;1H
[4;1Hdriftfile /var/lib/ntp/drift
[5;1H
[6;1H# Permit time synchronization with our time source, but do not
[7;1H# permit the source to query or modify the service on this system.
[8;1Hrestrict default nomodify notrap nopeer noquery
[9;1H
[10;1H# Permit all access over the loopback interface.  This could
[11;1H# be tightened as well, but to do so would effect some of
[12;1H# the administrative functions.
[13;1Hrestrict 127.0.0.1 
[14;1Hrestrict ::1
[15;1H
[16;1H# Hosts on local network are less restricted.
[17;1H#restrict 192.168.1.0 mask 255.255.255.0 nomodify notrap
[18;1H
[19;1H# Use public servers from the pool.ntp.org project.
[20;1H# Please consider joining the pool (http://www.pool.ntp.org/join.html).
[21;1Hserver 0.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
[22;1Hserver 1.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
[23;1Hserver 2.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
[24;1Hserver 3.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
[25;1H
[26;1H#broadcast 192.168.1.255 autokey        # broadcast server
[27;1H#broadcastclient                        # broadcast client
[28;1H#broadcast 224.0.1.1 autokey            # multicast server
[29;1H#multicastclient 224.0.1.1              # multicast client
[30;1H#manycastserver 239.255.254.254         # manycast server
[31;1H#manycastclient 239.255.254.254 autokey # manycast client
[32;1H
[33;1H# Enable public key cryptography.
[34;1H#crypto
[35;1H
[36;1Hincludefile /etc/ntp/crypto/pw
[37;1H
[38;1H# Key file containing the keys and key identifiers used when operating
[39;1H# with symmetric key cryptography. 
[40;1Hkeys /etc/ntp/keys
[41;1H
[42;1H# Specify the key identifiers which are trusted.
[43;1H#trustedkey 4 8 42
[44;1H
[45;1H# Specify the key identifier to use with the ntpdc utility.
[46;1H#requestkey 8
[47;1H
[48;1H# Specify the key identifier to use with the ntpq utility.
[49;1H#controlkey 8
[50;1H
[51;1H# Enable writing of statistics records.
[52;1H#statistics clockstats cryptostats loopstats peerstats
[53;1H
[54;1H# Disable the monitoring facility to prevent amplification attacks using ntpdc
[55;1H# monlist command when default restrict does not include the noquery flag. See
[56;1H# CVE-2013-5211 for more details.
[57;1H# Note: Monitoring will not be disabled with the limited restriction flag.
[58;1Hdisable monitor
[59;1H[1m~[0m
[66;1H[1;1H# For more information about this file, see the man pages
[2;1H# ntp.conf(5), ntp_acc(5), ntp_auth(5), ntp_clock(5), ntp_misc(5), ntp_mon(5).
[3;1H

]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 16:35:00]# man [1@(reverse-i-search)`':[C[C[C[C[C[4@less[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[15@less /etc/ntp.conf^C
]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 16:35:04]# [1@(reverse-i-search)`':[Cm': man ntp.conf[1@a[C[C[C[1@n[C[C[C[C[C[C[C[5Prpm^C
]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 16:35:06]# [1@(reverse-i-search)`':[Cm': man ntp.conf[1@a[C[C[C[1@n[C[C[C[4P[root@vm0 16:35:06]#[C
[?1049h[?1h=ntp.conf(5)                                                                                                File Formats Manual                                                                                                ntp.conf(5)[m
[m
[1mNAME[0m[m
       ntp.conf - Server Options[m
[m
       Following  is a description of the configuration commands in NTPv4. There are two classes of commands, configuration commands that configure an association with a remote server, peer or reference clock, and auxilliary commands[m
       that specify environmental variables that control various related operations.[m
[m
       The various modes described on the Association Management page are determined by the command keyword and the DNS name or IP address. Addresses are classed by type as (s) a remote server or peer (IPv4 class A, B and C), (b) the[m
       IP  broadcast address of a local interface, (m) a multicast address (IPv4 class D), or (r) a reference clock address (127.127.x.x). For type m addresses the IANA has assigned the multicast group address IPv4 224.0.1.1 and IPv6[m
       ff05::101 (site local) exclusively to NTP, but other nonconflicting addresses can be used.[m
[m
       If the Basic Socket Interface Extensions for IPv6 (RFC-2553) is detected, support for the IPv6 address family is generated in addition to the default IPv4 address family. IPv6 addresses can be identified  by  the  presence  of[m
       colons ":" in the address field. IPv6 addresses can be used almost everywhere where IPv4 addresses can be used, with the exception of reference clock addresses, which are always IPv4. Note that in contexts where a host name is[m
       expected, a [1m-4[0m qualifier preceding the host name forces DNS resolution to the IPv4 namespace, while a [1m-6[0m qualifier forces DNS resolution to the IPv6 namespace.[m
[m
[1mCONFIGURATION[0m [1mCOMMANDS[0m[m
       [1mserver[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[options[0m [1m...][0m[m
[m
       [1mpeer[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[options[0m [1m...][0m[m
[m
       [1mbroadcast[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[options[0m [1m...][0m[m
[m
       [1mmanycastclient[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[options[0m [1m...][0m[m
[m
       [1mpool[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[options[0m [1m...][0m[m
[m
       [1munpeer[0m [1m[[0m[4maddress[24m [1m|[0m [4massocid[24m[1m][0m[m
               These commands specify the time server name or address to be used and the mode in which to operate. The [4maddress[24m can be either a DNS name or a IPv4 or IPv6 address in standard notation. In general, multiple commands  of[m
               each type can be used for different server and peer addresses or multicast groups.[m
[m
               [1mserver[0m  For  type  s and r addresses (only), this command mobilizes a persistent client mode association with the specified remote server or local reference clock. If the [1mpreempt[0m flag is specified, a preemptable client[m
                       mode association is mobilized instead.[m
[m
               [1mpeer[0m    For type s addresses (only), this command mobilizes a persistent symmetric-active mode association with the specified remote peer.[m
[m
               [1mbroadcast[0m[m
                       For type b and m addressees (only), this command mobilizes a persistent broadcast or multicast server mode association. Note that type b messages go only to the interface specified, but type m  messages  go  to[m
                       all interfaces.[m
[m
               [1mmanycastclient[0m[m
                       For  type m addresses (only), this command mobilizes a manycast client mode association for the multicast group address specified. In this mode the address must match the address specified on the [1mmanycastserver[0m[m
                       command of one or more designated manycast servers.[m
[m
               [1mpool[0m    For type s messages (only) this command mobilizes a client mode association for servers implementing the pool automatic server discovery scheme described on the Association Management page. The address is a DNS[m
                       name in the form [4marea[24m[1m.pool.ntp.org[0m, where [4marea[24m is a qualifier designating the server geographic area such as [1mus[0m or [1meurope[0m.[m
[m
               [1munpeer[0m  This  command  removes  a  previously configured association. An address or association ID can be used to identify the association. Either an IP address or DNS name can be used. This command is most useful when[m
                       supplied via [1mntpq[0m runtime configuration commands [1m:config[0m and [1mconfig-from-file[0m.[m
[m
[1mCOMMAND[0m [1mOPTIONS[0m[m
       [1mautokey[0m Send and receive packets authenticated by the Autokey scheme described in the Authentication Options page. This option is mutually exclusive with the [1mkey[0m option.[m
[m
       [1mburst[0m   When the server is reachable, send a burst of eight packets instead of the usual one. The packet spacing is normally 2 s; however, the spacing between the first and second packets can be changed with the [1mcalldelay[0m com‚Äê[m
               mand  to  allow additional time for a modem or ISDN call to complete. This option is valid only with the [1mserver[0m command and type s addressesa. It is a recommended option when the [1mmaxpoll[0m option is greater than 10 (1024[m
               s).[m
[m
       [1miburst[0m  When the server is unreachable, send a burst of eight packets instead of the usual one. The packet spacing is normally 2 s; however, the spacing between the first and second packets can be changed  with  the  [1mcalldelay[0m[m
               command to allow additional time for a modem or ISDN call to complete. This option is valid only with the [1mserver[0m command and type s addresses. It is a recommended option with this command.[m
[m
       [1mkey[0m [1mkey[0m Send  and  receive  packets  authenticated  by the symmetric key scheme described in the Authentication Options page. The [1mkey[0m specifies the key identifier with values from 1 to 65534, inclusive. This option is mutually[m
               exclusive with the [1mautokey[0m option.[m
[m
       [1mminpoll[0m [4mminpoll[24m[m
[m
[7m Manual page ntp.conf(5) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[Krr[Kee[Kss[Ktt[Krr[Kii[Kcc[Ktt[K[1;1Hntp.conf(5)                                                                                                File Formats Manual                                                                                                ntp.conf(5)[m
[2;1H[m

[11;1H       ff05::101 (site local) exclusively to NTP, but other nonconflicting addresses can be used.[m
[12;1H[m

[15;1H       expected, a [1m-4[0m qualifier preceding the host name forces DNS resolution to the IPv4 namespace, while a [1m-6[0m qualifier forces DNS resolution to the IPv6 namespace.[m

[50;1H[m
[51;1H[1mCOMMAND[0m [1mOPTIONS[0m[m
[52;1H       [1mautokey[0m Send and receive packets authenticated by the Autokey scheme described in the Authentication Options page. This option is mutually exclusive with the [1mkey[0m option.[m
[53;1H[m
[54;1H       [1mburst[0m   When the server is reachable, send a burst of eight packets instead of the usual one. The packet spacing is normally 2 s; however, the spacing between the first and second packets can be changed with the [1mcalldelay[0m com‚Äê[m
[55;1H               mand  to  allow additional time for a modem or ISDN call to complete. This option is valid only with the [1mserver[0m command and type s addressesa. It is a recommended option when the [1mmaxpoll[0m option is greater than 10 (1024[m
[56;1H               s).[m
[57;1H[m
[58;1H       [1miburst[0m  When the server is unreachable, send a burst of eight packets instead of the usual one. The packet spacing is normally 2 s; however, the spacing between the first and second packets can be changed  with  the  [1mcalldelay[0m[m
[59;1H               command to allow additional time for a modem or ISDN call to complete. This option is valid only with the [1mserver[0m command and type s addresses. It is a recommended option with this command.[m

[1mNAME[0m[m
       ntp.conf - Server Options[m
[m
       Following  is a description of the configuration commands in NTPv4. There are two classes of commands, configuration commands that configure an association with a remote server, peer or reference clock, and auxilliary commands[m
       that specify environmental variables that control various related operations.[m
[m
       The various modes described on the Association Management page are determined by the command keyword and the DNS name or IP address. Addresses are classed by type as (s) a remote server or peer (IPv4 class A, B and C), (b) the[m
       IP  broadcast address of a local interface, (m) a multicast address (IPv4 class D), or (r) a reference clock address (127.127.x.x). For type m addresses the IANA has assigned the multicast group address IPv4 224.0.1.1 and IPv6[m
       ff05::101 (site local) exclusively to NTP, but other nonconflicting addresses can be used.[m
[m
       If the Basic Socket Interface Extensions for IPv6 (RFC-2553) is detected, support for the IPv6 address family is generated in addition to the default IPv4 address family. IPv6 addresses can be identified  by  the  presence  of[m
       colons ":" in the address field. IPv6 addresses can be used almost everywhere where IPv4 addresses can be used, with the exception of reference clock addresses, which are always IPv4. Note that in contexts where a host name is[m
       expected, a [1m-4[0m qualifier preceding the host name forces DNS resolution to the IPv4 namespace, while a [1m-6[0m qualifier forces DNS resolution to the IPv6 namespace.[m

       [1mautokey[0m Send and receive packets authenticated by the Autokey scheme described in the Authentication Options page. This option is mutually exclusive with the [1mkey[0m option.[m
[m
       [1mburst[0m   When the server is reachable, send a burst of eight packets instead of the usual one. The packet spacing is normally 2 s; however, the spacing between the first and second packets can be changed with the [1mcalldelay[0m com‚Äê[m
               mand  to  allow additional time for a modem or ISDN call to complete. This option is valid only with the [1mserver[0m command and type s addressesa. It is a recommended option when the [1mmaxpoll[0m option is greater than 10 (1024[m
               s).[m
[m
       [1miburst[0m  When the server is unreachable, send a burst of eight packets instead of the usual one. The packet spacing is normally 2 s; however, the spacing between the first and second packets can be changed  with  the  [1mcalldelay[0m[m
               command to allow additional time for a modem or ISDN call to complete. This option is valid only with the [1mserver[0m command and type s addresses. It is a recommended option with this command.[m
[m
       [1mkey[0m [1mkey[0m Send  and  receive  packets  authenticated  by the symmetric key scheme described in the Authentication Options page. The [1mkey[0m specifies the key identifier with values from 1 to 65534, inclusive. This option is mutually[m
               exclusive with the [1mautokey[0m option.[m
[m
       [1mminpoll[0m [4mminpoll[24m[m
[m
[7m Manual page ntp.conf(5) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[Kqq[K[7m Manual page ntp.conf(5) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K[?1l>[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 16:35:57]# man ntp.confjournalctl -f _COMM="ntpd"[1P"^C
]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 16:35:58]# [1@(reverse-i-search)`':[Cl': journalctl -f _COMM="ntpd"[6Pe': less /etc/ntp.conf [1@s[C[C[C[4P[root@vm0 16:35:58]#[C
[?1049h[?1h=# For more information about this file, see the man pages
# ntp.conf(5), ntp_acc(5), ntp_auth(5), ntp_clock(5), ntp_misc(5), ntp_mon(5).

driftfile /var/lib/ntp/drift

# Permit time synchronization with our time source, but do not
# permit the source to query or modify the service on this system.
restrict default nomodify notrap nopeer noquery

# Permit all access over the loopback interface.  This could
# be tightened as well, but to do so would effect some of
# the administrative functions.
restrict 127.0.0.1 
restrict ::1

# Hosts on local network are less restricted.
#restrict 192.168.1.0 mask 255.255.255.0 nomodify notrap

# Use public servers from the pool.ntp.org project.
# Please consider joining the pool (http://www.pool.ntp.org/join.html).
server 0.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
server 1.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
server 2.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
server 3.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst

#broadcast 192.168.1.255 autokey        # broadcast server
#broadcastclient                        # broadcast client
#broadcast 224.0.1.1 autokey            # multicast server
#multicastclient 224.0.1.1              # multicast client
#manycastserver 239.255.254.254         # manycast server
#manycastclient 239.255.254.254 autokey # manycast client

# Enable public key cryptography.
#crypto

includefile /etc/ntp/crypto/pw

# Key file containing the keys and key identifiers used when operating
# with symmetric key cryptography. 
keys /etc/ntp/keys

# Specify the key identifiers which are trusted.
#trustedkey 4 8 42

# Specify the key identifier to use with the ntpdc utility.
#requestkey 8

# Specify the key identifier to use with the ntpq utility.
#controlkey 8

# Enable writing of statistics records.
#statistics clockstats cryptostats loopstats peerstats

# Disable the monitoring facility to prevent amplification attacks using ntpdc
# monlist command when default restrict does not include the noquery flag. See
# CVE-2013-5211 for more details.
# Note: Monitoring will not be disabled with the limited restriction flag.
disable monitor
[7m/etc/ntp.conf (END)[27m[K[K[?1l>[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 16:36:44]# less /etc/ntp.conf [1P[1P[C[1P[1P[1@v[1@i[1@m

driftfile /var/lib/ntp/drift

]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 16:38:34]# man ntpq
[?1049h[?1h=ntpq(8)                                                                                                  System Manager's Manual                                                                                                  ntpq(8)[m
[m
[1mNAME[0m[m
       ntpq - standard NTP query program[m
[m
[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
       [1mntpq[0m [1m[-46dinp][0m [1m[-c[0m [4mcommand[24m[1m][0m [1m[[0m[4mhost[24m[1m][0m [1m[...][0m[m
[m
[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
       The  [1mntpq[0m utility program is used to monitor NTP daemon [1mntpd[0m operations and determine performance. It uses the standard NTP mode 6 control message formats defined in Appendix B of the NTPv3 specification RFC1305. The same for‚Äê[m
       mats are used in NTPv4, although some of the variable names have changed and new ones added. The description on this page is for the NTPv4 variables.[m
[m
       The program can be run either in interactive mode or controlled using command line arguments. Requests to read and write arbitrary variables can be assembled, with raw and pretty-printed output  options  being  available.  The[m
       [1mntpq[0m can also obtain and print a list of peers in a common format by sending multiple queries to the server.[m
[m
       If  one  or  more  request  options  is  included on the command line when [1mntpq[0m is executed, each of the requests will be sent to the NTP servers running on each of the hosts given as command line arguments, or on localhost by[m
       default. If no request options are given, [1mntpq[0m will attempt to read commands from the standard input and execute these on the NTP server running on the first host given on the command line, again defaulting to  localhost  when[m
       no other host is specified. [1mntpq[0m will prompt for commands if the standard input is a terminal device.[m
[m
       [1mntpq[0m  uses  NTP mode 6 packets to communicate with the NTP server, and hence can be used to query any compatible server on the network which permits it. Note that since NTP is a UDP protocol this communication will be somewhat[m
       unreliable, especially over large distances in terms of network topology. [1mntpq[0m makes one attempt to retransmit requests, and will time requests out if the remote host is not heard from within a suitable timeout time.[m
[m
       Note that in contexts where a host name is expected, a [1m-4[0m qualifier preceding the host name forces DNS resolution to the IPv4 namespace, while a [1m-6[0m qualifier forces DNS resolution to the IPv6 namespace.[m
[m
       For examples and usage, see the NTP Debugging Techniques page.[m
[m
       Command line options are described following. Specifying a command line option other than [1m-i[0m or [1m-n[0m will cause the specified query (queries) to be sent to the indicated host(s) immediately. Otherwise, [1mntpq[0m will attempt to  read[m
       interactive format commands from the standard input.[m
[m
       [1m-4[0m      Force DNS resolution of following host names on the command line to the IPv4 namespace.[m
[m
       [1m-6[0m      Force DNS resolution of following host names on the command line to the IPv6 namespace.[m
[m
       [1m-c[0m      The following argument is interpreted as an interactive format command and is added to the list of commands to be executed on the specified host(s). Multiple [1m-c[0m options may be given.[m
[m
       [1m-d[0m      Turn on debugging mode.[m
[m
       [1m-i[0m      Force [1mntpq[0m to operate in interactive mode. Prompts will be written to the standard output and commands read from the standard input.[m
[m
       [1m-n[0m      Output all host addresses in dotted-quad numeric format rather than converting to the canonical host names.[m
[m
       [1m-p[0m      Print a list of the peers known to the server as well as a summary of their state. This is equivalent to the [1mpeers[0m interactive command.[m
[m
[1mINTERNAL[0m [1mCOMMANDS[0m[m
       Interactive  format  commands  consist of a keyword followed by zero to four arguments. Only enough characters of the full keyword to uniquely identify the command need be typed. The output of a command is normally sent to the[m
       standard output, but optionally the output of individual commands may be sent to a file by appending a [1m>[0m, followed by a file name, to the command line. A number of interactive format commands are executed entirely  within  the[m
       [1mntpq[0m program itself and do not result in NTP mode-6 requests being sent to a server. These are described following.[m
[m
       [1m?[0m [1m[[0m[4mcommand_keyword[24m[1m][0m[m
[m
       [1mhelp[0m [1m[[0m[4mcommand_keyword[24m[1m][0m[m
               A [1m?[0m by itself will print a list of all the command keywords known to [1mntpq[0m. A [1m?[0m followed by a command keyword will print function and usage information about the command.[m
[m
       [1maddvars[0m [4mname[24m [1m[[0m [1m=[0m [4mvalue[24m[1m][0m [1m[...][0m[m
[m
       [1mrmvars[0m [4mname[24m [1m[...][0m[m
[m
       [1mclearvars[0m[m
               The arguments to this command consist of a list of items of the form [4mname[24m [1m=[0m [4mvalue[24m, where the [1m=[0m [4mvalue[24m is ignored, and can be omitted in read requests. [1mntpq[0m maintains an internal list in which data to be included in con‚Äê[m
               trol messages can be assembled, and sent using the [1mreadlist[0m and [1mwritelist[0m commands described below. The [1maddvars[0m command allows variables and optional values to be added to the list. If more than one variable is  to  be[m
               added, the list should be comma-separated and not contain white space. The [1mrmvars[0m command can be used to remove individual variables from the list, while the [1mclearlist[0m command removes all variables from the list.[m
[m
       [1mcooked[0m  Display server messages in prettyprint format.[m
[m
       [1mdebug[0m [1mmore[0m [1m|[0m [1mless[0m [1m|[0m [1moff[0m[m
[7m Manual page ntpq(8) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[Kpp[Kee[Kee[Krr[Kss[K[1;1Hntpq(8)                                                                                                  System Manager's Manual                                                                                                  ntpq(8)[m
[2;1H[m
[3;1H[1mNAME[0m[m
[4;1H       ntpq - standard NTP query program[m
[5;1H[m
[6;1H[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
[7;1H       [1mntpq[0m [1m[-46dinp][0m [1m[-c[0m [4mcommand[24m[1m][0m [1m[[0m[4mhost[24m[1m][0m [1m[...][0m[m
[8;1H[m
[9;1H[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
[10;1H       The  [1mntpq[0m utility program is used to monitor NTP daemon [1mntpd[0m operations and determine performance. It uses the standard NTP mode 6 control message formats defined in Appendix B of the NTPv3 specification RFC1305. The same for‚Äê[m
[11;1H       mats are used in NTPv4, although some of the variable names have changed and new ones added. The description on this page is for the NTPv4 variables.[m
[12;1H[m
[13;1H       The program can be run either in interactive mode or controlled using command line arguments. Requests to read and write arbitrary variables can be assembled, with raw and pretty-printed output  options  being  available.  The[m
[14;1H       [1mntpq[0m can also obtain and print a list of peers in a common format by sending multiple queries to the server.[m
[15;1H[m
[16;1H       If  one  or  more  request  options  is  included on the command line when [1mntpq[0m is executed, each of the requests will be sent to the NTP servers running on each of the hosts given as command line arguments, or on localhost by[m
[17;1H       default. If no request options are given, [1mntpq[0m will attempt to read commands from the standard input and execute these on the NTP server running on the first host given on the command line, again defaulting to  localhost  when[m
[18;1H       no other host is specified. [1mntpq[0m will prompt for commands if the standard input is a terminal device.[m
[19;1H[m
[20;1H       [1mntpq[0m  uses  NTP mode 6 packets to communicate with the NTP server, and hence can be used to query any compatible server on the network which permits it. Note that since NTP is a UDP protocol this communication will be somewhat[m
[21;1H       unreliable, especially over large distances in terms of network topology. [1mntpq[0m makes one attempt to retransmit requests, and will time requests out if the remote host is not heard from within a suitable timeout time.[m
[22;1H[m
[23;1H       Note that in contexts where a host name is expected, a [1m-4[0m qualifier preceding the host name forces DNS resolution to the IPv4 namespace, while a [1m-6[0m qualifier forces DNS resolution to the IPv6 namespace.[m
[24;1H[m
[25;1H       For examples and usage, see the NTP Debugging Techniques page.[m
[26;1H[m
[27;1H       Command line options are described following. Specifying a command line option other than [1m-i[0m or [1m-n[0m will cause the specified query (queries) to be sent to the indicated host(s) immediately. Otherwise, [1mntpq[0m will attempt to  read[m
[28;1H       interactive format commands from the standard input.[m
[29;1H[m
[30;1H       [1m-4[0m      Force DNS resolution of following host names on the command line to the IPv4 namespace.[m
[31;1H[m
[32;1H       [1m-6[0m      Force DNS resolution of following host names on the command line to the IPv6 namespace.[m
[33;1H[m
[34;1H       [1m-c[0m      The following argument is interpreted as an interactive format command and is added to the list of commands to be executed on the specified host(s). Multiple [1m-c[0m options may be given.[m
[35;1H[m
[36;1H       [1m-d[0m      Turn on debugging mode.[m
[37;1H[m
[38;1H       [1m-i[0m      Force [1mntpq[0m to operate in interactive mode. Prompts will be written to the standard output and commands read from the standard input.[m
[39;1H[m
[40;1H       [1m-n[0m      Output all host addresses in dotted-quad numeric format rather than converting to the canonical host names.[m
[41;1H[m
[42;1H       [1m-p[0m      Print a list of the peers known to the server as well as a summary of their state. This is equivalent to the [1mpeers[0m interactive command.[m
[43;1H[m
[44;1H[1mINTERNAL[0m [1mCOMMANDS[0m[m
[45;1H       Interactive  format  commands  consist of a keyword followed by zero to four arguments. Only enough characters of the full keyword to uniquely identify the command need be typed. The output of a command is normally sent to the[m
[46;1H       standard output, but optionally the output of individual commands may be sent to a file by appending a [1m>[0m, followed by a file name, to the command line. A number of interactive format commands are executed entirely  within  the[m
[47;1H       [1mntpq[0m program itself and do not result in NTP mode-6 requests being sent to a server. These are described following.[m
[48;1H[m
[49;1H       [1m?[0m [1m[[0m[4mcommand_keyword[24m[1m][0m[m
[50;1H[m
[51;1H       [1mhelp[0m [1m[[0m[4mcommand_keyword[24m[1m][0m[m
[52;1H               A [1m?[0m by itself will print a list of all the command keywords known to [1mntpq[0m. A [1m?[0m followed by a command keyword will print function and usage information about the command.[m
[53;1H[m
[54;1H       [1maddvars[0m [4mname[24m [1m[[0m [1m=[0m [4mvalue[24m[1m][0m [1m[...][0m[m
[55;1H[m
[56;1H       [1mrmvars[0m [4mname[24m [1m[...][0m[m
[57;1H[m
[58;1H       [1mclearvars[0m[m
[59;1H               The arguments to this command consist of a list of items of the form [4mname[24m [1m=[0m [4mvalue[24m, where the [1m=[0m [4mvalue[24m is ignored, and can be omitted in read requests. [1mntpq[0m maintains an internal list in which data to be included in con‚Äê[m
[60;1H               trol messages can be assembled, and sent using the [1mreadlist[0m and [1mwritelist[0m commands described below. The [1maddvars[0m command allows variables and optional values to be added to the list. If more than one variable is  to  be[m
[61;1H               added, the list should be comma-separated and not contain white space. The [1mrmvars[0m command can be used to remove individual variables from the list, while the [1mclearlist[0m command removes all variables from the list.[m
[62;1H[m
[63;1H       [1mcooked[0m  Display server messages in prettyprint format.[m
[64;1H[m
[65;1H       [1mdebug[0m [1mmore[0m [1m|[0m [1mless[0m [1m|[0m [1moff[0m[m
[66;1H[1;1Hntpq(8)                                                                                                  System Manager's Manual                                                                                                  ntpq(8)[m
[2;1H[m
[3;1H[1mNAME[0m[m
[4;1H       ntpq - standard NTP query program[m
[5;1H[m
[6;1H[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
[7;1H       [1mntpq[0m [1m[-46dinp][0m [1m[-c[0m [4mcommand[24m[1m][0m [1m[[0m[4mhost[24m[1m][0m [1m[...][0m[m
[8;1H[m
[9;1H[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
[10;1H       The  [1mntpq[0m utility program is used to monitor NTP daemon [1mntpd[0m operations and determine performance. It uses the standard NTP mode 6 control message formats defined in Appendix B of the NTPv3 specification RFC1305. The same for‚Äê[m
[11;1H       mats are used in NTPv4, although some of the variable names have changed and new ones added. The description on this page is for the NTPv4 variables.[m
[12;1H[m
[13;1H       The program can be run either in interactive mode or controlled using command line arguments. Requests to read and write arbitrary variables can be assembled, with raw and pretty-printed output  options  being  available.  The[m
[14;1H       [1mntpq[0m can also obtain and print a list of [7mpeers[27m in a common format by sending multiple queries to the server.[m
[15;1H[m
[16;1H       If  one  or  more  request  options  is  included on the command line when [1mntpq[0m is executed, each of the requests will be sent to the NTP servers running on each of the hosts given as command line arguments, or on localhost by[m
[17;1H       default. If no request options are given, [1mntpq[0m will attempt to read commands from the standard input and execute these on the NTP server running on the first host given on the command line, again defaulting to  localhost  when[m
[18;1H       no other host is specified. [1mntpq[0m will prompt for commands if the standard input is a terminal device.[m
[19;1H[m
[20;1H       [1mntpq[0m  uses  NTP mode 6 packets to communicate with the NTP server, and hence can be used to query any compatible server on the network which permits it. Note that since NTP is a UDP protocol this communication will be somewhat[m
[21;1H       unreliable, especially over large distances in terms of network topology. [1mntpq[0m makes one attempt to retransmit requests, and will time requests out if the remote host is not heard from within a suitable timeout time.[m
[22;1H[m
[23;1H       Note that in contexts where a host name is expected, a [1m-4[0m qualifier preceding the host name forces DNS resolution to the IPv4 namespace, while a [1m-6[0m qualifier forces DNS resolution to the IPv6 namespace.[m
[24;1H[m
[25;1H       For examples and usage, see the NTP Debugging Techniques page.[m
[26;1H[m
[27;1H       Command line options are described following. Specifying a command line option other than [1m-i[0m or [1m-n[0m will cause the specified query (queries) to be sent to the indicated host(s) immediately. Otherwise, [1mntpq[0m will attempt to  read[m
[28;1H       interactive format commands from the standard input.[m
[29;1H[m
[30;1H       [1m-4[0m      Force DNS resolution of following host names on the command line to the IPv4 namespace.[m
[31;1H[m
[32;1H       [1m-6[0m      Force DNS resolution of following host names on the command line to the IPv6 namespace.[m
[33;1H[m
[34;1H       [1m-c[0m      The following argument is interpreted as an interactive format command and is added to the list of commands to be executed on the specified host(s). Multiple [1m-c[0m options may be given.[m
[35;1H[m
[36;1H       [1m-d[0m      Turn on debugging mode.[m
[37;1H[m
[38;1H       [1m-i[0m      Force [1mntpq[0m to operate in interactive mode. Prompts will be written to the standard output and commands read from the standard input.[m
[39;1H[m
[40;1H       [1m-n[0m      Output all host addresses in dotted-quad numeric format rather than converting to the canonical host names.[m
[41;1H[m
[42;1H       [1m-p[0m      Print a list of the [7mpeers[27m known to the server as well as a summary of their state. This is equivalent to the [1m[7mpeers[27m[0m interactive command.[m
[43;1H[m
[44;1H[1mINTERNAL[0m [1mCOMMANDS[0m[m
[45;1H       Interactive  format  commands  consist of a keyword followed by zero to four arguments. Only enough characters of the full keyword to uniquely identify the command need be typed. The output of a command is normally sent to the[m
[46;1H       standard output, but optionally the output of individual commands may be sent to a file by appending a [1m>[0m, followed by a file name, to the command line. A number of interactive format commands are executed entirely  within  the[m
[47;1H       [1mntpq[0m program itself and do not result in NTP mode-6 requests being sent to a server. These are described following.[m
[48;1H[m
[49;1H       [1m?[0m [1m[[0m[4mcommand_keyword[24m[1m][0m[m
[50;1H[m
[51;1H       [1mhelp[0m [1m[[0m[4mcommand_keyword[24m[1m][0m[m
[52;1H               A [1m?[0m by itself will print a list of all the command keywords known to [1mntpq[0m. A [1m?[0m followed by a command keyword will print function and usage information about the command.[m
[53;1H[m
[54;1H       [1maddvars[0m [4mname[24m [1m[[0m [1m=[0m [4mvalue[24m[1m][0m [1m[...][0m[m
[55;1H[m
[56;1H       [1mrmvars[0m [4mname[24m [1m[...][0m[m
[57;1H[m
[58;1H       [1mclearvars[0m[m
[59;1H               The arguments to this command consist of a list of items of the form [4mname[24m [1m=[0m [4mvalue[24m, where the [1m=[0m [4mvalue[24m is ignored, and can be omitted in read requests. [1mntpq[0m maintains an internal list in which data to be included in con‚Äê[m
[60;1H               trol messages can be assembled, and sent using the [1mreadlist[0m and [1mwritelist[0m commands described below. The [1maddvars[0m command allows variables and optional values to be added to the list. If more than one variable is  to  be[m
[61;1H               added, the list should be comma-separated and not contain white space. The [1mrmvars[0m command can be used to remove individual variables from the list, while the [1mclearlist[0m command removes all variables from the list.[m
[62;1H[m
[63;1H       [1mcooked[0m  Display server messages in prettyprint format.[m
[64;1H[m
[65;1H       [1mdebug[0m [1mmore[0m [1m|[0m [1mless[0m [1m|[0m [1moff[0m[m
[66;1H               Turns internal query program debugging on and off.[m
[m
       [1mdelay[0m [4mmilliseconds[24m[m
               Specify  a  time  interval to be added to timestamps included in requests which require authentication. This is used to enable (unreliable) server reconfiguration over long delay network paths or between machines whose[m
               clocks are unsynchronized. Actually the server does not now require timestamps in authenticated requests, so this command may be obsolete.[m
[m
       [1mhost[0m [4mname[24m[m
               Set the host to which future queries will be sent. The name may be either a DNS name or a numeric address.[m
[m
       [1mhostnames[0m [1m[yes[0m [1m|[0m [1mno][0m[m
               If [1myes[0m is specified, host names are printed in information displays. If [1mno[0m is specified, numeric addresses are printed instead. The default is [1myes[0m, unless modified using the command line [1m-n[0m switch.[m
[m
       [1mkeyid[0m [4mkeyid[24m[m
[7m Manual page ntpq(8) line 18 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K[?1l>[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 16:40:52]# ntppq [K[K[Kq -p
     remote           refid      st t when poll reach   delay   offset  jitter

==============================================================================
 62.210.103.129  .INIT.          16 u    -   64    0    0.000    0.000   0.000
 88.191.250.97   .INIT.          16 u    -   64    0    0.000    0.000   0.000

[?1049h[?1h=ntpq(8)                                                                                                  System Manager's Manual                                                                                                  ntpq(8)[m
[m
[1mNAME[0m[m
       ntpq - standard NTP query program[m
[m
[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
       [1mntpq[0m [1m[-46dinp][0m [1m[-c[0m [4mcommand[24m[1m][0m [1m[[0m[4mhost[24m[1m][0m [1m[...][0m[m
[m
[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
       The  [1mntpq[0m utility program is used to monitor NTP daemon [1mntpd[0m operations and determine performance. It uses the standard NTP mode 6 control message formats defined in Appendix B of the NTPv3 specification RFC1305. The same for‚Äê[m
       mats are used in NTPv4, although some of the variable names have changed and new ones added. The description on this page is for the NTPv4 variables.[m
[m
       The program can be run either in interactive mode or controlled using command line arguments. Requests to read and write arbitrary variables can be assembled, with raw and pretty-printed output  options  being  available.  The[m
       [1mntpq[0m can also obtain and print a list of peers in a common format by sending multiple queries to the server.[m
[m
       If  one  or  more  request  options  is  included on the command line when [1mntpq[0m is executed, each of the requests will be sent to the NTP servers running on each of the hosts given as command line arguments, or on localhost by[m
       default. If no request options are given, [1mntpq[0m will attempt to read commands from the standard input and execute these on the NTP server running on the first host given on the command line, again defaulting to  localhost  when[m
       no other host is specified. [1mntpq[0m will prompt for commands if the standard input is a terminal device.[m
[m
       [1mntpq[0m  uses  NTP mode 6 packets to communicate with the NTP server, and hence can be used to query any compatible server on the network which permits it. Note that since NTP is a UDP protocol this communication will be somewhat[m
       unreliable, especially over large distances in terms of network topology. [1mntpq[0m makes one attempt to retransmit requests, and will time requests out if the remote host is not heard from within a suitable timeout time.[m
[m
       Note that in contexts where a host name is expected, a [1m-4[0m qualifier preceding the host name forces DNS resolution to the IPv4 namespace, while a [1m-6[0m qualifier forces DNS resolution to the IPv6 namespace.[m
[m
       For examples and usage, see the NTP Debugging Techniques page.[m
[m
       Command line options are described following. Specifying a command line option other than [1m-i[0m or [1m-n[0m will cause the specified query (queries) to be sent to the indicated host(s) immediately. Otherwise, [1mntpq[0m will attempt to  read[m
       interactive format commands from the standard input.[m
[m
       [1m-4[0m      Force DNS resolution of following host names on the command line to the IPv4 namespace.[m
[m
       [1m-6[0m      Force DNS resolution of following host names on the command line to the IPv6 namespace.[m
[m
       [1m-c[0m      The following argument is interpreted as an interactive format command and is added to the list of commands to be executed on the specified host(s). Multiple [1m-c[0m options may be given.[m
[m
       [1m-d[0m      Turn on debugging mode.[m
[m
       [1m-i[0m      Force [1mntpq[0m to operate in interactive mode. Prompts will be written to the standard output and commands read from the standard input.[m
[m
       [1m-n[0m      Output all host addresses in dotted-quad numeric format rather than converting to the canonical host names.[m
[m
       [1m-p[0m      Print a list of the peers known to the server as well as a summary of their state. This is equivalent to the [1mpeers[0m interactive command.[m
[m
[1mINTERNAL[0m [1mCOMMANDS[0m[m
       Interactive  format  commands  consist of a keyword followed by zero to four arguments. Only enough characters of the full keyword to uniquely identify the command need be typed. The output of a command is normally sent to the[m
       standard output, but optionally the output of individual commands may be sent to a file by appending a [1m>[0m, followed by a file name, to the command line. A number of interactive format commands are executed entirely  within  the[m
       [1mntpq[0m program itself and do not result in NTP mode-6 requests being sent to a server. These are described following.[m
[m
       [1m?[0m [1m[[0m[4mcommand_keyword[24m[1m][0m[m
[m
       [1mhelp[0m [1m[[0m[4mcommand_keyword[24m[1m][0m[m
               A [1m?[0m by itself will print a list of all the command keywords known to [1mntpq[0m. A [1m?[0m followed by a command keyword will print function and usage information about the command.[m
[m
       [1maddvars[0m [4mname[24m [1m[[0m [1m=[0m [4mvalue[24m[1m][0m [1m[...][0m[m
[m
       [1mrmvars[0m [4mname[24m [1m[...][0m[m
[m
       [1mclearvars[0m[m
               The arguments to this command consist of a list of items of the form [4mname[24m [1m=[0m [4mvalue[24m, where the [1m=[0m [4mvalue[24m is ignored, and can be omitted in read requests. [1mntpq[0m maintains an internal list in which data to be included in con‚Äê[m
               trol messages can be assembled, and sent using the [1mreadlist[0m and [1mwritelist[0m commands described below. The [1maddvars[0m command allows variables and optional values to be added to the list. If more than one variable is  to  be[m
               added, the list should be comma-separated and not contain white space. The [1mrmvars[0m command can be used to remove individual variables from the list, while the [1mclearlist[0m command removes all variables from the list.[m
[m
       [1mcooked[0m  Display server messages in prettyprint format.[m
[m
       [1mdebug[0m [1mmore[0m [1m|[0m [1mless[0m [1m|[0m [1moff[0m[m
[7m Manual page ntpq(8) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[Kpp[Kee[Kee[Krr[K[1;1Hntpq(8)                                                                                                  System Manager's Manual                                                                                                  ntpq(8)[m

[30;1H       [1m-4[0m      Force DNS resolution of following host names on the command line to the IPv4 namespace.[m
[31;1H[m
[32;1H       [1m-6[0m      Force DNS resolution of following host names on the command line to the IPv6 namespace.[m
[33;1H[m
[34;1H       [1m-c[0m      The following argument is interpreted as an interactive format command and is added to the list of commands to be executed on the specified host(s). Multiple [1m-c[0m options may be given.[m
[35;1H[m
[36;1H       [1m-d[0m      Turn on debugging mode.[m
[37;1H[m
[38;1H       [1m-i[0m      Force [1mntpq[0m to operate in interactive mode. Prompts will be written to the standard output and commands read from the standard input.[m
[39;1H[m
[40;1H       [1m-n[0m      Output all host addresses in dotted-quad numeric format rather than converting to the canonical host names.[m
[41;1H[m
[42;1H       [1m-p[0m      Print a list of the peers known to the server as well as a summary of their state. This is equivalent to the [1mpeers[0m interactive command.[m
[43;1H[m
[44;1H[1mINTERNAL[0m [1mCOMMANDS[0m[m
[45;1H       Interactive  format  commands  consist of a keyword followed by zero to four arguments. Only enough characters of the full keyword to uniquely identify the command need be typed. The output of a command is normally sent to the[m
[46;1H       standard output, but optionally the output of individual commands may be sent to a file by appending a [1m>[0m, followed by a file name, to the command line. A number of interactive format commands are executed entirely  within  the[m
[47;1H       [1mntpq[0m program itself and do not result in NTP mode-6 requests being sent to a server. These are described following.[m
[48;1H[m
[49;1H       [1m?[0m [1m[[0m[4mcommand_keyword[24m[1m][0m[m
[50;1H[m
[51;1H       [1mhelp[0m [1m[[0m[4mcommand_keyword[24m[1m][0m[m
[52;1H               A [1m?[0m by itself will print a list of all the command keywords known to [1mntpq[0m. A [1m?[0m followed by a command keyword will print function and usage information about the command.[m
[53;1H[m
[54;1H       [1maddvars[0m [4mname[24m [1m[[0m [1m=[0m [4mvalue[24m[1m][0m [1m[...][0m[m
[55;1H[m
[56;1H       [1mrmvars[0m [4mname[24m [1m[...][0m[m
[57;1H[m
[58;1H       [1mclearvars[0m[m
[59;1H               The arguments to this command consist of a list of items of the form [4mname[24m [1m=[0m [4mvalue[24m, where the [1m=[0m [4mvalue[24m is ignored, and can be omitted in read requests. [1mntpq[0m maintains an internal list in which data to be included in con‚Äê[m
[60;1H               trol messages can be assembled, and sent using the [1mreadlist[0m and [1mwritelist[0m commands described below. The [1maddvars[0m command allows variables and optional values to be added to the list. If more than one variable is  to  be[m
[61;1H               added, the list should be comma-separated and not contain white space. The [1mrmvars[0m command can be used to remove individual variables from the list, while the [1mclearlist[0m command removes all variables from the list.[m
[62;1H[m
[63;1H       [1mcooked[0m  Display server messages in prettyprint format.[m
[64;1H[m
[65;1H       [1mdebug[0m [1mmore[0m [1m|[0m [1mless[0m [1m|[0m [1moff[0m[m
[66;1H[1;1Hntpq(8)                                                                                                  System Manager's Manual                                                                                                  ntpq(8)[m
[2;1H[m
[3;1H[1mNAME[0m[m
[4;1H       ntpq - standard NTP query program[m
[5;1H[m
[6;1H[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
[7;1H       [1mntpq[0m [1m[-46dinp][0m [1m[-c[0m [4mcommand[24m[1m][0m [1m[[0m[4mhost[24m[1m][0m [1m[...][0m[m
[8;1H[m
[9;1H[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
[10;1H       The  [1mntpq[0m utility program is used to monitor NTP daemon [1mntpd[0m operations and determine performance. It uses the standard NTP mode 6 control message formats defined in Appendix B of the NTPv3 specification RFC1305. The same for‚Äê[m
[11;1H       mats are used in NTPv4, although some of the variable names have changed and new ones added. The description on this page is for the NTPv4 variables.[m
[12;1H[m
[13;1H       The program can be run either in interactive mode or controlled using command line arguments. Requests to read and write arbitrary variables can be assembled, with raw and pretty-printed output  options  being  available.  The[m
[14;1H       [1mntpq[0m can also obtain and print a list of [7mpeer[27ms in a common format by sending multiple queries to the server.[m
[15;1H[m
[16;1H       If  one  or  more  request  options  is  included on the command line when [1mntpq[0m is executed, each of the requests will be sent to the NTP servers running on each of the hosts given as command line arguments, or on localhost by[m
[17;1H       default. If no request options are given, [1mntpq[0m will attempt to read commands from the standard input and execute these on the NTP server running on the first host given on the command line, again defaulting to  localhost  when[m
[18;1H       no other host is specified. [1mntpq[0m will prompt for commands if the standard input is a terminal device.[m
[19;1H[m
[20;1H       [1mntpq[0m  uses  NTP mode 6 packets to communicate with the NTP server, and hence can be used to query any compatible server on the network which permits it. Note that since NTP is a UDP protocol this communication will be somewhat[m
[21;1H       unreliable, especially over large distances in terms of network topology. [1mntpq[0m makes one attempt to retransmit requests, and will time requests out if the remote host is not heard from within a suitable timeout time.[m
[22;1H[m
[23;1H       Note that in contexts where a host name is expected, a [1m-4[0m qualifier preceding the host name forces DNS resolution to the IPv4 namespace, while a [1m-6[0m qualifier forces DNS resolution to the IPv6 namespace.[m
[24;1H[m
[25;1H       For examples and usage, see the NTP Debugging Techniques page.[m
[26;1H[m
[27;1H       Command line options are described following. Specifying a command line option other than [1m-i[0m or [1m-n[0m will cause the specified query (queries) to be sent to the indicated host(s) immediately. Otherwise, [1mntpq[0m will attempt to  read[m
[28;1H       interactive format commands from the standard input.[m
[29;1H[m
[30;1H       [1m-4[0m      Force DNS resolution of following host names on the command line to the IPv4 namespace.[m
[31;1H[m
[32;1H       [1m-6[0m      Force DNS resolution of following host names on the command line to the IPv6 namespace.[m
[33;1H[m
[34;1H       [1m-c[0m      The following argument is interpreted as an interactive format command and is added to the list of commands to be executed on the specified host(s). Multiple [1m-c[0m options may be given.[m
[35;1H[m
[36;1H       [1m-d[0m      Turn on debugging mode.[m
[37;1H[m
[38;1H       [1m-i[0m      Force [1mntpq[0m to operate in interactive mode. Prompts will be written to the standard output and commands read from the standard input.[m
[39;1H[m
[40;1H       [1m-n[0m      Output all host addresses in dotted-quad numeric format rather than converting to the canonical host names.[m
[41;1H[m
[42;1H       [1m-p[0m      Print a list of the [7mpeer[27ms known to the server as well as a summary of their state. This is equivalent to the [1m[7mpeer[27m[0m[1ms[0m interactive command.[m
[43;1H[m
[44;1H[1mINTERNAL[0m [1mCOMMANDS[0m[m
[45;1H       Interactive  format  commands  consist of a keyword followed by zero to four arguments. Only enough characters of the full keyword to uniquely identify the command need be typed. The output of a command is normally sent to the[m
[46;1H       standard output, but optionally the output of individual commands may be sent to a file by appending a [1m>[0m, followed by a file name, to the command line. A number of interactive format commands are executed entirely  within  the[m
[47;1H       [1mntpq[0m program itself and do not result in NTP mode-6 requests being sent to a server. These are described following.[m
[48;1H[m
[49;1H       [1m?[0m [1m[[0m[4mcommand_keyword[24m[1m][0m[m
[50;1H[m
[51;1H       [1mhelp[0m [1m[[0m[4mcommand_keyword[24m[1m][0m[m
[52;1H               A [1m?[0m by itself will print a list of all the command keywords known to [1mntpq[0m. A [1m?[0m followed by a command keyword will print function and usage information about the command.[m
[53;1H[m
[54;1H       [1maddvars[0m [4mname[24m [1m[[0m [1m=[0m [4mvalue[24m[1m][0m [1m[...][0m[m
[55;1H[m
[56;1H       [1mrmvars[0m [4mname[24m [1m[...][0m[m
[57;1H[m
[58;1H       [1mclearvars[0m[m
[59;1H               The arguments to this command consist of a list of items of the form [4mname[24m [1m=[0m [4mvalue[24m, where the [1m=[0m [4mvalue[24m is ignored, and can be omitted in read requests. [1mntpq[0m maintains an internal list in which data to be included in con‚Äê[m
[60;1H               trol messages can be assembled, and sent using the [1mreadlist[0m and [1mwritelist[0m commands described below. The [1maddvars[0m command allows variables and optional values to be added to the list. If more than one variable is  to  be[m
[61;1H               added, the list should be comma-separated and not contain white space. The [1mrmvars[0m command can be used to remove individual variables from the list, while the [1mclearlist[0m command removes all variables from the list.[m
[62;1H[m
[63;1H       [1mcooked[0m  Display server messages in prettyprint format.[m
[64;1H[m
[65;1H       [1mdebug[0m [1mmore[0m [1m|[0m [1mless[0m [1m|[0m [1moff[0m[m
[66;1H               Turns internal query program debugging on and off.[m
[m
       [1mdelay[0m [4mmilliseconds[24m[m
               Specify  a  time  interval to be added to timestamps included in requests which require authentication. This is used to enable (unreliable) server reconfiguration over long delay network paths or between machines whose[m
               clocks are unsynchronized. Actually the server does not now require timestamps in authenticated requests, so this command may be obsolete.[m
[m
       [1mhost[0m [4mname[24m[m
               Set the host to which future queries will be sent. The name may be either a DNS name or a numeric address.[m
[m
       [1mhostnames[0m [1m[yes[0m [1m|[0m [1mno][0m[m
               If [1myes[0m is specified, host names are printed in information displays. If [1mno[0m is specified, numeric addresses are printed instead. The default is [1myes[0m, unless modified using the command line [1m-n[0m switch.[m
[m
       [1mkeyid[0m [4mkeyid[24m[m
[7m Manual page ntpq(8) line 18 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[K               This command specifies the key number to be used to authenticate configuration requests. This must correspond to a key number the server has been configured to use for this purpose.[m
[m
       [1mntpversion[0m [1m1[0m [1m|[0m [1m2[0m [1m|[0m [1m3[0m [1m|[0m [1m4[0m[m
               Sets the NTP version number which [1mntpq[0m claims in packets. Defaults to 2, Note that mode-6 control messages (and modes, for that matter) didn't exist in NTP version 1.[m
[m
       [1mpasswd[0m  This command prompts for a password to authenticate configuration requests. The password must correspond to the key configured for NTP server for this purpose.[m
[m
       [1mquit[0m    Exit [1mntpq[0m.[m
[m
       [1mraw[0m     Display server messages as received and without reformatting.[m
[m
       [1mtimeout[0m [4mmilliseconds[24m[m
               Specify a timeout period for responses to server queries. The default is about 5000 milliseconds. Note that since [1mntpq[0m retries each query once after a timeout, the total waiting time for a timeout  will  be  twice  the[m
               timeout value set.[m
[m
[1mCONTROL[0m [1mMESSAGE[0m [1mCOMMANDS[0m[m
       Association  IDs are used to identify system, [7mpeer[27m and clock variables. System variables are assigned an association ID of zero and system name space, while each association is assigned a nonzero association ID and [7mpeer[27m names‚Äê[m
       pace. Most control commands send a single mode-6 message to the server and expect a single response message. The exceptions are the [1m[7mpeer[27m[0m[1ms[0m command, which sends a series of messages, and  the  [1mmreadlist[0m  and  [1mmreadvar[0m  commands,[m
       which iterate over a range of associations.[m
[m
       [1massociations[0m[m
               Display a list of mobilized associations in the form [1mind[0m [1massid[0m [1mstatus[0m [1mconf[0m [1mreach[0m [1mauth[0m [1mcondition[0m [1mlast_event[0m [1mcnt[0m[m
[m
               ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î¨‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê[m
               ‚îÇ                            Variable                                             ‚îÇ                                           Description                                                                                 ‚îÇ[m
               ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îº‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î§[m
               ‚îÇ                            [1mind[0m                                                  ‚îÇ                                           index on this list                                                                          ‚îÇ[m
               ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îº‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î§[m
[7m Manual page ntpq(8) line 47 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[K               ‚îÇ                            [1massid[0m                                                ‚îÇ                                           association ID                                                                              ‚îÇ[m
               ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îº‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î§[m
               ‚îÇ                            [1mstatus[0m                                               ‚îÇ                                           [7mpeer[27m status word                                                                            ‚îÇ[m
               ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îº‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î§[m
               ‚îÇ                            [1mconf[0m                                                 ‚îÇ                                           [1myes[0m: persistent, [1mno[0m: ephemeral                                                              ‚îÇ[m
               ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îº‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î§[m
               ‚îÇ                            [1mreach[0m                                                ‚îÇ                                           [1myes[0m: reachable, [1mno[0m: unreachable                                                             ‚îÇ[m

               ‚îÇ                            [1mauth[0m                                                 ‚îÇ                                           [1mok[0m, [1myes[0m, [1mbad[0m and [1mnone[0m                                                                       ‚îÇ[m
               ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îº‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î§[m
               ‚îÇ                            [1mcondition[0m                                            ‚îÇ                                           selection status (see the [1mselect[0m field of the [7mpeer[27m status word)                             ‚îÇ[m
