[?1049h[?1h=ntp_acc(5)                                                                                                 File Formats Manual                                                                                                 ntp_acc(5)[m
[m
[1mNAME[0m[m
       ntp_acc - Access Control Options[m
[m
[1mACCESS[0m [1mCONTROL[0m [1mSUPPORT[0m[m
       The  [1mntpd[0m  daemon implements a general purpose access control list (ACL) containing address/match entries sorted first by increasing address values and then by increasing mask values. A match occurs when the bitwise AND of the[m
       mask and the packet source address is equal to the bitwise AND of the mask and address in the list. The list is searched in order with the last match found defining the restriction flags associated with the entry.[m
[m
       An example may clarify how it works. Our campus has two class-B networks, 128.4 for the ECE and CIS departments and 128.175 for the rest of campus. Let's assume (not true!) that subnet  128.4.1  homes  critical  services  like[m
       class rosters and spread sheets. A suitable ACL might be[m
[m
       restrict default nopeer                      # deny new associations[m
       restrict 128.175.0.0 mask 255.255.0.0        # allow campus access[m
       restrict 128.4.0.0 mask 255.255.0.0 none     # allow ECE and CIS access[m
       restrict 128.4.1.0 mask 255.255.255.0 notrust # require authentication on subnet 1[m
       restrict time.nist.gov                            # allow access[m
[m
       While  this  facility  may  be  useful  for  keeping unwanted, broken or malicious clients from congesting innocent servers, it should not be considered an alternative to the NTP authentication facilities. Source address based[m
       restrictions are easily circumvented by a determined cracker.[m
[m
[1mACCESS[0m [1mCONTROL[0m [1mCOMMANDS[0m[m
       [1mdiscard[0m [1m[[0m [1maverage[0m [4mavg[24m [1m][[0m [1mminimum[0m [4mmin[24m [1m][0m [1m[[0m [1mmonitor[0m [4mprob[24m [1m][0m[m
               Set the parameters of the rate control facility which protects the server from client abuse. If the [1mlimited[0m flag is present in the ACL, packets that violate these limits are discarded. If in addition the  [1mkod[0m  restric‚Äê[m
               tion is present, a kiss-o'-death packet is returned.[m
[m
               [1maverage[0m [4mavg[24m[m
                       Specify the minimum average interpacket spacing (minimum average headway time) in log2 s with default 3.[m
[m
               [1mminimum[0m [4mmin[24m[m
                       Specify the minimum interpacket spacing (guard time) in log2 s with default 1.[m
[m
               [1mmonitor[0m Specify the probability of discard for packets that overflow the rate-control window. This is a performance optimization for servers with aggregate arrivals of 1000 packets per second or more.[m
[m
       [1mrestrict[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[mask[0m [4mmask[24m[1m][0m [1m[[0m[4mflag[24m[1m][...][0m[m
               The  [4maddress[24m  argument expressed in dotted-quad form is the address of a host or network. Alternatively, the [4maddress[24m argument can be a valid host DNS name, but it must be resolvable at the time when [1mntpd[0m is started and[m
               if it's resolved to multiple addresses, only the first address will be added to the list. The [4mmask[24m argument expressed in dotted-quad form defaults to 255.255.255.255, meaning that the [4maddress[24m is treated as the  address[m
               of  an  individual host. A default entry (address 0.0.0.0, mask 0.0.0.0) is always included and is always the first entry in the list. Note that the text string [1mdefault[0m, with no mask option, may be used to indicate the[m
               default entry.  Some flags have the effect to deny service, some have the effect to enable service and some are conditioned by other flags. The flags. are not orthogonal, in that more restrictive flags will often  make[m
               less  restrictive ones redundant. The flags that deny service are classed in two categories, those that restrict time service and those that restrict informational queries and attempts to do run-time reconfiguration of[m
               the server. One or more of the following flags may be specified:[m
[m
               [1mflake[0m   Discard received NTP packets with probability 0.1; that is, on average drop one packet in ten. This is for testing and amusement. The name comes from Bob Braden's [4mflakeway[24m, which once did a  similar  thing  for[m
                       early Internet testing.[m
[m
               [1mignore[0m  Deny packets of all kinds, including [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries.[m
[m
               [1mkod[0m     Send  a  kiss-o'-death (KoD) packet if the [1mlimited[0m flag is present and a packet violates the rate limits established by the [1mdiscard[0m command. KoD packets are themselves rate limited for each source address sepa‚Äê[m
                       rately. If this flag is not present, packets that violate the rate limits are discarded.[m
[m
               [1mlimited[0m Deny time service if the packet violates the rate limits established by the [1mdiscard[0m command. This does not apply to [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries.[m
[m
               [1mlowpriotrap[0m[m
                       Declare traps set by matching hosts to be low priority. The number of traps a server can maintain is limited (the current limit is 3). Traps are usually assigned on a first come, first served basis, with  later[m
                       trap requestors being denied service. This flag modifies the assignment algorithm by allowing low priority traps to be overridden by later requests for normal priority traps.[m
[m
               [1mmssntp[0m  Enable  Microsoft  Windows  MS-SNTP  authentication  using Active Directory services. Note: Potential users should be aware that these services involve a TCP connection to another process that could potentially[m
                       block, denying services to other users. Therefore, this flag should be used only for a dedicated server with no clients other than MS-SNTP.[m
[m
               [1mnomodify[0m[m
                       Deny [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries which attempt to modify the state of the server (i.e., run time reconfiguration). Queries which return information are permitted.[m
[m
               [1mnoquery[0m Deny [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries. Time service is not affected.[m
[m
               [1mnopeer[0m  Deny packets that might mobilize an association unless authenticated. This includes broadcast, symmetric-active and manycast server packets when a configured association does not exist. Note that this flag does[m
[7m Manual page ntp_acc(5) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K[?1l>[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 16:54:58]# man ntp_accping 88.191.250.9762.210.103.129^C
]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 16:55:00]# less /etc/ntp.conf 
[?1049h[?1h=# For more information about this file, see the man pages
# ntp.conf(5), ntp_acc(5), ntp_auth(5), ntp_clock(5), ntp_misc(5), ntp_mon(5).

driftfile /var/lib/ntp/drift

# Permit time synchronization with our time source, but do not
# permit the source to query or modify the service on this system.
restrict default nomodify notrap nopeer noquery

# Permit all access over the loopback interface.  This could
# be tightened as well, but to do so would effect some of
# the administrative functions.
restrict 127.0.0.1 
restrict ::1

# Hosts on local network are less restricted.
#restrict 192.168.1.0 mask 255.255.255.0 nomodify notrap

# Use public servers from the pool.ntp.org project.
# Please consider joining the pool (http://www.pool.ntp.org/join.html).
#server 0.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
#server 1.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
#server 2.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
#server 3.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst

server 62.210.103.129 iburst
server 88.191.250.97 iburst

#broadcast 192.168.1.255 autokey        # broadcast server
#broadcastclient                        # broadcast client
#broadcast 224.0.1.1 autokey            # multicast server
#multicastclient 224.0.1.1              # multicast client
#manycastserver 239.255.254.254         # manycast server
#manycastclient 239.255.254.254 autokey # manycast client

# Enable public key cryptography.
#crypto

includefile /etc/ntp/crypto/pw

# Key file containing the keys and key identifiers used when operating
# with symmetric key cryptography. 
keys /etc/ntp/keys

# Specify the key identifiers which are trusted.
#trustedkey 4 8 42

# Specify the key identifier to use with the ntpdc utility.
#requestkey 8

# Specify the key identifier to use with the ntpq utility.
#controlkey 8

# Enable writing of statistics records.
#statistics clockstats cryptostats loopstats peerstats

# Disable the monitoring facility to prevent amplification attacks using ntpdc
# monlist command when default restrict does not include the noquery flag. See
# CVE-2013-5211 for more details.
# Note: Monitoring will not be disabled with the limited restriction flag.
disable monitor
[7m/etc/ntp.conf (END)[27m[K[K[?1l>[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 16:55:17]# less /etc/ntp.conf [8Pman ntp_acc
[?1049h[?1h=ntp_acc(5)                                                                                                 File Formats Manual                                                                                                 ntp_acc(5)[m
[m
[1mNAME[0m[m
       ntp_acc - Access Control Options[m
[m
[1mACCESS[0m [1mCONTROL[0m [1mSUPPORT[0m[m
       The  [1mntpd[0m  daemon implements a general purpose access control list (ACL) containing address/match entries sorted first by increasing address values and then by increasing mask values. A match occurs when the bitwise AND of the[m
       mask and the packet source address is equal to the bitwise AND of the mask and address in the list. The list is searched in order with the last match found defining the restriction flags associated with the entry.[m
[m
       An example may clarify how it works. Our campus has two class-B networks, 128.4 for the ECE and CIS departments and 128.175 for the rest of campus. Let's assume (not true!) that subnet  128.4.1  homes  critical  services  like[m
       class rosters and spread sheets. A suitable ACL might be[m
[m
       restrict default nopeer                      # deny new associations[m
       restrict 128.175.0.0 mask 255.255.0.0        # allow campus access[m
       restrict 128.4.0.0 mask 255.255.0.0 none     # allow ECE and CIS access[m
       restrict 128.4.1.0 mask 255.255.255.0 notrust # require authentication on subnet 1[m
       restrict time.nist.gov                            # allow access[m
[m
       While  this  facility  may  be  useful  for  keeping unwanted, broken or malicious clients from congesting innocent servers, it should not be considered an alternative to the NTP authentication facilities. Source address based[m
       restrictions are easily circumvented by a determined cracker.[m
[m
[1mACCESS[0m [1mCONTROL[0m [1mCOMMANDS[0m[m
       [1mdiscard[0m [1m[[0m [1maverage[0m [4mavg[24m [1m][[0m [1mminimum[0m [4mmin[24m [1m][0m [1m[[0m [1mmonitor[0m [4mprob[24m [1m][0m[m
               Set the parameters of the rate control facility which protects the server from client abuse. If the [1mlimited[0m flag is present in the ACL, packets that violate these limits are discarded. If in addition the  [1mkod[0m  restric‚Äê[m
               tion is present, a kiss-o'-death packet is returned.[m
[m
               [1maverage[0m [4mavg[24m[m
                       Specify the minimum average interpacket spacing (minimum average headway time) in log2 s with default 3.[m
[m
               [1mminimum[0m [4mmin[24m[m
                       Specify the minimum interpacket spacing (guard time) in log2 s with default 1.[m
[m
               [1mmonitor[0m Specify the probability of discard for packets that overflow the rate-control window. This is a performance optimization for servers with aggregate arrivals of 1000 packets per second or more.[m
[m
       [1mrestrict[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[mask[0m [4mmask[24m[1m][0m [1m[[0m[4mflag[24m[1m][...][0m[m
               The  [4maddress[24m  argument expressed in dotted-quad form is the address of a host or network. Alternatively, the [4maddress[24m argument can be a valid host DNS name, but it must be resolvable at the time when [1mntpd[0m is started and[m
               if it's resolved to multiple addresses, only the first address will be added to the list. The [4mmask[24m argument expressed in dotted-quad form defaults to 255.255.255.255, meaning that the [4maddress[24m is treated as the  address[m
               of  an  individual host. A default entry (address 0.0.0.0, mask 0.0.0.0) is always included and is always the first entry in the list. Note that the text string [1mdefault[0m, with no mask option, may be used to indicate the[m
               default entry.  Some flags have the effect to deny service, some have the effect to enable service and some are conditioned by other flags. The flags. are not orthogonal, in that more restrictive flags will often  make[m
               less  restrictive ones redundant. The flags that deny service are classed in two categories, those that restrict time service and those that restrict informational queries and attempts to do run-time reconfiguration of[m
               the server. One or more of the following flags may be specified:[m
[m
               [1mflake[0m   Discard received NTP packets with probability 0.1; that is, on average drop one packet in ten. This is for testing and amusement. The name comes from Bob Braden's [4mflakeway[24m, which once did a  similar  thing  for[m
                       early Internet testing.[m
[m
               [1mignore[0m  Deny packets of all kinds, including [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries.[m
[m
               [1mkod[0m     Send  a  kiss-o'-death (KoD) packet if the [1mlimited[0m flag is present and a packet violates the rate limits established by the [1mdiscard[0m command. KoD packets are themselves rate limited for each source address sepa‚Äê[m
                       rately. If this flag is not present, packets that violate the rate limits are discarded.[m
[m
               [1mlimited[0m Deny time service if the packet violates the rate limits established by the [1mdiscard[0m command. This does not apply to [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries.[m
[m
               [1mlowpriotrap[0m[m
                       Declare traps set by matching hosts to be low priority. The number of traps a server can maintain is limited (the current limit is 3). Traps are usually assigned on a first come, first served basis, with  later[m
                       trap requestors being denied service. This flag modifies the assignment algorithm by allowing low priority traps to be overridden by later requests for normal priority traps.[m
[m
               [1mmssntp[0m  Enable  Microsoft  Windows  MS-SNTP  authentication  using Active Directory services. Note: Potential users should be aware that these services involve a TCP connection to another process that could potentially[m
                       block, denying services to other users. Therefore, this flag should be used only for a dedicated server with no clients other than MS-SNTP.[m
[m
               [1mnomodify[0m[m
                       Deny [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries which attempt to modify the state of the server (i.e., run time reconfiguration). Queries which return information are permitted.[m
[m
               [1mnoquery[0m Deny [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries. Time service is not affected.[m
[m
               [1mnopeer[0m  Deny packets that might mobilize an association unless authenticated. This includes broadcast, symmetric-active and manycast server packets when a configured association does not exist. Note that this flag does[m
[7m Manual page ntp_acc(5) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[K::[K::[K11[K[1;1Hntp_acc(5)                                                                                                 File Formats Manual                                                                                                 ntp_acc(5)[m
[2;1H[m
[3;1H[1mNAME[0m[m
[4;1H       ntp_acc - Access Control Options[m
[5;1H[m
[6;1H[1mACCESS[0m [1mCONTROL[0m [1mSUPPORT[0m[m
[7;1H       The  [1mntpd[0m  daemon implements a general purpose access control list (ACL) containing address/match entries sorted first by increasing address values and then by increasing mask values. A match occurs when the bitwise AND of the[m
[8;1H       mask and the packet source address is equal to the bitwise AND of the mask and address in the list. The list is searched in order with the last match found defining the restriction flags associated with the entry.[m
[9;1H[m
[10;1H       An example may clarify how it works. Our campus has two class-B networks, 128.4 for the ECE and CIS departments and 128.175 for the rest of campus. Let's assume (not true!) that subnet  128.4.1  homes  critical  services  like[m
[11;1H       class rosters and spread sheets. A suitable ACL might be[m
[12;1H[m
[13;1H       restrict default nopeer                      # deny new associations[m
[14;1H       restrict 128.175.0.0 mask 255.255.0.0        # allow campus access[m
[15;1H       restrict 128.4.0.0 mask 255.255.0.0 none     # allow ECE and CIS access[m
[16;1H       restrict 128.4.1.0 mask 255.255.255.0 notrust # require authentication on subnet 1[m
[17;1H       restrict time.nist.gov                            # allow access[m
[18;1H[m
[19;1H       While  this  facility  may  be  useful  for  keeping unwanted, broken or malicious clients from congesting innocent servers, it should not be considered an alternative to the NTP authentication facilities. Source address based[m
[20;1H       restrictions are easily circumvented by a determined cracker.[m
[21;1H[m
[22;1H[1mACCESS[0m [1mCONTROL[0m [1mCOMMANDS[0m[m
[23;1H       [1mdiscard[0m [1m[[0m [1maverage[0m [4mavg[24m [1m][[0m [1mminimum[0m [4mmin[24m [1m][0m [1m[[0m [1mmonitor[0m [4mprob[24m [1m][0m[m
[24;1H               Set the parameters of the rate control facility which protects the server from client abuse. If the [1mlimited[0m flag is present in the ACL, packets that violate these limits are discarded. If in addition the  [1mkod[0m  restric‚Äê[m
[25;1H               tion is present, a kiss-o'-death packet is returned.[m
[26;1H[m
[27;1H               [1maverage[0m [4mavg[24m[m
[28;1H                       Specify the minimum average interpacket spacing (minimum average headway time) in log2 s with default 3.[m

[30;1H               [1mminimum[0m [4mmin[24m[m
[31;1H                       Specify the minimum interpacket spacing (guard time) in log2 s with default 1.[m
[32;1H[m
[33;1H               [1mmonitor[0m Specify the probability of discard for packets that overflow the rate-control window. This is a performance optimization for servers with aggregate arrivals of 1000 packets per second or more.[m
[34;1H[m
[35;1H       [1mrestrict[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[mask[0m [4mmask[24m[1m][0m [1m[[0m[4mflag[24m[1m][...][0m[m
[36;1H               The  [4maddress[24m  argument expressed in dotted-quad form is the address of a host or network. Alternatively, the [4maddress[24m argument can be a valid host DNS name, but it must be resolvable at the time when [1mntpd[0m is started and[m

[38;1H               of  an  individual host. A default entry (address 0.0.0.0, mask 0.0.0.0) is always included and is always the first entry in the list. Note that the text string [1mdefault[0m, with no mask option, may be used to indicate the[m
[39;1H               default entry.  Some flags have the effect to deny service, some have the effect to enable service and some are conditioned by other flags. The flags. are not orthogonal, in that more restrictive flags will often  make[m
[40;1H               less  restrictive ones redundant. The flags that deny service are classed in two categories, those that restrict time service and those that restrict informational queries and attempts to do run-time reconfiguration of[m
[41;1H               the server. One or more of the following flags may be specified:[m
[42;1H[m
[43;1H               [1mflake[0m   Discard received NTP packets with probability 0.1; that is, on average drop one packet in ten. This is for testing and amusement. The name comes from Bob Braden's [4mflakeway[24m, which once did a  similar  thing  for[m
[44;1H                       early Internet testing.[m
[45;1H[m
[46;1H               [1mignore[0m  Deny packets of all kinds, including [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries.[m

[49;1H                       rately. If this flag is not present, packets that violate the rate limits are discarded.[m
[50;1H[m
[51;1H               [1mlimited[0m Deny time service if the packet violates the rate limits established by the [1mdiscard[0m command. This does not apply to [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries.[m
[52;1H[m

[2;1H[m
[3;1H[1mNAME[0m[m
[4;1H       ntp_acc - Access Control Options[m
[5;1H[m
[6;1H[1mACCESS[0m [1mCONTROL[0m [1mSUPPORT[0m[m
[7;1H       The  [1mntpd[0m  daemon implements a general purpose access control list (ACL) containing address/match entries sorted first by increasing address values and then by increasing mask values. A match occurs when the bitwise AND of the[m
[8;1H       mask and the packet source address is equal to the bitwise AND of the mask and address in the list. The list is searched in order with the last match found defining the restriction flags associated with the entry.[m
[9;1H[m
[10;1H       An example may clarify how it works. Our campus has two class-B networks, 128.4 for the ECE and CIS departments and 128.175 for the rest of campus. Let's assume (not true!) that subnet  128.4.1  homes  critical  services  like[m
[11;1H       class rosters and spread sheets. A suitable ACL might be[m
[12;1H[m
[13;1H       restrict default nopeer                      # deny new associations[m
[14;1H       restrict 128.175.0.0 mask 255.255.0.0        # allow campus access[m
[15;1H       restrict 128.4.0.0 mask 255.255.0.0 none     # allow ECE and CIS access[m
[16;1H       restrict 128.4.1.0 mask 255.255.255.0 notrust # require authentication on subnet 1[m
[17;1H       restrict time.nist.gov                            # allow access[m
[18;1H[m
[19;1H       While  this  facility  may  be  useful  for  keeping unwanted, broken or malicious clients from congesting innocent servers, it should not be considered an alternative to the NTP authentication facilities. Source address based[m
[20;1H       restrictions are easily circumvented by a determined cracker.[m
[21;1H[m
[22;1H[1mACCESS[0m [1mCONTROL[0m [1mCOMMANDS[0m[m
[23;1H       [1mdiscard[0m [1m[[0m [1maverage[0m [4mavg[24m [1m][[0m [1mminimum[0m [4mmin[24m [1m][0m [1m[[0m [1mmonitor[0m [4mprob[24m [1m][0m[m
[24;1H               Set the parameters of the rate control facility which protects the server from client abuse. If the [1mlimited[0m flag is present in the ACL, packets that violate these limits are discarded. If in addition the  [1mkod[0m  restric‚Äê[m
[25;1H               tion is present, a kiss-o'-death packet is returned.[m
[26;1H[m
[27;1H               [1maverage[0m [4mavg[24m[m
[28;1H                       Specify the minimum average interpacket spacing (minimum average headway time) in log2 s with default 3.[m
[29;1H[m

[31;1H                       Specify the minimum interpacket spacing (guard time) in log2 s with default 1.[m
[32;1H[m
[33;1H               [1mmonitor[0m Specify the probability of discard for packets that overflow the rate-control window. This is a performance optimization for servers with aggregate arrivals of 1000 packets per second or more.[m
[34;1H[m
[35;1H       [1mrestrict[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[mask[0m [4mmask[24m[1m][0m [1m[[0m[4mflag[24m[1m][...][0m[m
[36;1H               The  [4maddress[24m  argument expressed in dotted-quad form is the address of a host or network. Alternatively, the [4maddress[24m argument can be a valid host DNS name, but it must be resolvable at the time when [1mntpd[0m is started and[m

[38;1H               of  an  individual host. A default entry (address 0.0.0.0, mask 0.0.0.0) is always included and is always the first entry in the list. Note that the text string [1mdefault[0m, with no mask option, may be used to indicate the[m
[39;1H               default entry.  Some flags have the effect to deny service, some have the effect to enable service and some are conditioned by other flags. The flags. are not orthogonal, in that more restrictive flags will often  make[m

[45;1H[m
[46;1H               [1mignore[0m  Deny packets of all kinds, including [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries.[m
[47;1H[m
[48;1H               [1mkod[0m     Send  a  kiss-o'-death (KoD) packet if the [1mlimited[0m flag is present and a packet violates the rate limits established by the [1mdiscard[0m command. KoD packets are themselves rate limited for each source address sepa‚Äê[m
[49;1H                       rately. If this flag is not present, packets that violate the rate limits are discarded.[m
[50;1H[m
[51;1H               [1mlimited[0m Deny time service if the packet violates the rate limits established by the [1mdiscard[0m command. This does not apply to [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries.[m
[52;1H[m
[53;1H               [1mlowpriotrap[0m[m
[54;1H                       Declare traps set by matching hosts to be low priority. The number of traps a server can maintain is limited (the current limit is 3). Traps are usually assigned on a first come, first served basis, with  later[m
[55;1H                       trap requestors being denied service. This flag modifies the assignment algorithm by allowing low priority traps to be overridden by later requests for normal priority traps.[m
[56;1H[m
[57;1H               [1mmssntp[0m  Enable  Microsoft  Windows  MS-SNTP  authentication  using Active Directory services. Note: Potential users should be aware that these services involve a TCP connection to another process that could potentially[m
[58;1H                       block, denying services to other users. Therefore, this flag should be used only for a dedicated server with no clients other than MS-SNTP.[m
[59;1H[m
[60;1H               [1mnomodify[0m[m
[61;1H                       Deny [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries which attempt to modify the state of the server (i.e., run time reconfiguration). Queries which return information are permitted.[m
[62;1H[m
[63;1H               [1mnoquery[0m Deny [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries. Time service is not affected.[m
[64;1H[m
[65;1H               [1mnopeer[0m  Deny packets that might mobilize an association unless authenticated. This includes broadcast, symmetric-active and manycast server packets when a configured association does not exist. Note that this flag does[m
[66;1H[K[7mPattern not found  (press RETURN)[27m[66;1H[K[K [KESCESC[K[[[K66[K~~[K                       not apply to packets that do not attempt to mobilize an association.[m
[m
               [1mnoserve[0m Deny all packets except [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries.[m
[m
               [1mnotrap[0m  Decline to provide mode 6 control message trap service to matching hosts. The trap service is a subsystem of the [1mntpdc[0m control message protocol which is intended for use by remote event logging programs.[m
[m
               [1mnotrust[0m Deny  packets  that are not cryptographically authenticated. Note carefully how this flag interacts with the [1mauth[0m option of the [1menable[0m and [1mdisable[0m commands. If [1mauth[0m is enabled, which is the default, authentica‚Äê[m
                       tion is required for all packets that might mobilize an association. If [1mauth[0m is disabled, but the [1mnotrust[0m flag is not present, an association can be mobilized whether or not authenticated. If [1mauth[0m is  disabled,[m
                       but the [1mnotrust[0m flag is present, authentication is required only for the specified address/mask range.[m
[m
               [1mntpport[0m[m
[m
               [1mnon-ntpport[0m[m
                       This  is  actually  a  match algorithm modifier, rather than a restriction flag. Its presence causes the restriction entry to be matched only if the source port in the packet is the standard NTP UDP port (123).[m
                       Both [1mntpport[0m and [1mnon-ntpport[0m may be specified. The [1mntpport[0m is considered more specific and is sorted later in the list.[m
[m
               [1mversion[0m Deny packets that do not match the current NTP version.[m
[m
       Default restriction list entries with the flags [1mignore,[0m [1mntpport[0m, for each of the local host's interface addresses are inserted into the table at startup to prevent the server from attempting to synchronize to its own  time.  A[m
       default entry is also always present, though if it is otherwise unconfigured; no flags are associated with the default entry (i.e., everything besides your own NTP server is unrestricted).[m
[m
[1mSEE[0m [1mALSO[0m[m
       ntp.conf(5)[m

[HM               [1maverage[0m [4mavg[24m[m
[HM[m

[HM               Set the parameters of the rate control facility which protects the server from client abuse. If the [1mlimited[0m flag is present in the ACL, packets that violate these limits are discarded. If in addition the  [1mkod[0m  restric‚Äê[m
[HM       [1mdiscard[0m [1m[[0m [1maverage[0m [4mavg[24m [1m][[0m [1mminimum[0m [4mmin[24m [1m][0m [1m[[0m [1mmonitor[0m [4mprob[24m [1m][0m[m

[?1049h[?1h=# For more information about this file, see the man pages
# ntp.conf(5), ntp_acc(5), ntp_auth(5), ntp_clock(5), ntp_misc(5), ntp_mon(5).

driftfile /var/lib/ntp/drift

# Permit time synchronization with our time source, but do not
# permit the source to query or modify the service on this system.
restrict default nomodify notrap nopeer noquery

# Permit all access over the loopback interface.  This could
# be tightened as well, but to do so would effect some of
# the administrative functions.
restrict 127.0.0.1 
restrict ::1

# Hosts on local network are less restricted.
#restrict 192.168.1.0 mask 255.255.255.0 nomodify notrap

# Use public servers from the pool.ntp.org project.
# Please consider joining the pool (http://www.pool.ntp.org/join.html).
#server 0.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
#server 1.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
#server 2.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
#server 3.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst

server 62.210.103.129 iburst
server 88.191.250.97 iburst

#broadcast 192.168.1.255 autokey        # broadcast server
#broadcastclient                        # broadcast client
#broadcast 224.0.1.1 autokey            # multicast server
#multicastclient 224.0.1.1              # multicast client
#manycastserver 239.255.254.254         # manycast server
#manycastclient 239.255.254.254 autokey # manycast client

# Enable public key cryptography.
#crypto

includefile /etc/ntp/crypto/pw

# Key file containing the keys and key identifiers used when operating
# with symmetric key cryptography. 
keys /etc/ntp/keys

# Specify the key identifiers which are trusted.
#trustedkey 4 8 42

# Specify the key identifier to use with the ntpdc utility.
#requestkey 8

# Specify the key identifier to use with the ntpq utility.
#controlkey 8

# Enable writing of statistics records.
#statistics clockstats cryptostats loopstats peerstats

# Disable the monitoring facility to prevent amplification attacks using ntpdc
# monlist command when default restrict does not include the noquery flag. See
# CVE-2013-5211 for more details.
# Note: Monitoring will not be disabled with the limited restriction flag.
disable monitor
[7m/etc/ntp.conf (END)[27m[K[K[?1l>[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 16:56:10]# less /etc/ntp.conf fg[Kman ntp_acc
[?1049h[?1h=ntp_acc(5)                                                                                                 File Formats Manual                                                                                                 ntp_acc(5)[m
[m
[1mNAME[0m[m
       ntp_acc - Access Control Options[m
[m
[1mACCESS[0m [1mCONTROL[0m [1mSUPPORT[0m[m
       The  [1mntpd[0m  daemon implements a general purpose access control list (ACL) containing address/match entries sorted first by increasing address values and then by increasing mask values. A match occurs when the bitwise AND of the[m
       mask and the packet source address is equal to the bitwise AND of the mask and address in the list. The list is searched in order with the last match found defining the restriction flags associated with the entry.[m
[m
       An example may clarify how it works. Our campus has two class-B networks, 128.4 for the ECE and CIS departments and 128.175 for the rest of campus. Let's assume (not true!) that subnet  128.4.1  homes  critical  services  like[m
       class rosters and spread sheets. A suitable ACL might be[m
[m
       restrict default nopeer                      # deny new associations[m
       restrict 128.175.0.0 mask 255.255.0.0        # allow campus access[m
       restrict 128.4.0.0 mask 255.255.0.0 none     # allow ECE and CIS access[m
       restrict 128.4.1.0 mask 255.255.255.0 notrust # require authentication on subnet 1[m
       restrict time.nist.gov                            # allow access[m
[m
       While  this  facility  may  be  useful  for  keeping unwanted, broken or malicious clients from congesting innocent servers, it should not be considered an alternative to the NTP authentication facilities. Source address based[m
       restrictions are easily circumvented by a determined cracker.[m
[m
[1mACCESS[0m [1mCONTROL[0m [1mCOMMANDS[0m[m
       [1mdiscard[0m [1m[[0m [1maverage[0m [4mavg[24m [1m][[0m [1mminimum[0m [4mmin[24m [1m][0m [1m[[0m [1mmonitor[0m [4mprob[24m [1m][0m[m
               Set the parameters of the rate control facility which protects the server from client abuse. If the [1mlimited[0m flag is present in the ACL, packets that violate these limits are discarded. If in addition the  [1mkod[0m  restric‚Äê[m
               tion is present, a kiss-o'-death packet is returned.[m
[m
               [1maverage[0m [4mavg[24m[m
                       Specify the minimum average interpacket spacing (minimum average headway time) in log2 s with default 3.[m
[m
               [1mminimum[0m [4mmin[24m[m
                       Specify the minimum interpacket spacing (guard time) in log2 s with default 1.[m
[m
               [1mmonitor[0m Specify the probability of discard for packets that overflow the rate-control window. This is a performance optimization for servers with aggregate arrivals of 1000 packets per second or more.[m
[m
       [1mrestrict[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[mask[0m [4mmask[24m[1m][0m [1m[[0m[4mflag[24m[1m][...][0m[m
               The  [4maddress[24m  argument expressed in dotted-quad form is the address of a host or network. Alternatively, the [4maddress[24m argument can be a valid host DNS name, but it must be resolvable at the time when [1mntpd[0m is started and[m
               if it's resolved to multiple addresses, only the first address will be added to the list. The [4mmask[24m argument expressed in dotted-quad form defaults to 255.255.255.255, meaning that the [4maddress[24m is treated as the  address[m
               of  an  individual host. A default entry (address 0.0.0.0, mask 0.0.0.0) is always included and is always the first entry in the list. Note that the text string [1mdefault[0m, with no mask option, may be used to indicate the[m
               default entry.  Some flags have the effect to deny service, some have the effect to enable service and some are conditioned by other flags. The flags. are not orthogonal, in that more restrictive flags will often  make[m
               less  restrictive ones redundant. The flags that deny service are classed in two categories, those that restrict time service and those that restrict informational queries and attempts to do run-time reconfiguration of[m
               the server. One or more of the following flags may be specified:[m
[m
               [1mflake[0m   Discard received NTP packets with probability 0.1; that is, on average drop one packet in ten. This is for testing and amusement. The name comes from Bob Braden's [4mflakeway[24m, which once did a  similar  thing  for[m
                       early Internet testing.[m
[m
               [1mignore[0m  Deny packets of all kinds, including [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries.[m
[m
               [1mkod[0m     Send  a  kiss-o'-death (KoD) packet if the [1mlimited[0m flag is present and a packet violates the rate limits established by the [1mdiscard[0m command. KoD packets are themselves rate limited for each source address sepa‚Äê[m
                       rately. If this flag is not present, packets that violate the rate limits are discarded.[m
[m
               [1mlimited[0m Deny time service if the packet violates the rate limits established by the [1mdiscard[0m command. This does not apply to [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries.[m
[m
               [1mlowpriotrap[0m[m
                       Declare traps set by matching hosts to be low priority. The number of traps a server can maintain is limited (the current limit is 3). Traps are usually assigned on a first come, first served basis, with  later[m
                       trap requestors being denied service. This flag modifies the assignment algorithm by allowing low priority traps to be overridden by later requests for normal priority traps.[m
[m
               [1mmssntp[0m  Enable  Microsoft  Windows  MS-SNTP  authentication  using Active Directory services. Note: Potential users should be aware that these services involve a TCP connection to another process that could potentially[m
                       block, denying services to other users. Therefore, this flag should be used only for a dedicated server with no clients other than MS-SNTP.[m
[m
               [1mnomodify[0m[m
                       Deny [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries which attempt to modify the state of the server (i.e., run time reconfiguration). Queries which return information are permitted.[m
[m
               [1mnoquery[0m Deny [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries. Time service is not affected.[m
[m
               [1mnopeer[0m  Deny packets that might mobilize an association unless authenticated. This includes broadcast, symmetric-active and manycast server packets when a configured association does not exist. Note that this flag does[m
[7m Manual page ntp_acc(5) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K[?1l>[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 16:57:01]# man ntp_accless /etc/ntp.conf 
[?1049h[?1h=# For more information about this file, see the man pages
# ntp.conf(5), ntp_acc(5), ntp_auth(5), ntp_clock(5), ntp_misc(5), ntp_mon(5).

driftfile /var/lib/ntp/drift

# Permit time synchronization with our time source, but do not
# permit the source to query or modify the service on this system.
restrict default nomodify notrap nopeer noquery

# Permit all access over the loopback interface.  This could
# be tightened as well, but to do so would effect some of
# the administrative functions.
restrict 127.0.0.1 
restrict ::1

# Hosts on local network are less restricted.
#restrict 192.168.1.0 mask 255.255.255.0 nomodify notrap

# Use public servers from the pool.ntp.org project.
# Please consider joining the pool (http://www.pool.ntp.org/join.html).
#server 0.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
#server 1.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
#server 2.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
#server 3.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst

server 62.210.103.129 iburst
server 88.191.250.97 iburst

#broadcast 192.168.1.255 autokey        # broadcast server
#broadcastclient                        # broadcast client
#broadcast 224.0.1.1 autokey            # multicast server
#multicastclient 224.0.1.1              # multicast client
#manycastserver 239.255.254.254         # manycast server
#manycastclient 239.255.254.254 autokey # manycast client

# Enable public key cryptography.
#crypto

includefile /etc/ntp/crypto/pw

# Key file containing the keys and key identifiers used when operating
# with symmetric key cryptography. 
keys /etc/ntp/keys

# Specify the key identifiers which are trusted.
#trustedkey 4 8 42

# Specify the key identifier to use with the ntpdc utility.
#requestkey 8

# Specify the key identifier to use with the ntpq utility.
#controlkey 8

# Enable writing of statistics records.
#statistics clockstats cryptostats loopstats peerstats

# Disable the monitoring facility to prevent amplification attacks using ntpdc
# monlist command when default restrict does not include the noquery flag. See
# CVE-2013-5211 for more details.
# Note: Monitoring will not be disabled with the limited restriction flag.
disable monitor

server 62.210.103.129 iburst

#broadcastclient                        # broadcast client
#broadcast 224.0.1.1 autokey            # multicast server
#multicastclient 224.0.1.1              # multicast client

[19;1H# Use public servers from the pool.ntp.org project.
[20;1H# Please consider joining the pool (http://www.pool.ntp.org/join.html).
[21;1H#server 0.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
[22;1H#server 1.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
[23;1H#server 2.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
[24;1H#server 3.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
[25;1H
[26;1Hserver 62.210.103.129 iburst
[27;1Hserver 88.191.250.97 iburst
[28;1H
[29;1H#broadcast 192.168.1.255 autokey        # broadcast server
[30;1H#broadcastclient                        # broadcast client
[31;1H#broadcast 224.0.1.1 autokey            # multicast server
[32;1H#multicastclient 224.0.1.1              # multicast client
[33;1H#manycastserver 239.255.254.254         # manycast server
[34;1H#manycastclient 239.255.254.254 autokey # manycast client
[35;1H
[36;1H# Enable public key cryptography.
[37;1H#crypto
[38;1H
[39;1Hincludefile /etc/ntp/crypto/pw
[40;1H
[41;1H# Key file containing the keys and key identifiers used when operating
[42;1H# with symmetric key cryptography. 
[43;1Hkeys /etc/ntp/keys
[44;1H
[45;1H# Specify the key identifiers which are trusted.
[46;1H#trustedkey 4 8 42
[47;1H
[48;1H# Specify the key identifier to use with the ntpdc utility.
[49;1H#requestkey 8
[50;1H
[51;1H# Specify the key identifier to use with the ntpq utility.
[52;1H#controlkey 8
[53;1H
[54;1H# Enable writing of statistics records.
[55;1H#statistics clockstats cryptostats loopstats peerstats
[56;1H
[57;1H# Disable the monitoring facility to prevent amplification attacks using ntpdc
[58;1H# monlist command when default restrict does not include the noquery flag. See
[59;1H# CVE-2013-5211 for more details.
[60;1H# Note: Monitoring will not be disabled with the limited restriction flag.
[61;1Hdisable monitor
[62;1H[1m~[0m
[66;1H[K[7mPattern not found  (press RETURN)[27m[66;1H[K[K[?1l>[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 16:57:46]# less /etc/ntp.conf [8Pman ntp_acc
[?1049h[?1h=ntp_acc(5)                                                                                                 File Formats Manual                                                                                                 ntp_acc(5)[m
[m
[1mNAME[0m[m
       ntp_acc - Access Control Options[m
[m
[1mACCESS[0m [1mCONTROL[0m [1mSUPPORT[0m[m
       The  [1mntpd[0m  daemon implements a general purpose access control list (ACL) containing address/match entries sorted first by increasing address values and then by increasing mask values. A match occurs when the bitwise AND of the[m
       mask and the packet source address is equal to the bitwise AND of the mask and address in the list. The list is searched in order with the last match found defining the restriction flags associated with the entry.[m
[m
       An example may clarify how it works. Our campus has two class-B networks, 128.4 for the ECE and CIS departments and 128.175 for the rest of campus. Let's assume (not true!) that subnet  128.4.1  homes  critical  services  like[m
       class rosters and spread sheets. A suitable ACL might be[m
[m
       restrict default nopeer                      # deny new associations[m
       restrict 128.175.0.0 mask 255.255.0.0        # allow campus access[m
       restrict 128.4.0.0 mask 255.255.0.0 none     # allow ECE and CIS access[m
       restrict 128.4.1.0 mask 255.255.255.0 notrust # require authentication on subnet 1[m
       restrict time.nist.gov                            # allow access[m
[m
       While  this  facility  may  be  useful  for  keeping unwanted, broken or malicious clients from congesting innocent servers, it should not be considered an alternative to the NTP authentication facilities. Source address based[m
       restrictions are easily circumvented by a determined cracker.[m
[m
[1mACCESS[0m [1mCONTROL[0m [1mCOMMANDS[0m[m
       [1mdiscard[0m [1m[[0m [1maverage[0m [4mavg[24m [1m][[0m [1mminimum[0m [4mmin[24m [1m][0m [1m[[0m [1mmonitor[0m [4mprob[24m [1m][0m[m
               Set the parameters of the rate control facility which protects the server from client abuse. If the [1mlimited[0m flag is present in the ACL, packets that violate these limits are discarded. If in addition the  [1mkod[0m  restric‚Äê[m
               tion is present, a kiss-o'-death packet is returned.[m
[m
               [1maverage[0m [4mavg[24m[m
                       Specify the minimum average interpacket spacing (minimum average headway time) in log2 s with default 3.[m
[m
               [1mminimum[0m [4mmin[24m[m
                       Specify the minimum interpacket spacing (guard time) in log2 s with default 1.[m
[m
               [1mmonitor[0m Specify the probability of discard for packets that overflow the rate-control window. This is a performance optimization for servers with aggregate arrivals of 1000 packets per second or more.[m
[m
       [1mrestrict[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[mask[0m [4mmask[24m[1m][0m [1m[[0m[4mflag[24m[1m][...][0m[m
               The  [4maddress[24m  argument expressed in dotted-quad form is the address of a host or network. Alternatively, the [4maddress[24m argument can be a valid host DNS name, but it must be resolvable at the time when [1mntpd[0m is started and[m
               if it's resolved to multiple addresses, only the first address will be added to the list. The [4mmask[24m argument expressed in dotted-quad form defaults to 255.255.255.255, meaning that the [4maddress[24m is treated as the  address[m
               of  an  individual host. A default entry (address 0.0.0.0, mask 0.0.0.0) is always included and is always the first entry in the list. Note that the text string [1mdefault[0m, with no mask option, may be used to indicate the[m
               default entry.  Some flags have the effect to deny service, some have the effect to enable service and some are conditioned by other flags. The flags. are not orthogonal, in that more restrictive flags will often  make[m
               less  restrictive ones redundant. The flags that deny service are classed in two categories, those that restrict time service and those that restrict informational queries and attempts to do run-time reconfiguration of[m
               the server. One or more of the following flags may be specified:[m
[m
               [1mflake[0m   Discard received NTP packets with probability 0.1; that is, on average drop one packet in ten. This is for testing and amusement. The name comes from Bob Braden's [4mflakeway[24m, which once did a  similar  thing  for[m
                       early Internet testing.[m
[m
               [1mignore[0m  Deny packets of all kinds, including [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries.[m
[m
               [1mkod[0m     Send  a  kiss-o'-death (KoD) packet if the [1mlimited[0m flag is present and a packet violates the rate limits established by the [1mdiscard[0m command. KoD packets are themselves rate limited for each source address sepa‚Äê[m
                       rately. If this flag is not present, packets that violate the rate limits are discarded.[m
[m
               [1mlimited[0m Deny time service if the packet violates the rate limits established by the [1mdiscard[0m command. This does not apply to [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries.[m
[m
               [1mlowpriotrap[0m[m
                       Declare traps set by matching hosts to be low priority. The number of traps a server can maintain is limited (the current limit is 3). Traps are usually assigned on a first come, first served basis, with  later[m
                       trap requestors being denied service. This flag modifies the assignment algorithm by allowing low priority traps to be overridden by later requests for normal priority traps.[m
[m
               [1mmssntp[0m  Enable  Microsoft  Windows  MS-SNTP  authentication  using Active Directory services. Note: Potential users should be aware that these services involve a TCP connection to another process that could potentially[m
                       block, denying services to other users. Therefore, this flag should be used only for a dedicated server with no clients other than MS-SNTP.[m
[m
               [1mnomodify[0m[m
                       Deny [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries which attempt to modify the state of the server (i.e., run time reconfiguration). Queries which return information are permitted.[m
[m
               [1mnoquery[0m Deny [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries. Time service is not affected.[m
[m
               [1mnopeer[0m  Deny packets that might mobilize an association unless authenticated. This includes broadcast, symmetric-active and manycast server packets when a configured association does not exist. Note that this flag does[m
[7m Manual page ntp_acc(5) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[Kll[Koo[Kcc[Kaa[Kll[Khh[Koo[Kss[Ktt[K[1;1Hntp_acc(5)                                                                                                 File Formats Manual                                                                                                 ntp_acc(5)[m

[7;1H       The  [1mntpd[0m  daemon implements a general purpose access control list (ACL) containing address/match entries sorted first by increasing address values and then by increasing mask values. A match occurs when the bitwise AND of the[m

[16;1H       restrict 128.4.1.0 mask 255.255.255.0 notrust # require authentication on subnet 1[m
[17;1H       restrict time.nist.gov                            # allow access[m

[3;1H[1mNAME[0m[m
[4;1H       ntp_acc - Access Control Options[m
[5;1H[m
[6;1H[1mACCESS[0m [1mCONTROL[0m [1mSUPPORT[0m[m
[7;1H       The  [1mntpd[0m  daemon implements a general purpose access control list (ACL) containing address/match entries sorted first by increasing address values and then by increasing mask values. A match occurs when the bitwise AND of the[m

[22;1H[1mACCESS[0m [1mCONTROL[0m [1mCOMMANDS[0m[m
[23;1H       [1mdiscard[0m [1m[[0m [1maverage[0m [4mavg[24m [1m][[0m [1mminimum[0m [4mmin[24m [1m][0m [1m[[0m [1mmonitor[0m [4mprob[24m [1m][0m[m
[24;1H               Set the parameters of the rate control facility which protects the server from client abuse. If the [1mlimited[0m flag is present in the ACL, packets that violate these limits are discarded. If in addition the  [1mkod[0m  restric‚Äê[m
[25;1H               tion is present, a kiss-o'-death packet is returned.[m
[26;1H[m
[27;1H               [1maverage[0m [4mavg[24m[m
[28;1H                       Specify the minimum average interpacket spacing (minimum average headway time) in log2 s with default 3.[m
[29;1H[m
[30;1H               [1mminimum[0m [4mmin[24m[m
[31;1H                       Specify the minimum interpacket spacing (guard time) in log2 s with default 1.[m
[32;1H[m
[33;1H               [1mmonitor[0m Specify the probability of discard for packets that overflow the rate-control window. This is a performance optimization for servers with aggregate arrivals of 1000 packets per second or more.[m
[34;1H[m
[35;1H       [1mrestrict[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[mask[0m [4mmask[24m[1m][0m [1m[[0m[4mflag[24m[1m][...][0m[m
[36;1H               The  [4maddress[24m  argument expressed in dotted-quad form is the address of a host or network. Alternatively, the [4maddress[24m argument can be a valid host DNS name, but it must be resolvable at the time when [1mntpd[0m is started and[m
[37;1H               if it's resolved to multiple addresses, only the first address will be added to the list. The [4mmask[24m argument expressed in dotted-quad form defaults to 255.255.255.255, meaning that the [4maddress[24m is treated as the  address[m
[38;1H               of  an  individual host. A default entry (address 0.0.0.0, mask 0.0.0.0) is always included and is always the first entry in the list. Note that the text string [1mdefault[0m, with no mask option, may be used to indicate the[m
[39;1H               default entry.  Some flags have the effect to deny service, some have the effect to enable service and some are conditioned by other flags. The flags. are not orthogonal, in that more restrictive flags will often  make[m
[40;1H               less  restrictive ones redundant. The flags that deny service are classed in two categories, those that restrict time service and those that restrict informational queries and attempts to do run-time reconfiguration of[m
[41;1H               the server. One or more of the following flags may be specified:[m
[42;1H[m
[43;1H               [1mflake[0m   Discard received NTP packets with probability 0.1; that is, on average drop one packet in ten. This is for testing and amusement. The name comes from Bob Braden's [4mflakeway[24m, which once did a  similar  thing  for[m
[44;1H                       early Internet testing.[m
[45;1H[m
[46;1H               [1mignore[0m  Deny packets of all kinds, including [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries.[m
[47;1H[m
[48;1H               [1mkod[0m     Send  a  kiss-o'-death (KoD) packet if the [1mlimited[0m flag is present and a packet violates the rate limits established by the [1mdiscard[0m command. KoD packets are themselves rate limited for each source address sepa‚Äê[m
[49;1H                       rately. If this flag is not present, packets that violate the rate limits are discarded.[m
[50;1H[m
[51;1H               [1mlimited[0m Deny time service if the packet violates the rate limits established by the [1mdiscard[0m command. This does not apply to [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries.[m
[52;1H[m
[53;1H               [1mlowpriotrap[0m[m
[54;1H                       Declare traps set by matching hosts to be low priority. The number of traps a server can maintain is limited (the current limit is 3). Traps are usually assigned on a first come, first served basis, with  later[m
[55;1H                       trap requestors being denied service. This flag modifies the assignment algorithm by allowing low priority traps to be overridden by later requests for normal priority traps.[m
[56;1H[m
[57;1H               [1mmssntp[0m  Enable  Microsoft  Windows  MS-SNTP  authentication  using Active Directory services. Note: Potential users should be aware that these services involve a TCP connection to another process that could potentially[m
[58;1H                       block, denying services to other users. Therefore, this flag should be used only for a dedicated server with no clients other than MS-SNTP.[m
[59;1H[m
[60;1H               [1mnomodify[0m[m
[61;1H                       Deny [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries which attempt to modify the state of the server (i.e., run time reconfiguration). Queries which return information are permitted.[m
[62;1H[m
[63;1H               [1mnoquery[0m Deny [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries. Time service is not affected.[m
[64;1H[m
[65;1H               [1mnopeer[0m  Deny packets that might mobilize an association unless authenticated. This includes broadcast, symmetric-active and manycast server packets when a configured association does not exist. Note that this flag does[m
[66;1H[1;1Hntp_acc(5)                                                                                                 File Formats Manual                                                                                                 ntp_acc(5)[m
[2;1H[m
[3;1H[1mNAME[0m[m
[4;1H       ntp_acc - Access Control Options[m
[5;1H[m
[6;1H[1mACCESS[0m [1mCONTROL[0m [1mSUPPORT[0m[m
[7;1H       The  [1mntpd[0m  daemon implements a general purpose access control list (ACL) containing address/match entries sorted first by increasing address values and then by increasing mask values. A match occurs when the bitwise AND of the[m
[8;1H       mask and the packet source address is equal to the bitwise AND of the mask and address in the list. The list is searched in order with the last match found defining the restriction flags associated with the entry.[m
[9;1H[m
[10;1H       An example may clarify how it works. Our campus has two class-B networks, 128.4 for the ECE and CIS departments and 128.175 for the rest of campus. Let's assume (not true!) that subnet  128.4.1  homes  critical  services  like[m
[11;1H       class rosters and spread sheets. A suitable ACL might be[m
[12;1H[m
[13;1H       restrict [7mdefault[27m nopeer                      # deny new associations[m
[14;1H       restrict 128.175.0.0 mask 255.255.0.0        # allow campus access[m
[15;1H       restrict 128.4.0.0 mask 255.255.0.0 none     # allow ECE and CIS access[m
[16;1H       restrict 128.4.1.0 mask 255.255.255.0 notrust # require authentication on subnet 1[m
[17;1H       restrict time.nist.gov                            # allow access[m
[18;1H[m
[19;1H       While  this  facility  may  be  useful  for  keeping unwanted, broken or malicious clients from congesting innocent servers, it should not be considered an alternative to the NTP authentication facilities. Source address based[m
[20;1H       restrictions are easily circumvented by a determined cracker.[m
[21;1H[m
[22;1H[1mACCESS[0m [1mCONTROL[0m [1mCOMMANDS[0m[m
[23;1H       [1mdiscard[0m [1m[[0m [1maverage[0m [4mavg[24m [1m][[0m [1mminimum[0m [4mmin[24m [1m][0m [1m[[0m [1mmonitor[0m [4mprob[24m [1m][0m[m
[24;1H               Set the parameters of the rate control facility which protects the server from client abuse. If the [1mlimited[0m flag is present in the ACL, packets that violate these limits are discarded. If in addition the  [1mkod[0m  restric‚Äê[m
[25;1H               tion is present, a kiss-o'-death packet is returned.[m
[26;1H[m
[27;1H               [1maverage[0m [4mavg[24m[m
[28;1H                       Specify the minimum average interpacket spacing (minimum average headway time) in log2 s with [7mdefault[27m 3.[m
[29;1H[m
[30;1H               [1mminimum[0m [4mmin[24m[m
[31;1H                       Specify the minimum interpacket spacing (guard time) in log2 s with [7mdefault[27m 1.[m
[32;1H[m
[33;1H               [1mmonitor[0m Specify the probability of discard for packets that overflow the rate-control window. This is a performance optimization for servers with aggregate arrivals of 1000 packets per second or more.[m
[34;1H[m
[35;1H       [1mrestrict[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[mask[0m [4mmask[24m[1m][0m [1m[[0m[4mflag[24m[1m][...][0m[m
[36;1H               The  [4maddress[24m  argument expressed in dotted-quad form is the address of a host or network. Alternatively, the [4maddress[24m argument can be a valid host DNS name, but it must be resolvable at the time when [1mntpd[0m is started and[m
[37;1H               if it's resolved to multiple addresses, only the first address will be added to the list. The [4mmask[24m argument expressed in dotted-quad form [7mdefault[27ms to 255.255.255.255, meaning that the [4maddress[24m is treated as the  address[m
[38;1H               of  an  individual host. A [7mdefault[27m entry (address 0.0.0.0, mask 0.0.0.0) is always included and is always the first entry in the list. Note that the text string [1m[7mdefault[27m[0m, with no mask option, may be used to indicate the[m
[39;1H               [7mdefault[27m entry.  Some flags have the effect to deny service, some have the effect to enable service and some are conditioned by other flags. The flags. are not orthogonal, in that more restrictive flags will often  make[m
[40;1H               less  restrictive ones redundant. The flags that deny service are classed in two categories, those that restrict time service and those that restrict informational queries and attempts to do run-time reconfiguration of[m
[41;1H               the server. One or more of the following flags may be specified:[m
[42;1H[m
[43;1H               [1mflake[0m   Discard received NTP packets with probability 0.1; that is, on average drop one packet in ten. This is for testing and amusement. The name comes from Bob Braden's [4mflakeway[24m, which once did a  similar  thing  for[m
[44;1H                       early Internet testing.[m
[45;1H[m
[46;1H               [1mignore[0m  Deny packets of all kinds, including [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries.[m
[47;1H[m
[48;1H               [1mkod[0m     Send  a  kiss-o'-death (KoD) packet if the [1mlimited[0m flag is present and a packet violates the rate limits established by the [1mdiscard[0m command. KoD packets are themselves rate limited for each source address sepa‚Äê[m
[49;1H                       rately. If this flag is not present, packets that violate the rate limits are discarded.[m
[50;1H[m
[51;1H               [1mlimited[0m Deny time service if the packet violates the rate limits established by the [1mdiscard[0m command. This does not apply to [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries.[m
[52;1H[m
[53;1H               [1mlowpriotrap[0m[m
[54;1H                       Declare traps set by matching hosts to be low priority. The number of traps a server can maintain is limited (the current limit is 3). Traps are usually assigned on a first come, first served basis, with  later[m
[55;1H                       trap requestors being denied service. This flag modifies the assignment algorithm by allowing low priority traps to be overridden by later requests for normal priority traps.[m
[56;1H[m
[57;1H               [1mmssntp[0m  Enable  Microsoft  Windows  MS-SNTP  authentication  using Active Directory services. Note: Potential users should be aware that these services involve a TCP connection to another process that could potentially[m
[58;1H                       block, denying services to other users. Therefore, this flag should be used only for a dedicated server with no clients other than MS-SNTP.[m
[59;1H[m
[60;1H               [1mnomodify[0m[m
[61;1H                       Deny [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries which attempt to modify the state of the server (i.e., run time reconfiguration). Queries which return information are permitted.[m
[62;1H[m
[63;1H               [1mnoquery[0m Deny [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries. Time service is not affected.[m
[64;1H[m
[65;1H               [1mnopeer[0m  Deny packets that might mobilize an association unless authenticated. This includes broadcast, symmetric-active and manycast server packets when a configured association does not exist. Note that this flag does[m
[66;1H                       not apply to packets that do not attempt to mobilize an association.[m
[m
               [1mnoserve[0m Deny all packets except [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries.[m
[m
               [1mnotrap[0m  Decline to provide mode 6 control message trap service to matching hosts. The trap service is a subsystem of the [1mntpdc[0m control message protocol which is intended for use by remote event logging programs.[m
[m
               [1mnotrust[0m Deny  packets  that are not cryptographically authenticated. Note carefully how this flag interacts with the [1mauth[0m option of the [1menable[0m and [1mdisable[0m commands. If [1mauth[0m is enabled, which is the [7mdefault[27m, authentica‚Äê[m
                       tion is required for all packets that might mobilize an association. If [1mauth[0m is disabled, but the [1mnotrust[0m flag is not present, an association can be mobilized whether or not authenticated. If [1mauth[0m is  disabled,[m
                       but the [1mnotrust[0m flag is present, authentication is required only for the specified address/mask range.[m
[m
               [1mntpport[0m[m
[m
[7m Manual page ntp_acc(5) line 16/105 85% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[Kdd[Kee[Kff[Kaa[Kuu[Kll[Ktt[K[1;1H       restrict default nopeer                      # deny new associations[m
[2;1H       restrict 128.175.0.0 mask 255.255.0.0        # allow campus access[m
[3;1H       restrict 128.4.0.0 mask 255.255.0.0 none     # allow ECE and CIS access[m
[4;1H       restrict 128.4.1.0 mask 255.255.255.0 notrust # require authentication on subnet 1[m
[5;1H       restrict time.nist.gov                            # allow access[m
[6;1H[m
[7;1H       While  this  facility  may  be  useful  for  keeping unwanted, broken or malicious clients from congesting innocent servers, it should not be considered an alternative to the NTP authentication facilities. Source address based[m
[8;1H       restrictions are easily circumvented by a determined cracker.[m
[9;1H[m
[10;1H[1mACCESS[0m [1mCONTROL[0m [1mCOMMANDS[0m[m
[11;1H       [1mdiscard[0m [1m[[0m [1maverage[0m [4mavg[24m [1m][[0m [1mminimum[0m [4mmin[24m [1m][0m [1m[[0m [1mmonitor[0m [4mprob[24m [1m][0m[m
[12;1H               Set the parameters of the rate control facility which protects the server from client abuse. If the [1mlimited[0m flag is present in the ACL, packets that violate these limits are discarded. If in addition the  [1mkod[0m  restric‚Äê[m
[13;1H               tion is present, a kiss-o'-death packet is returned.[m
[14;1H[m
[15;1H               [1maverage[0m [4mavg[24m[m
[16;1H                       Specify the minimum average interpacket spacing (minimum average headway time) in log2 s with default 3.[m
[17;1H[m
[18;1H               [1mminimum[0m [4mmin[24m[m
[19;1H                       Specify the minimum interpacket spacing (guard time) in log2 s with default 1.[m
[20;1H[m
[21;1H               [1mmonitor[0m Specify the probability of discard for packets that overflow the rate-control window. This is a performance optimization for servers with aggregate arrivals of 1000 packets per second or more.[m
[22;1H[m
[23;1H       [1mrestrict[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[mask[0m [4mmask[24m[1m][0m [1m[[0m[4mflag[24m[1m][...][0m[m
[24;1H               The  [4maddress[24m  argument expressed in dotted-quad form is the address of a host or network. Alternatively, the [4maddress[24m argument can be a valid host DNS name, but it must be resolvable at the time when [1mntpd[0m is started and[m
[25;1H               if it's resolved to multiple addresses, only the first address will be added to the list. The [4mmask[24m argument expressed in dotted-quad form defaults to 255.255.255.255, meaning that the [4maddress[24m is treated as the  address[m
[26;1H               of  an  individual host. A default entry (address 0.0.0.0, mask 0.0.0.0) is always included and is always the first entry in the list. Note that the text string [1mdefault[0m, with no mask option, may be used to indicate the[m
[27;1H               default entry.  Some flags have the effect to deny service, some have the effect to enable service and some are conditioned by other flags. The flags. are not orthogonal, in that more restrictive flags will often  make[m
[28;1H               less  restrictive ones redundant. The flags that deny service are classed in two categories, those that restrict time service and those that restrict informational queries and attempts to do run-time reconfiguration of[m
[29;1H               the server. One or more of the following flags may be specified:[m
[30;1H[m
[31;1H               [1mflake[0m   Discard received NTP packets with probability 0.1; that is, on average drop one packet in ten. This is for testing and amusement. The name comes from Bob Braden's [4mflakeway[24m, which once did a  similar  thing  for[m
[32;1H                       early Internet testing.[m
[33;1H[m
[34;1H               [1mignore[0m  Deny packets of all kinds, including [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries.[m
[35;1H[m
[36;1H               [1mkod[0m     Send  a  kiss-o'-death (KoD) packet if the [1mlimited[0m flag is present and a packet violates the rate limits established by the [1mdiscard[0m command. KoD packets are themselves rate limited for each source address sepa‚Äê[m
[37;1H                       rately. If this flag is not present, packets that violate the rate limits are discarded.[m
[38;1H[m
[39;1H               [1mlimited[0m Deny time service if the packet violates the rate limits established by the [1mdiscard[0m command. This does not apply to [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries.[m
[40;1H[m
[41;1H               [1mlowpriotrap[0m[m
[42;1H                       Declare traps set by matching hosts to be low priority. The number of traps a server can maintain is limited (the current limit is 3). Traps are usually assigned on a first come, first served basis, with  later[m
[43;1H                       trap requestors being denied service. This flag modifies the assignment algorithm by allowing low priority traps to be overridden by later requests for normal priority traps.[m
[44;1H[m
[45;1H               [1mmssntp[0m  Enable  Microsoft  Windows  MS-SNTP  authentication  using Active Directory services. Note: Potential users should be aware that these services involve a TCP connection to another process that could potentially[m
[46;1H                       block, denying services to other users. Therefore, this flag should be used only for a dedicated server with no clients other than MS-SNTP.[m
[47;1H[m
[48;1H               [1mnomodify[0m[m
[49;1H                       Deny [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries which attempt to modify the state of the server (i.e., run time reconfiguration). Queries which return information are permitted.[m
[50;1H[m
[51;1H               [1mnoquery[0m Deny [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries. Time service is not affected.[m
[52;1H[m
[53;1H               [1mnopeer[0m  Deny packets that might mobilize an association unless authenticated. This includes broadcast, symmetric-active and manycast server packets when a configured association does not exist. Note that this flag does[m
[54;1H                       not apply to packets that do not attempt to mobilize an association.[m
[55;1H[m
[56;1H               [1mnoserve[0m Deny all packets except [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries.[m

[58;1H               [1mnotrap[0m  Decline to provide mode 6 control message trap service to matching hosts. The trap service is a subsystem of the [1mntpdc[0m control message protocol which is intended for use by remote event logging programs.[m
[59;1H[m
[60;1H               [1mnotrust[0m Deny  packets  that are not cryptographically authenticated. Note carefully how this flag interacts with the [1mauth[0m option of the [1menable[0m and [1mdisable[0m commands. If [1mauth[0m is enabled, which is the default, authentica‚Äê[m
[61;1H                       tion is required for all packets that might mobilize an association. If [1mauth[0m is disabled, but the [1mnotrust[0m flag is not present, an association can be mobilized whether or not authenticated. If [1mauth[0m is  disabled,[m
[62;1H                       but the [1mnotrust[0m flag is present, authentication is required only for the specified address/mask range.[m
[63;1H[m
[64;1H               [1mntpport[0m[m
[65;1H[m
[66;1H[1;1H       restrict [7mdefault[27m nopeer                      # deny new associations[m
[2;1H       restrict 128.175.0.0 mask 255.255.0.0        # allow campus access[m
[3;1H       restrict 128.4.0.0 mask 255.255.0.0 none     # allow ECE and CIS access[m
[4;1H       restrict 128.4.1.0 mask 255.255.255.0 notrust # require authentication on subnet 1[m
[5;1H       restrict time.nist.gov                            # allow access[m
[6;1H[m
[7;1H       While  this  facility  may  be  useful  for  keeping unwanted, broken or malicious clients from congesting innocent servers, it should not be considered an alternative to the NTP authentication facilities. Source address based[m
[8;1H       restrictions are easily circumvented by a determined cracker.[m

[10;1H[1mACCESS[0m [1mCONTROL[0m [1mCOMMANDS[0m[m
[11;1H       [1mdiscard[0m [1m[[0m [1maverage[0m [4mavg[24m [1m][[0m [1mminimum[0m [4mmin[24m [1m][0m [1m[[0m [1mmonitor[0m [4mprob[24m [1m][0m[m
[12;1H               Set the parameters of the rate control facility which protects the server from client abuse. If the [1mlimited[0m flag is present in the ACL, packets that violate these limits are discarded. If in addition the  [1mkod[0m  restric‚Äê[m
[13;1H               tion is present, a kiss-o'-death packet is returned.[m
[14;1H[m
[15;1H               [1maverage[0m [4mavg[24m[m
[16;1H                       Specify the minimum average interpacket spacing (minimum average headway time) in log2 s with [7mdefault[27m 3.[m
[17;1H[m
[18;1H               [1mminimum[0m [4mmin[24m[m
[19;1H                       Specify the minimum interpacket spacing (guard time) in log2 s with [7mdefault[27m 1.[m
[20;1H[m
[21;1H               [1mmonitor[0m Specify the probability of discard for packets that overflow the rate-control window. This is a performance optimization for servers with aggregate arrivals of 1000 packets per second or more.[m
[22;1H[m
[23;1H       [1mrestrict[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[mask[0m [4mmask[24m[1m][0m [1m[[0m[4mflag[24m[1m][...][0m[m
[24;1H               The  [4maddress[24m  argument expressed in dotted-quad form is the address of a host or network. Alternatively, the [4maddress[24m argument can be a valid host DNS name, but it must be resolvable at the time when [1mntpd[0m is started and[m
[25;1H               if it's resolved to multiple addresses, only the first address will be added to the list. The [4mmask[24m argument expressed in dotted-quad form [7mdefault[27ms to 255.255.255.255, meaning that the [4maddress[24m is treated as the  address[m
[26;1H               of  an  individual host. A [7mdefault[27m entry (address 0.0.0.0, mask 0.0.0.0) is always included and is always the first entry in the list. Note that the text string [1m[7mdefault[27m[0m, with no mask option, may be used to indicate the[m
[27;1H               [7mdefault[27m entry.  Some flags have the effect to deny service, some have the effect to enable service and some are conditioned by other flags. The flags. are not orthogonal, in that more restrictive flags will often  make[m
[28;1H               less  restrictive ones redundant. The flags that deny service are classed in two categories, those that restrict time service and those that restrict informational queries and attempts to do run-time reconfiguration of[m
[29;1H               the server. One or more of the following flags may be specified:[m
