[31;1H               [1mflake[0m   Discard received NTP packets with probability 0.1; that is, on average drop one packet in ten. This is for testing and amusement. The name comes from Bob Braden's [4mflakeway[24m, which once did a  similar  thing  for[m
[32;1H                       early Internet testing.[m
[33;1H[m
[34;1H               [1mignore[0m  Deny packets of all kinds, including [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries.[m
[35;1H[m
[36;1H               [1mkod[0m     Send  a  kiss-o'-death (KoD) packet if the [1mlimited[0m flag is present and a packet violates the rate limits established by the [1mdiscard[0m command. KoD packets are themselves rate limited for each source address sepa‚Äê[m
[37;1H                       rately. If this flag is not present, packets that violate the rate limits are discarded.[m
[38;1H[m
[39;1H               [1mlimited[0m Deny time service if the packet violates the rate limits established by the [1mdiscard[0m command. This does not apply to [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries.[m
[40;1H[m
[41;1H               [1mlowpriotrap[0m[m
[42;1H                       Declare traps set by matching hosts to be low priority. The number of traps a server can maintain is limited (the current limit is 3). Traps are usually assigned on a first come, first served basis, with  later[m
[43;1H                       trap requestors being denied service. This flag modifies the assignment algorithm by allowing low priority traps to be overridden by later requests for normal priority traps.[m
[44;1H[m
[45;1H               [1mmssntp[0m  Enable  Microsoft  Windows  MS-SNTP  authentication  using Active Directory services. Note: Potential users should be aware that these services involve a TCP connection to another process that could potentially[m
[46;1H                       block, denying services to other users. Therefore, this flag should be used only for a dedicated server with no clients other than MS-SNTP.[m
[47;1H[m
[48;1H               [1mnomodify[0m[m
[49;1H                       Deny [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries which attempt to modify the state of the server (i.e., run time reconfiguration). Queries which return information are permitted.[m
[50;1H[m
[51;1H               [1mnoquery[0m Deny [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries. Time service is not affected.[m
[52;1H[m
[53;1H               [1mnopeer[0m  Deny packets that might mobilize an association unless authenticated. This includes broadcast, symmetric-active and manycast server packets when a configured association does not exist. Note that this flag does[m
[54;1H                       not apply to packets that do not attempt to mobilize an association.[m
[55;1H[m
[56;1H               [1mnoserve[0m Deny all packets except [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries.[m
[57;1H[m
[58;1H               [1mnotrap[0m  Decline to provide mode 6 control message trap service to matching hosts. The trap service is a subsystem of the [1mntpdc[0m control message protocol which is intended for use by remote event logging programs.[m
[59;1H[m
[60;1H               [1mnotrust[0m Deny  packets  that are not cryptographically authenticated. Note carefully how this flag interacts with the [1mauth[0m option of the [1menable[0m and [1mdisable[0m commands. If [1mauth[0m is enabled, which is the [7mdefault[27m, authentica‚Äê[m
[61;1H                       tion is required for all packets that might mobilize an association. If [1mauth[0m is disabled, but the [1mnotrust[0m flag is not present, an association can be mobilized whether or not authenticated. If [1mauth[0m is  disabled,[m
[62;1H                       but the [1mnotrust[0m flag is present, authentication is required only for the specified address/mask range.[m
[63;1H[m
[64;1H               [1mntpport[0m[m
[65;1H[m
[66;1H[K[7m Manual page ntp_acc(5) line 16/105 85% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KESCESC[K[7m Manual page ntp_acc(5) line 16/105 85% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KESCESC[K[7m Manual page ntp_acc(5) line 16/105 85% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K[7m Manual page ntp_acc(5) line 16/105 85% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K[7m Manual page ntp_acc(5) line 16/105 85% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM[m
[66;1H[K[7m Manual page ntp_acc(5) line 15/105 85% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM       class rosters and spread sheets. A suitable ACL might be[m
[66;1H[K[7m Manual page ntp_acc(5) line 14/105 85% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM       An example may clarify how it works. Our campus has two class-B networks, 128.4 for the ECE and CIS departments and 128.175 for the rest of campus. Let's assume (not true!) that subnet  128.4.1  homes  critical  services  like[m
[66;1H[K[7m Manual page ntp_acc(5) line 13/105 85% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM[m
[66;1H[K[7m Manual page ntp_acc(5) line 12/105 83% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM       mask and the packet source address is equal to the bitwise AND of the mask and address in the list. The list is searched in order with the last match found defining the restriction flags associated with the entry.[m
[66;1H[K[7m Manual page ntp_acc(5) line 11/105 80% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM       The  [1mntpd[0m  daemon implements a general purpose access control list (ACL) containing address/match entries sorted first by increasing address values and then by increasing mask values. A match occurs when the bitwise AND of the[m
[66;1H[K[7m Manual page ntp_acc(5) line 10/105 77% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM[1mACCESS[0m [1mCONTROL[0m [1mSUPPORT[0m[m
[66;1H[K[7m Manual page ntp_acc(5) line 9/105 77% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM[m
[66;1H[K[7m Manual page ntp_acc(5) line 8/105 75% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM       ntp_acc - Access Control Options[m
[66;1H[K[7m Manual page ntp_acc(5) line 6/105 75% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KAA[K[HM[1mNAME[0m[m
[66;1H[K[7m Manual page ntp_acc(5) line 5/105 74% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K               [1mnoserve[0m Deny all packets except [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries.[m
[7m Manual page ntp_acc(5) line 6/105 75% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[KOO[KBB[K[m
[7m Manual page ntp_acc(5) line 8/105 75% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[Knn[Koo[Kpp[Kee[Kee[Krr[K[1;1H[m
[2;1H[1mACCESS[0m [1mCONTROL[0m [1mSUPPORT[0m[m
[3;1H       The  [1mntpd[0m  daemon implements a general purpose access control list (ACL) containing address/match entries sorted first by increasing address values and then by increasing mask values. A match occurs when the bitwise AND of the[m
[4;1H       mask and the packet source address is equal to the bitwise AND of the mask and address in the list. The list is searched in order with the last match found defining the restriction flags associated with the entry.[m
[5;1H[m
[6;1H       An example may clarify how it works. Our campus has two class-B networks, 128.4 for the ECE and CIS departments and 128.175 for the rest of campus. Let's assume (not true!) that subnet  128.4.1  homes  critical  services  like[m
[7;1H       class rosters and spread sheets. A suitable ACL might be[m
[8;1H[m
[9;1H       restrict default nopeer                      # deny new associations[m
[10;1H       restrict 128.175.0.0 mask 255.255.0.0        # allow campus access[m
[11;1H       restrict 128.4.0.0 mask 255.255.0.0 none     # allow ECE and CIS access[m
[12;1H       restrict 128.4.1.0 mask 255.255.255.0 notrust # require authentication on subnet 1[m
[13;1H       restrict time.nist.gov                            # allow access[m
[14;1H[m
[15;1H       While  this  facility  may  be  useful  for  keeping unwanted, broken or malicious clients from congesting innocent servers, it should not be considered an alternative to the NTP authentication facilities. Source address based[m
[16;1H       restrictions are easily circumvented by a determined cracker.[m
[17;1H[m
[18;1H[1mACCESS[0m [1mCONTROL[0m [1mCOMMANDS[0m[m
[19;1H       [1mdiscard[0m [1m[[0m [1maverage[0m [4mavg[24m [1m][[0m [1mminimum[0m [4mmin[24m [1m][0m [1m[[0m [1mmonitor[0m [4mprob[24m [1m][0m[m
[20;1H               Set the parameters of the rate control facility which protects the server from client abuse. If the [1mlimited[0m flag is present in the ACL, packets that violate these limits are discarded. If in addition the  [1mkod[0m  restric‚Äê[m
[21;1H               tion is present, a kiss-o'-death packet is returned.[m
[22;1H[m
[23;1H               [1maverage[0m [4mavg[24m[m
[24;1H                       Specify the minimum average interpacket spacing (minimum average headway time) in log2 s with default 3.[m
[25;1H[m
[26;1H               [1mminimum[0m [4mmin[24m[m
[27;1H                       Specify the minimum interpacket spacing (guard time) in log2 s with default 1.[m
[28;1H[m
[29;1H               [1mmonitor[0m Specify the probability of discard for packets that overflow the rate-control window. This is a performance optimization for servers with aggregate arrivals of 1000 packets per second or more.[m
[30;1H[m
[31;1H       [1mrestrict[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[mask[0m [4mmask[24m[1m][0m [1m[[0m[4mflag[24m[1m][...][0m[m
[32;1H               The  [4maddress[24m  argument expressed in dotted-quad form is the address of a host or network. Alternatively, the [4maddress[24m argument can be a valid host DNS name, but it must be resolvable at the time when [1mntpd[0m is started and[m
[33;1H               if it's resolved to multiple addresses, only the first address will be added to the list. The [4mmask[24m argument expressed in dotted-quad form defaults to 255.255.255.255, meaning that the [4maddress[24m is treated as the  address[m
[34;1H               of  an  individual host. A default entry (address 0.0.0.0, mask 0.0.0.0) is always included and is always the first entry in the list. Note that the text string [1mdefault[0m, with no mask option, may be used to indicate the[m
[35;1H               default entry.  Some flags have the effect to deny service, some have the effect to enable service and some are conditioned by other flags. The flags. are not orthogonal, in that more restrictive flags will often  make[m
[36;1H               less  restrictive ones redundant. The flags that deny service are classed in two categories, those that restrict time service and those that restrict informational queries and attempts to do run-time reconfiguration of[m
[37;1H               the server. One or more of the following flags may be specified:[m
[38;1H[m
[39;1H               [1mflake[0m   Discard received NTP packets with probability 0.1; that is, on average drop one packet in ten. This is for testing and amusement. The name comes from Bob Braden's [4mflakeway[24m, which once did a  similar  thing  for[m
[40;1H                       early Internet testing.[m
[41;1H[m
[42;1H               [1mignore[0m  Deny packets of all kinds, including [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries.[m
[43;1H[m
[44;1H               [1mkod[0m     Send  a  kiss-o'-death (KoD) packet if the [1mlimited[0m flag is present and a packet violates the rate limits established by the [1mdiscard[0m command. KoD packets are themselves rate limited for each source address sepa‚Äê[m
[45;1H                       rately. If this flag is not present, packets that violate the rate limits are discarded.[m
[46;1H[m
[47;1H               [1mlimited[0m Deny time service if the packet violates the rate limits established by the [1mdiscard[0m command. This does not apply to [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries.[m
[48;1H[m
[49;1H               [1mlowpriotrap[0m[m
[50;1H                       Declare traps set by matching hosts to be low priority. The number of traps a server can maintain is limited (the current limit is 3). Traps are usually assigned on a first come, first served basis, with  later[m
[51;1H                       trap requestors being denied service. This flag modifies the assignment algorithm by allowing low priority traps to be overridden by later requests for normal priority traps.[m
[52;1H[m
[53;1H               [1mmssntp[0m  Enable  Microsoft  Windows  MS-SNTP  authentication  using Active Directory services. Note: Potential users should be aware that these services involve a TCP connection to another process that could potentially[m
[54;1H                       block, denying services to other users. Therefore, this flag should be used only for a dedicated server with no clients other than MS-SNTP.[m
[55;1H[m
[56;1H               [1mnomodify[0m[m
[57;1H                       Deny [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries which attempt to modify the state of the server (i.e., run time reconfiguration). Queries which return information are permitted.[m
[58;1H[m
[59;1H               [1mnoquery[0m Deny [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries. Time service is not affected.[m
[60;1H[m
[61;1H               [1mnopeer[0m  Deny packets that might mobilize an association unless authenticated. This includes broadcast, symmetric-active and manycast server packets when a configured association does not exist. Note that this flag does[m
[62;1H                       not apply to packets that do not attempt to mobilize an association.[m
[63;1H[m
[64;1H               [1mnoserve[0m Deny all packets except [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries.[m
[65;1H[m
[66;1H[1;1H[m
[2;1H[1mACCESS[0m [1mCONTROL[0m [1mSUPPORT[0m[m
[3;1H       The  [1mntpd[0m  daemon implements a general purpose access control list (ACL) containing address/match entries sorted first by increasing address values and then by increasing mask values. A match occurs when the bitwise AND of the[m
[4;1H       mask and the packet source address is equal to the bitwise AND of the mask and address in the list. The list is searched in order with the last match found defining the restriction flags associated with the entry.[m
[5;1H[m
[6;1H       An example may clarify how it works. Our campus has two class-B networks, 128.4 for the ECE and CIS departments and 128.175 for the rest of campus. Let's assume (not true!) that subnet  128.4.1  homes  critical  services  like[m
[7;1H       class rosters and spread sheets. A suitable ACL might be[m
[8;1H[m
[9;1H       restrict default [7mnopeer[27m                      # deny new associations[m
[10;1H       restrict 128.175.0.0 mask 255.255.0.0        # allow campus access[m
[11;1H       restrict 128.4.0.0 mask 255.255.0.0 none     # allow ECE and CIS access[m
[12;1H       restrict 128.4.1.0 mask 255.255.255.0 notrust # require authentication on subnet 1[m
[13;1H       restrict time.nist.gov                            # allow access[m
[14;1H[m
[15;1H       While  this  facility  may  be  useful  for  keeping unwanted, broken or malicious clients from congesting innocent servers, it should not be considered an alternative to the NTP authentication facilities. Source address based[m
[16;1H       restrictions are easily circumvented by a determined cracker.[m
[17;1H[m
[18;1H[1mACCESS[0m [1mCONTROL[0m [1mCOMMANDS[0m[m
[19;1H       [1mdiscard[0m [1m[[0m [1maverage[0m [4mavg[24m [1m][[0m [1mminimum[0m [4mmin[24m [1m][0m [1m[[0m [1mmonitor[0m [4mprob[24m [1m][0m[m
[20;1H               Set the parameters of the rate control facility which protects the server from client abuse. If the [1mlimited[0m flag is present in the ACL, packets that violate these limits are discarded. If in addition the  [1mkod[0m  restric‚Äê[m
[21;1H               tion is present, a kiss-o'-death packet is returned.[m
[22;1H[m
[23;1H               [1maverage[0m [4mavg[24m[m
[24;1H                       Specify the minimum average interpacket spacing (minimum average headway time) in log2 s with default 3.[m
[25;1H[m
[26;1H               [1mminimum[0m [4mmin[24m[m
[27;1H                       Specify the minimum interpacket spacing (guard time) in log2 s with default 1.[m
[28;1H[m
[29;1H               [1mmonitor[0m Specify the probability of discard for packets that overflow the rate-control window. This is a performance optimization for servers with aggregate arrivals of 1000 packets per second or more.[m
[30;1H[m
[31;1H       [1mrestrict[0m [4maddress[24m [1m[mask[0m [4mmask[24m[1m][0m [1m[[0m[4mflag[24m[1m][...][0m[m
[32;1H               The  [4maddress[24m  argument expressed in dotted-quad form is the address of a host or network. Alternatively, the [4maddress[24m argument can be a valid host DNS name, but it must be resolvable at the time when [1mntpd[0m is started and[m
[33;1H               if it's resolved to multiple addresses, only the first address will be added to the list. The [4mmask[24m argument expressed in dotted-quad form defaults to 255.255.255.255, meaning that the [4maddress[24m is treated as the  address[m
[34;1H               of  an  individual host. A default entry (address 0.0.0.0, mask 0.0.0.0) is always included and is always the first entry in the list. Note that the text string [1mdefault[0m, with no mask option, may be used to indicate the[m
[35;1H               default entry.  Some flags have the effect to deny service, some have the effect to enable service and some are conditioned by other flags. The flags. are not orthogonal, in that more restrictive flags will often  make[m
[36;1H               less  restrictive ones redundant. The flags that deny service are classed in two categories, those that restrict time service and those that restrict informational queries and attempts to do run-time reconfiguration of[m
[37;1H               the server. One or more of the following flags may be specified:[m
[38;1H[m
[39;1H               [1mflake[0m   Discard received NTP packets with probability 0.1; that is, on average drop one packet in ten. This is for testing and amusement. The name comes from Bob Braden's [4mflakeway[24m, which once did a  similar  thing  for[m
[40;1H                       early Internet testing.[m
[41;1H[m
[42;1H               [1mignore[0m  Deny packets of all kinds, including [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries.[m
[43;1H[m
[44;1H               [1mkod[0m     Send  a  kiss-o'-death (KoD) packet if the [1mlimited[0m flag is present and a packet violates the rate limits established by the [1mdiscard[0m command. KoD packets are themselves rate limited for each source address sepa‚Äê[m
[45;1H                       rately. If this flag is not present, packets that violate the rate limits are discarded.[m
[46;1H[m
[47;1H               [1mlimited[0m Deny time service if the packet violates the rate limits established by the [1mdiscard[0m command. This does not apply to [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries.[m
[48;1H[m
[49;1H               [1mlowpriotrap[0m[m
[50;1H                       Declare traps set by matching hosts to be low priority. The number of traps a server can maintain is limited (the current limit is 3). Traps are usually assigned on a first come, first served basis, with  later[m
[51;1H                       trap requestors being denied service. This flag modifies the assignment algorithm by allowing low priority traps to be overridden by later requests for normal priority traps.[m
[52;1H[m
[53;1H               [1mmssntp[0m  Enable  Microsoft  Windows  MS-SNTP  authentication  using Active Directory services. Note: Potential users should be aware that these services involve a TCP connection to another process that could potentially[m
[54;1H                       block, denying services to other users. Therefore, this flag should be used only for a dedicated server with no clients other than MS-SNTP.[m
[55;1H[m
[56;1H               [1mnomodify[0m[m
[57;1H                       Deny [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries which attempt to modify the state of the server (i.e., run time reconfiguration). Queries which return information are permitted.[m
[58;1H[m
[59;1H               [1mnoquery[0m Deny [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries. Time service is not affected.[m
[60;1H[m
[61;1H               [1m[7mnopeer[27m[0m  Deny packets that might mobilize an association unless authenticated. This includes broadcast, symmetric-active and manycast server packets when a configured association does not exist. Note that this flag does[m
[62;1H                       not apply to packets that do not attempt to mobilize an association.[m
[63;1H[m
[64;1H               [1mnoserve[0m Deny all packets except [1mntpq[0m and [1mntpdc[0m queries.[m
[65;1H[m
[66;1H               [1mnotrap[0m  Decline to provide mode 6 control message trap service to matching hosts. The trap service is a subsystem of the [1mntpdc[0m control message protocol which is intended for use by remote event logging programs.[m
[m
               [1mnotrust[0m Deny  packets  that are not cryptographically authenticated. Note carefully how this flag interacts with the [1mauth[0m option of the [1menable[0m and [1mdisable[0m commands. If [1mauth[0m is enabled, which is the default, authentica‚Äê[m
                       tion is required for all packets that might mobilize an association. If [1mauth[0m is disabled, but the [1mnotrust[0m flag is not present, an association can be mobilized whether or not authenticated. If [1mauth[0m is  disabled,[m
                       but the [1mnotrust[0m flag is present, authentication is required only for the specified address/mask range.[m

[m
[7m Manual page ntp_acc(5) line 16/105 85% (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K[?1l>[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 17:00:04]# man ntp_clock
[?1049h[?1h=ntp_clock(5)                                                                                               File Formats Manual                                                                                               ntp_clock(5)[m
[m
[1mNAME[0m[m
       ntp_clock - Reference Clock Options[m
[m
[1mREFERENCE[0m [1mCLOCK[0m [1mSUPPORT[0m[m
       The NTP Version 4 daemon supports some three dozen different radio, satellite and modem reference clocks plus a special pseudo-clock used for backup or when no other clock source is available. Detailed descriptions of individ‚Äê[m
       ual device drivers and options can be found in the Reference Clock Drivers page. Additional information can be found in the pages linked there, including the Debugging Hints for Reference Clock Drivers and How To Write a  Ref‚Äê[m
       erence Clock Driver pages. In addition, support for a PPS signal is available as described in Pulse-per-second (PPS) Signal Interfacing page.[m
[m
       A  reference clock will generally (though not always) be a radio timecode receiver which is synchronized to a source of standard time such as the services offered by the NRC in Canada and NIST and USNO in the US. The interface[m
       between the computer and the timecode receiver is device dependent, but is usually a serial port. A device driver specific to each reference clock must be selected and compiled in the distribution; however, most common  radio,[m
       satellite  and  modem  clocks  are included by default. Note that an attempt to configure a reference clock when the driver has not been compiled or the hardware port has not been appropriately configured results in a scalding[m
       remark to the system log file, but is otherwise non hazardous.[m
[m
       For the purposes of configuration, [1mntpd[0m treats reference clocks in a manner analogous to normal NTP peers as much as possible. Reference clocks are identified by a syntactically correct but invalid IP address, in order to dis‚Äê[m
       tinguish  them  from normal NTP peers. Reference clock addresses are of the form [1m127.127.[0m[4mt.u[24m, where [1mt[0m is an integer denoting the clock type and [1mu[0m indicates the unit number in the range 0-3. While it may seem overkill, it is in[m
       fact sometimes useful to configure multiple reference clocks of the same type, in which case the unit numbers must be unique.[m
[m
       The [1mserver[0m command is used to configure a reference clock, where the [1maddress[0m argument in that command is the clock address. The [1mkey[0m, [1mversion[0m and [1mttl[0m options are not used for reference clock support. The [1mmode[0m  option  is  added[m
       for  reference  clock  support, as described below. The [1mprefer[0m option can be useful to persuade the server to cherish a reference clock with somewhat more enthusiasm than other reference clocks or peers. Further information on[m
       this option can be found in the Mitigation Rules and the [1mprefer[0m Keyword page. The [1mminpoll[0m and [1mmaxpoll[0m options have meaning only for selected clock drivers. See the individual clock driver document pages for additional informa‚Äê[m
       tion.[m
[m
       The  [1mfudge[0m  command  is  used  to  provide  additional information for individual clock drivers and normally follows immediately after the [1mserver[0m command. The [1maddress[0m argument specifies the clock address. The [1mrefid[0m and [1mstratum[0m[m
       options control can be used to override the defaults for the device. There are two optional device-dependent time offsets and four flags that can be included in the [1mfudge[0m command as well.[m
[m
       The stratum number of a reference clock is by default zero. Since the [1mntpd[0m daemon adds one to the stratum of each peer, a primary server ordinarily displays an external stratum of one. In order to provide  engineered  backups,[m
       it is often useful to specify the reference clock stratum as greater than zero. The [1mstratum[0m option is used for this purpose. Also, in cases involving both a reference clock and a pulse-per-second (PPS) discipline signal, it is[m
       useful to specify the reference clock identifier as other than the default, depending on the driver. The [1mrefid[0m option is used for this purpose. Except where noted, these options apply to all clock drivers.[m
[m
[1mREFERENCE[0m [1mCLOCK[0m [1mCOMMANDS[0m[m
       [1mserver[0m [1m127.127.[0m[4mt.u[24m [1m[prefer][0m [1m[mode[0m [4mint[24m[1m][0m [1m[minpoll[0m [4mint[24m[1m][0m [1m[maxpoll[0m [4mint[24m[1m][0m[m
               This command can be used to configure reference clocks in special ways. The options are interpreted as follows:[m
[m
               [1mprefer[0m  Marks the reference clock as preferred. All other things being equal, this host will be chosen for synchronization among a set of correctly operating hosts. See the Mitigation Rules and the [1mprefer[0m Keyword  page[m
                       for further information.[m
[m
               [1mmode[0m [4mint[24m[m
                       Specifies a mode number which is interpreted in a device-specific fashion. For instance, it selects a dialing protocol in the ACTS driver and a device subtype in the [1mparse[0m drivers.[m
[m
               [1mminpoll[0m [4mint[24m[m
[m
               [1mmaxpoll[0m [4mint[24m[m
                       These  options  specify  the  minimum and maximum polling interval for reference clock messages in seconds, interpreted as dual logarithms (2 ^ x). For most directly connected reference clocks, both [1mminpoll[0m and[m
                       [1mmaxpoll[0m default to 6 (2^16 = 64 s). For modem reference clocks, [1mminpoll[0m defaults to 10 (2^10 = 1024 s = 17.1 m) and [1mmaxpoll[0m defaults to 14 (2^14 = 16384 s = 4.5 h). The allowable range is 4 (16 s) to  17  (36.4[m
                       h) inclusive.[m
[m
       [1mfudge[0m [1m127.127.[0m[4mt.u[24m [1m[time1[0m [4msec[24m[1m][0m [1m[time2[0m [4msec[24m[1m][0m [1m[stratum[0m [4mint[24m[1m][0m [1m[refid[0m [4mstring[24m[1m][0m [1m[flag1[0m [1m0|1][0m [1m[flag2[0m [1m0|1][0m [1m[flag3[0m [1m0|1][0m [1m[flag4[0m [1m0|1][0m[m
               This  command  can be used to configure reference clocks in special ways. It must immediately follow the [1mserver[0m command which configures the driver. Note that the same capability is possible at run time using the [1mntpdc[0m[m
               program. The options are interpreted as follows:[m
[m
               [1mtime1[0m [4msec[24m[m
                       Specifies a constant to be added to the time offset produced by the driver, a fixed-point decimal number in seconds. This is used as a calibration constant to adjust the nominal  time  offset  of  a  particular[m
                       clock  to  agree with an external standard, such as a precision PPS signal. It also provides a way to correct a systematic error or bias due to serial port or operating system latencies, different cable lengths[m
                       or receiver internal delay. The specified offset is in addition to the propagation delay provided by other means, such as internal DIPswitches. Where a calibration for an individual system and driver is  avail‚Äê[m
                       able,  an approximate correction is noted in the driver documentation pages.  Note: in order to facilitate calibration when more than one radio clock or PPS signal is supported, a special calibration feature is[m
                       available. It takes the form of an argument to the [1menable[0m command described in the Miscellaneous Options page and operates as described in the Reference Clock Drivers page.[m
[m
               [1mtime2[0m [4msecs[24m[m
                       Specifies a fixed-point decimal number in seconds, which is interpreted in a driver-dependent way. See the descriptions of specific drivers in the reference clock drivers page.[m
[m
               [1mstratum[0m [4mint[24m[m
                       Specifies the stratum number assigned to the driver, an integer between 0 and 15. This number overrides the default stratum number ordinarily assigned by the driver itself, usually zero.[m
[m
[7m Manual page ntp_clock(5) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K[?1l>[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 17:00:53]# vii[Km /etn[Kc/ntp.conf 
[?1049h[?1h=[2;1H‚ñΩ[6n[1;1H  [1;1H[1;66r[?12;25h[?12l[?25h[27m[m[H[2J[?25l[66;1H"/etc/ntp.conf" 61L, 2062C[>c[1;1H[34m# For more information about this file, see the man pages
# ntp.conf(5), ntp_acc(5), ntp_auth(5), ntp_clock(5), ntp_misc(5), ntp_mon(5).[m

driftfile /var/lib/ntp/drift

[34m# Permit time synchronization with our time source, but do not
# permit the source to query or modify the service on this system.[m
restrict default nomodify notrap nopeer noquery

[34m# Permit all access over the loopback interface.  This could
# be tightened as well, but to do so would effect some of
# the administrative functions.[m
restrict 127.0.0.1
restrict ::1

[34m# Hosts on local network are less restricted.
#restrict 192.168.1.0 mask 255.255.255.0 nomodify notrap

# Use public [m[30m[43mserver[m[34ms from the pool.ntp.org project.
# Please consider joining the pool (http://www.pool.ntp.org/join.html).
#[m[30m[43mserver[m[34m 0.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
#[m[30m[43mserver[m[34m 1.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
#[m[30m[43mserver[m[34m 2.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
#[m[30m[43mserver[m[34m 3.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst[m

[30m[43mserver[m 62.210.103.129 iburst
[30m[43mserver[m 88.191.250.97 iburst

[34m#broadcast 192.168.1.255 autokey        # broadcast [m[30m[43mserver[m
[34m#broadcastclient                        # broadcast client
#broadcast 224.0.1.1 autokey            # multicast [m[30m[43mserver[m
[34m#multicastclient 224.0.1.1              # multicast client
#manycast[m[30m[43mserver[m[34m 239.255.254.254         # manycast [m[30m[43mserver[m
[34m#manycastclient 239.255.254.254 autokey # manycast client

# Enable public key cryptography.
#crypto[m

includefile /etc/ntp/crypto/pw

[34m# Key file containing the keys and key identifiers used when operating
# with symmetric key cryptography. [m
keys /etc/ntp/keys

[34m# Specify the key identifiers which are trusted.
#trustedkey 4 8 42

# Specify the key identifier to use with the ntpdc utility.
#requestkey 8

# Specify the key identifier to use with the ntpq utility.
#controlkey 8

# Enable writing of statistics records.
#statistics clockstats cryptostats loopstats peerstats

# Disable the monitoring facility to prevent amplification attacks using ntpdc
# monlist command when default restrict does not include the noquery flag. See
# CVE-2013-5211 for more details.
# Note: Monitoring will not be disabled with the limited restriction flag.[m
disable monitor

]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 17:06:05]# ntpstat
synchronised to local net at stratum 11 
   time correct to within 1948 ms
   polling server every 64 s
]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 17:06:19]# ntpstatq -p
     remote           refid      st t when poll reach   delay   offset  jitter
==============================================================================
*LOCAL(0)        .LOCL.          10 l    7   64    7    0.000    0.000   0.000
]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 17:06:21]# man ntpq
[?1049h[?1h=ntpq(8)                                                                                                  System Manager's Manual                                                                                                  ntpq(8)[m
[m
[1mNAME[0m[m
       ntpq - standard NTP query program[m
[m
[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
       [1mntpq[0m [1m[-46dinp][0m [1m[-c[0m [4mcommand[24m[1m][0m [1m[[0m[4mhost[24m[1m][0m [1m[...][0m[m
[m
[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
       The  [1mntpq[0m utility program is used to monitor NTP daemon [1mntpd[0m operations and determine performance. It uses the standard NTP mode 6 control message formats defined in Appendix B of the NTPv3 specification RFC1305. The same for‚Äê[m
       mats are used in NTPv4, although some of the variable names have changed and new ones added. The description on this page is for the NTPv4 variables.[m
[m
       The program can be run either in interactive mode or controlled using command line arguments. Requests to read and write arbitrary variables can be assembled, with raw and pretty-printed output  options  being  available.  The[m
       [1mntpq[0m can also obtain and print a list of peers in a common format by sending multiple queries to the server.[m
[m
       If  one  or  more  request  options  is  included on the command line when [1mntpq[0m is executed, each of the requests will be sent to the NTP servers running on each of the hosts given as command line arguments, or on localhost by[m
       default. If no request options are given, [1mntpq[0m will attempt to read commands from the standard input and execute these on the NTP server running on the first host given on the command line, again defaulting to  localhost  when[m
       no other host is specified. [1mntpq[0m will prompt for commands if the standard input is a terminal device.[m
[m
       [1mntpq[0m  uses  NTP mode 6 packets to communicate with the NTP server, and hence can be used to query any compatible server on the network which permits it. Note that since NTP is a UDP protocol this communication will be somewhat[m
       unreliable, especially over large distances in terms of network topology. [1mntpq[0m makes one attempt to retransmit requests, and will time requests out if the remote host is not heard from within a suitable timeout time.[m
[m
       Note that in contexts where a host name is expected, a [1m-4[0m qualifier preceding the host name forces DNS resolution to the IPv4 namespace, while a [1m-6[0m qualifier forces DNS resolution to the IPv6 namespace.[m
[m
       For examples and usage, see the NTP Debugging Techniques page.[m
[m
       Command line options are described following. Specifying a command line option other than [1m-i[0m or [1m-n[0m will cause the specified query (queries) to be sent to the indicated host(s) immediately. Otherwise, [1mntpq[0m will attempt to  read[m
       interactive format commands from the standard input.[m
[m
       [1m-4[0m      Force DNS resolution of following host names on the command line to the IPv4 namespace.[m
[m
       [1m-6[0m      Force DNS resolution of following host names on the command line to the IPv6 namespace.[m
[m
       [1m-c[0m      The following argument is interpreted as an interactive format command and is added to the list of commands to be executed on the specified host(s). Multiple [1m-c[0m options may be given.[m
[m
       [1m-d[0m      Turn on debugging mode.[m
[m
       [1m-i[0m      Force [1mntpq[0m to operate in interactive mode. Prompts will be written to the standard output and commands read from the standard input.[m
[m
       [1m-n[0m      Output all host addresses in dotted-quad numeric format rather than converting to the canonical host names.[m
[m
       [1m-p[0m      Print a list of the peers known to the server as well as a summary of their state. This is equivalent to the [1mpeers[0m interactive command.[m
[m
[1mINTERNAL[0m [1mCOMMANDS[0m[m
       Interactive  format  commands  consist of a keyword followed by zero to four arguments. Only enough characters of the full keyword to uniquely identify the command need be typed. The output of a command is normally sent to the[m
       standard output, but optionally the output of individual commands may be sent to a file by appending a [1m>[0m, followed by a file name, to the command line. A number of interactive format commands are executed entirely  within  the[m
       [1mntpq[0m program itself and do not result in NTP mode-6 requests being sent to a server. These are described following.[m
[m
       [1m?[0m [1m[[0m[4mcommand_keyword[24m[1m][0m[m
[m
       [1mhelp[0m [1m[[0m[4mcommand_keyword[24m[1m][0m[m
               A [1m?[0m by itself will print a list of all the command keywords known to [1mntpq[0m. A [1m?[0m followed by a command keyword will print function and usage information about the command.[m
[m
       [1maddvars[0m [4mname[24m [1m[[0m [1m=[0m [4mvalue[24m[1m][0m [1m[...][0m[m
[m
       [1mrmvars[0m [4mname[24m [1m[...][0m[m
[m
       [1mclearvars[0m[m
               The arguments to this command consist of a list of items of the form [4mname[24m [1m=[0m [4mvalue[24m, where the [1m=[0m [4mvalue[24m is ignored, and can be omitted in read requests. [1mntpq[0m maintains an internal list in which data to be included in con‚Äê[m
               trol messages can be assembled, and sent using the [1mreadlist[0m and [1mwritelist[0m commands described below. The [1maddvars[0m command allows variables and optional values to be added to the list. If more than one variable is  to  be[m
               added, the list should be comma-separated and not contain white space. The [1mrmvars[0m command can be used to remove individual variables from the list, while the [1mclearlist[0m command removes all variables from the list.[m
[m
       [1mcooked[0m  Display server messages in prettyprint format.[m
[m
       [1mdebug[0m [1mmore[0m [1m|[0m [1mless[0m [1m|[0m [1moff[0m[m
[7m Manual page ntpq(8) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K [KESCESC[K[[[K66[K~~[K               Turns internal query program debugging on and off.[m
[m
       [1mdelay[0m [4mmilliseconds[24m[m
               Specify  a  time  interval to be added to timestamps included in requests which require authentication. This is used to enable (unreliable) server reconfiguration over long delay network paths or between machines whose[m
               clocks are unsynchronized. Actually the server does not now require timestamps in authenticated requests, so this command may be obsolete.[m
[m
       [1mhost[0m [4mname[24m[m
               Set the host to which future queries will be sent. The name may be either a DNS name or a numeric address.[m
[m
       [1mhostnames[0m [1m[yes[0m [1m|[0m [1mno][0m[m
               If [1myes[0m is specified, host names are printed in information displays. If [1mno[0m is specified, numeric addresses are printed instead. The default is [1myes[0m, unless modified using the command line [1m-n[0m switch.[m
[m
       [1mkeyid[0m [4mkeyid[24m[m
               This command specifies the key number to be used to authenticate configuration requests. This must correspond to a key number the server has been configured to use for this purpose.[m
[m
       [1mntpversion[0m [1m1[0m [1m|[0m [1m2[0m [1m|[0m [1m3[0m [1m|[0m [1m4[0m[m
               Sets the NTP version number which [1mntpq[0m claims in packets. Defaults to 2, Note that mode-6 control messages (and modes, for that matter) didn't exist in NTP version 1.[m
[m
       [1mpasswd[0m  This command prompts for a password to authenticate configuration requests. The password must correspond to the key configured for NTP server for this purpose.[m
[m
       [1mquit[0m    Exit [1mntpq[0m.[m
[m
       [1mraw[0m     Display server messages as received and without reformatting.[m
[m
       [1mtimeout[0m [4mmilliseconds[24m[m
               Specify a timeout period for responses to server queries. The default is about 5000 milliseconds. Note that since [1mntpq[0m retries each query once after a timeout, the total waiting time for a timeout  will  be  twice  the[m
               timeout value set.[m
[m
[1mCONTROL[0m [1mMESSAGE[0m [1mCOMMANDS[0m[m
       Association  IDs are used to identify system, peer and clock variables. System variables are assigned an association ID of zero and system name space, while each association is assigned a nonzero association ID and peer names‚Äê[m
       pace. Most control commands send a single mode-6 message to the server and expect a single response message. The exceptions are the [1mpeers[0m command, which sends a series of messages, and  the  [1mmreadlist[0m  and  [1mmreadvar[0m  commands,[m
       which iterate over a range of associations.[m
[m
       [1massociations[0m[m
               Display a list of mobilized associations in the form [1mind[0m [1massid[0m [1mstatus[0m [1mconf[0m [1mreach[0m [1mauth[0m [1mcondition[0m [1mlast_event[0m [1mcnt[0m[m
[m
               ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î¨‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê[m
               ‚îÇ                            Variable                                             ‚îÇ                                           Description                                                                                 ‚îÇ[m
               ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îº‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î§[m
               ‚îÇ                            [1mind[0m                                                  ‚îÇ                                           index on this list                                                                          ‚îÇ[m
               ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îº‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î§[m
               ‚îÇ                            [1massid[0m                                                ‚îÇ                                           association ID                                                                              ‚îÇ[m
               ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îº‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î§[m
               ‚îÇ                            [1mstatus[0m                                               ‚îÇ                                           peer status word                                                                            ‚îÇ[m
               ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îº‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î§[m
               ‚îÇ                            [1mconf[0m                                                 ‚îÇ                                           [1myes[0m: persistent, [1mno[0m: ephemeral                                                              ‚îÇ[m

               Perform the same function as the [1mreadvar[0m command, except for a range of association IDs. This range is determined from the association list cached by the most recent [1massociations[0m command.[m
[m
       [1mpassociations[0m[m
               Perform the same function as the [1massociations[0m [1mcommand[0m, except that it uses previously stored data rather than making a new query.[m

               ‚îå‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î¨‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îê[m

               ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îº‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î§[m
               ‚îÇ                       [1m[tally][0m                                     ‚îÇ                                   single-character code indicating current value of the [1mselect[0m field of the peer status word                        ‚îÇ[m
               ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îº‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î§[m
               ‚îÇ                       [1mremote[0m                                      ‚îÇ                                   host name (or IP number) of peer                                                                                  ‚îÇ[m

               ‚îÇ                       [1mst[0m                                          ‚îÇ                                   stratum                                                                                                           ‚îÇ[m

               ‚îÇ                       [1mt[0m                                           ‚îÇ                                   [1mu[0m: unicast, [1mb[0m: broadcast, [1ml[0m: local                                                                                ‚îÇ[m
               ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îº‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î§[m
               ‚îÇ                       [1mwhen[0m                                        ‚îÇ                                   sec/min/hr since last received packet                                                                             ‚îÇ[m
               ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îº‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î§[m
               ‚îÇ                       [1mpoll[0m                                        ‚îÇ                                   poll interval (log2 s)                                                                                            ‚îÇ[m
               ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îº‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î§[m
               ‚îÇ                       [1mreach[0m                                       ‚îÇ                                   reach shift register (octal)                                                                                      ‚îÇ[m
               ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îº‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î§[m
               ‚îÇ                       [1mdelay[0m                                       ‚îÇ                                   roundtrip delay                                                                                                   ‚îÇ[m
               ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îº‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î§[m
               ‚îÇ                       [1moffset[0m                                      ‚îÇ                                   offset                                                                                                            ‚îÇ[m
               ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îº‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î§[m
               ‚îÇ                       [1mjitter[0m                                      ‚îÇ                                   jitter                                                                                                            ‚îÇ[m
               ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚î¥‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îò[m

       [1mreadvar[0m [4massocID[24m [4mname[24m [1m[[0m [1m=[0m [4mvalue[24m [1m][0m [1m[,...][0m[m
[m
       [1mrv[0m [4massocID[24m [1m[[0m [4mname[24m [1m][0m [1m[,...][0m[m
               Display the specified variables. If [4massocID[24m is zero, the variables are from the system variables name space, otherwise they are from the peer variables name space. The [4massocID[24m is required, as the same name can occur in[m
               both spaces. If no [4mname[24m is included, all operative variables in the name space are displayed. In this case only, if the [4massocID[24m is omitted, it is assumed zero. Multiple names are specified  with  comma  separators  and[m
               without  whitespace. Note that time values are represented in milliseconds and frequency values in parts-per-million (PPM). Some NTP timestamps are represented in the format YYYYMMDDTTTT, where YYYY is the year, MM the[m
               month of year, DD the day of month and TTTT the time of day.[m
[m
       [1msaveconfig[0m [4mfilename[24m[m
               Write the current configuration, including any runtime modifications given with [1m:config[0m or [1mconfig-from-file[0m, to the ntpd host's file [4mfilename[24m. This command will be rejected by the server unless saveconfigdir appears in[m
               the  [1mntpd[0m configuration file. [4mfilename[24m can use strftime() format specifiers to substitute the current date and time, for example, [1msaveconfig[0m [1mntp-%Y%m%d-%H%M%S.conf[0m. The filename used is stored in system variable [1msaved‚Äê[0m[m
               [1mconfig[0m. Authentication is required.[m
[m
       [1mwritevar[0m [4massocID[24m [4mname[24m [1m=[0m [4mvalue[24m [1m[,...][0m[m
               Write the specified variables. If the [4massocID[24m is zero, the variables are from the system variables name space, otherwise they are from the peer variables name space. The [4massocID[24m is required, as the same name can  occur[m
               in both spaces.[m
[7m Manual page ntpq(8) line 141 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K[?1l>[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 17:07:34]# man ntpstat
[?1049h[?1h=ntpstat(8)                                                                                               System Manager's Manual                                                                                               ntpstat(8)[m
[m
[1mNAME[0m[m
       ntpstat - show network time synchronisation status[m
[m
[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
       [1mntpstat[0m[m
[m
[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
       [4mntpstat[24m  will  report the synchronisation state of the NTP daemon (ntpd) running on the local machine.  If the local system is found to be synchronised to a reference time source, [4mntpstat[24m will report the approximate time accu‚Äê[m
       racy.[m
[m
       When the synchronised state is reported, it means the system clock was updated at some point.  There is no timeout for this state.  It will stay there even when the source becomes unreachable and there  are  no  other  sources[m
       available.  However, the reported accuracy will be slowly increasing, in the default ntpd configuration by 15 microseconds per second.[m
[m
[1mRETURNS[0m[m
       [4mntpstat[24m returns 0 if clock is synchronised.  [4mntpstat[24m returns 1 if clock is not synchronised.  [4mntpstat[24m returns 2 if clock state is indeterminant, for example if ntpd is not contactable.[m
[m
[1mSEE[0m [1mALSO[0m[m
       [1mntp_misc[0m(5), [1mntpd[0m(8), [1mntpq[0m(8), [1mntpdc[0m(8)[m
[m
[1mAUTHOR[0m[m
       G. Richard Keech (rkeech@redhat.com)[m
[m
4th Berkeley Distribution                                                                                                                                                                                                      ntpstat(8)[m
[7m Manual page ntpstat(8) line 1/32 (END) (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K/[Kss[Ktt[Krr[Kaa[Ktt[K...skipping...

[m
[1mNAME[0m[m
       ntpstat - show network time synchronisation status[m
[m
[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
       [1mntpstat[0m[m
[m
[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
       [4mntpstat[24m  will  report the synchronisation state of the NTP daemon (ntpd) running on the local machine.  If the local system is found to be synchronised to a reference time source, [4mntpstat[24m will report the approximate time accu‚Äê[m
       racy.[m
[m
       When the synchronised state is reported, it means the system clock was updated at some point.  There is no timeout for this state.  It will stay there even when the source becomes unreachable and there  are  no  other  sources[m
       available.  However, the reported accuracy will be slowly increasing, in the default ntpd configuration by 15 microseconds per second.[m
[m
[1mRETURNS[0m[m
       [4mntpstat[24m returns 0 if clock is synchronised.  [4mntpstat[24m returns 1 if clock is not synchronised.  [4mntpstat[24m returns 2 if clock state is indeterminant, for example if ntpd is not contactable.[m

[1mSEE[0m [1mALSO[0m[m

[1;1Hntpstat(8)                                                                                               System Manager's Manual                                                                                               ntpstat(8)[m
[2;1H[m
[3;1H[1mNAME[0m[m
[4;1H       ntpstat - show network time synchronisation status[m
[5;1H[m
[6;1H[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
[7;1H       [1mntpstat[0m[m
[8;1H[m
[9;1H[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
[10;1H       [4mntpstat[24m  will  report the synchronisation state of the NTP daemon (ntpd) running on the local machine.  If the local system is found to be synchronised to a reference time source, [4mntpstat[24m will report the approximate time accu‚Äê[m
[11;1H       racy.[m
[12;1H[m
[13;1H       When the synchronised state is reported, it means the system clock was updated at some point.  There is no timeout for this state.  It will stay there even when the source becomes unreachable and there  are  no  other  sources[m
[14;1H       available.  However, the reported accuracy will be slowly increasing, in the default ntpd configuration by 15 microseconds per second.[m
[15;1H[m
[16;1H[1mRETURNS[0m[m
[17;1H       [4mntpstat[24m returns 0 if clock is synchronised.  [4mntpstat[24m returns 1 if clock is not synchronised.  [4mntpstat[24m returns 2 if clock state is indeterminant, for example if ntpd is not contactable.[m
[18;1H[m
[19;1H[1mSEE[0m [1mALSO[0m[m
[20;1H       [1mntp_misc[0m(5), [1mntpd[0m(8), [1mntpq[0m(8), [1mntpdc[0m(8)[m
[21;1H[m
[22;1H[1mAUTHOR[0m[m
[23;1H       G. Richard Keech (rkeech@redhat.com)[m
[24;1H[m
[25;1H4th Berkeley Distribution                                                                                                                                                                                                      ntpstat(8)[m
[26;1H[1m~[0m
[66;1H[1;1Hntpstat(8)                                                                                               System Manager's Manual                                                                                               ntpstat(8)[m
[2;1H[m
[3;1H[1mNAME[0m[m
[4;1H       ntpstat - show network time synchronisation status[m
[5;1H[m
[6;1H[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
[7;1H       [1mntpstat[0m[m
[8;1H[m
[9;1H[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
[10;1H       [4mntpstat[24m  will  report the synchronisation state of the NTP daemon (ntpd) running on the local machine.  If the local system is found to be synchronised to a reference time source, [4mntpstat[24m will report the approximate time accu‚Äê[m
[11;1H       racy.[m
[12;1H[m
[13;1H       When the synchronised state is reported, it means the system clock was updated at some point.  There is no timeout for this state.  It will stay there even when the source becomes unreachable and there  are  no  other  sources[m
[14;1H       available.  However, the reported accuracy will be slowly increasing, in the default ntpd configuration by 15 microseconds per second.[m
[15;1H[m
[16;1H[1mRETURNS[0m[m
[17;1H       [4mntpstat[24m returns 0 if clock is synchronised.  [4mntpstat[24m returns 1 if clock is not synchronised.  [4mntpstat[24m returns 2 if clock state is indeterminant, for example if ntpd is not contactable.[m
[18;1H[m
[19;1H[1mSEE[0m [1mALSO[0m[m
[20;1H       [1mntp_misc[0m(5), [1mntpd[0m(8), [1mntpq[0m(8), [1mntpdc[0m(8)[m
[21;1H[m
[22;1H[1mAUTHOR[0m[m
[23;1H       G. Richard Keech (rkeech@redhat.com)[m
[24;1H[m
[25;1H4th Berkeley Distribution                                                                                                                                                                                                      ntpstat(8)[m
[26;1H[1m~[0m
[66;1H[K[7mPattern not found  (press RETURN)[27m[66;1H[K[K[?1l>[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 17:08:40]# man ntpq
[?1049h[?1h=ntpq(8)                                                                                                  System Manager's Manual                                                                                                  ntpq(8)[m
[m
[1mNAME[0m[m
       ntpq - standard NTP query program[m
[m
[1mSYNOPSIS[0m[m
       [1mntpq[0m [1m[-46dinp][0m [1m[-c[0m [4mcommand[24m[1m][0m [1m[[0m[4mhost[24m[1m][0m [1m[...][0m[m
[m
[1mDESCRIPTION[0m[m
       The  [1mntpq[0m utility program is used to monitor NTP daemon [1mntpd[0m operations and determine performance. It uses the standard NTP mode 6 control message formats defined in Appendix B of the NTPv3 specification RFC1305. The same for‚Äê[m
       mats are used in NTPv4, although some of the variable names have changed and new ones added. The description on this page is for the NTPv4 variables.[m
[m
       The program can be run either in interactive mode or controlled using command line arguments. Requests to read and write arbitrary variables can be assembled, with raw and pretty-printed output  options  being  available.  The[m
       [1mntpq[0m can also obtain and print a list of peers in a common format by sending multiple queries to the server.[m
[m
       If  one  or  more  request  options  is  included on the command line when [1mntpq[0m is executed, each of the requests will be sent to the NTP servers running on each of the hosts given as command line arguments, or on localhost by[m
       default. If no request options are given, [1mntpq[0m will attempt to read commands from the standard input and execute these on the NTP server running on the first host given on the command line, again defaulting to  localhost  when[m
       no other host is specified. [1mntpq[0m will prompt for commands if the standard input is a terminal device.[m
[m
       [1mntpq[0m  uses  NTP mode 6 packets to communicate with the NTP server, and hence can be used to query any compatible server on the network which permits it. Note that since NTP is a UDP protocol this communication will be somewhat[m
       unreliable, especially over large distances in terms of network topology. [1mntpq[0m makes one attempt to retransmit requests, and will time requests out if the remote host is not heard from within a suitable timeout time.[m
[m
       Note that in contexts where a host name is expected, a [1m-4[0m qualifier preceding the host name forces DNS resolution to the IPv4 namespace, while a [1m-6[0m qualifier forces DNS resolution to the IPv6 namespace.[m
[m
       For examples and usage, see the NTP Debugging Techniques page.[m
[m
       Command line options are described following. Specifying a command line option other than [1m-i[0m or [1m-n[0m will cause the specified query (queries) to be sent to the indicated host(s) immediately. Otherwise, [1mntpq[0m will attempt to  read[m
       interactive format commands from the standard input.[m
[m
       [1m-4[0m      Force DNS resolution of following host names on the command line to the IPv4 namespace.[m
[m
       [1m-6[0m      Force DNS resolution of following host names on the command line to the IPv6 namespace.[m
[m
       [1m-c[0m      The following argument is interpreted as an interactive format command and is added to the list of commands to be executed on the specified host(s). Multiple [1m-c[0m options may be given.[m
[m
       [1m-d[0m      Turn on debugging mode.[m
[m
       [1m-i[0m      Force [1mntpq[0m to operate in interactive mode. Prompts will be written to the standard output and commands read from the standard input.[m
[m
       [1m-n[0m      Output all host addresses in dotted-quad numeric format rather than converting to the canonical host names.[m
[m
       [1m-p[0m      Print a list of the peers known to the server as well as a summary of their state. This is equivalent to the [1mpeers[0m interactive command.[m
[m
[1mINTERNAL[0m [1mCOMMANDS[0m[m
       Interactive  format  commands  consist of a keyword followed by zero to four arguments. Only enough characters of the full keyword to uniquely identify the command need be typed. The output of a command is normally sent to the[m
       standard output, but optionally the output of individual commands may be sent to a file by appending a [1m>[0m, followed by a file name, to the command line. A number of interactive format commands are executed entirely  within  the[m
       [1mntpq[0m program itself and do not result in NTP mode-6 requests being sent to a server. These are described following.[m
[m
       [1m?[0m [1m[[0m[4mcommand_keyword[24m[1m][0m[m
[m
       [1mhelp[0m [1m[[0m[4mcommand_keyword[24m[1m][0m[m
               A [1m?[0m by itself will print a list of all the command keywords known to [1mntpq[0m. A [1m?[0m followed by a command keyword will print function and usage information about the command.[m
[m
       [1maddvars[0m [4mname[24m [1m[[0m [1m=[0m [4mvalue[24m[1m][0m [1m[...][0m[m
[m
       [1mrmvars[0m [4mname[24m [1m[...][0m[m
[m
       [1mclearvars[0m[m
               The arguments to this command consist of a list of items of the form [4mname[24m [1m=[0m [4mvalue[24m, where the [1m=[0m [4mvalue[24m is ignored, and can be omitted in read requests. [1mntpq[0m maintains an internal list in which data to be included in con‚Äê[m
               trol messages can be assembled, and sent using the [1mreadlist[0m and [1mwritelist[0m commands described below. The [1maddvars[0m command allows variables and optional values to be added to the list. If more than one variable is  to  be[m
               added, the list should be comma-separated and not contain white space. The [1mrmvars[0m command can be used to remove individual variables from the list, while the [1mclearlist[0m command removes all variables from the list.[m
[m
       [1mcooked[0m  Display server messages in prettyprint format.[m
[m
       [1mdebug[0m [1mmore[0m [1m|[0m [1mless[0m [1m|[0m [1moff[0m[m
[7m Manual page ntpq(8) line 1 (press h for help or q to quit)[27m[K[K[?1l>[?1049l]0;root@vm0:/home/romain.pereira[root@vm0 17:09:35]# vim /etc/ntp.conf 
[?1049h[?1h=[2;1H‚ñΩ[6n[1;1H  [1;1H[1;66r[?12;25h[?12l[?25h[27m[m[H[2J[?25l[66;1H"/etc/ntp.conf" 64L, 2114C[>c[1;1H[34m# For more information about this file, see the man pages
# ntp.conf(5), ntp_acc(5), ntp_auth(5), ntp_clock(5), ntp_misc(5), ntp_mon(5).[m

driftfile /var/lib/ntp/drift

[34m# Permit time synchronization with our time source, but do not
# permit the source to query or modify the service on this system.[m
restrict default nomodify notrap nopeer noquery

[34m# Permit all access over the loopback interface.  This could
# be tightened as well, but to do so would effect some of
# the administrative functions.[m
restrict 127.0.0.1
restrict ::1

[34m# Hosts on local network are less restricted.
#restrict 192.168.1.0 mask 255.255.255.0 nomodify notrap

# Use public [m[30m[43mserver[m[34ms from the pool.ntp.org project.
# Please consider joining the pool (http://www.pool.ntp.org/join.html).
#[m[30m[43mserver[m[34m 0.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
#[m[30m[43mserver[m[34m 1.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
#[m[30m[43mserver[m[34m 2.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst
#[m[30m[43mserver[m[34m 3.centos.pool.ntp.org iburst

#[m[30m[43mserver[m[34m 62.210.103.129 iburst
#[m[30m[43mserver[m[34m 88.191.250.97 iburst
#[m
[30m[43mserver[m 127.127.1.0
fudge 127.127.1.0 stratum 10

[34m#broadcast 192.168.1.255 autokey        # broadcast [m[30m[43mserver[m
[34m#broadcastclient                        # broadcast client
#broadcast 224.0.1.1 autokey            # multicast [m[30m[43mserver[m
[34m#multicastclient 224.0.1.1              # multicast client
#manycast[m[30m[43mserver[m[34m 239.255.254.254         # manycast [m[30m[43mserver[m
[34m#manycastclient 239.255.254.254 autokey # manycast client

# Enable public key cryptography.
#crypto[m

includefile /etc/ntp/crypto/pw

[34m# Key file containing the keys and key identifiers used when operating
# with symmetric key cryptography. [m
keys /etc/ntp/keys

[34m# Specify the key identifiers which are trusted.
#trustedkey 4 8 42

# Specify the key identifier to use with the ntpdc utility.
#requestkey 8

# Specify the key identifier to use with the ntpq utility.
#controlkey 8

# Enable writing of statistics records.
#statistics clockstats cryptostats loopstats peerstats

# Disable the monitoring facility to prevent amplification attacks using ntpdc
# monlist command when default restrict does not include the noquery flag. See
# CVE-2013-5211 for more details.
# Note: Monitoring will not be disabled with the limited restriction flag.[m
disable monitor
